Kamsack, Sask.

12th Feb. 1935.

Sir,

I beg to advise that during the cold spell we just recently experienced, the St. Philips School were having difficulty with the line from the well to the pressure tank freezing caused principally by the door on the boiler room leading outside not being sufficiently tight and when opened during a south wind cools off the furnace room, also engine room and the room which houses the pressure tank. A great deal of this direct draft could be avoided by the building of a small porch at this entrance which could be put on each winter.

The Acting Principal at St. Philips asks if the Department would do this for the school, an estimate of the cost would be as follows:

Lumber and material for porch $15.
Labour $6.

$21.00

The labour could be done by Mr. G. Barton who lives quite near to the school.

May I have your instructions herein?

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, February 22, 1935.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, I beg to say that you may incur an expenditure not exceeding $21 in the erection of a porch near the door of a boiler room at the St. Philips Indian Residential.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Ottawa, March 19, 1935.

Sir,-

For some time past, the Department has been allowing a grant at the rate of $40.00 a month towards the salary of a night watchman at the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

Our appropriation for this purpose is limited and, in view of the fact that requests have been made for allowances towards night watchmen's salaries at several schools that have not previously received same, the Department has found it necessary to place all Indian residential schools on the same basis and, therefore, we will only be able to make the allowance towards the night watchman's salary for a period of seven months. Consequently, the allowance for the night watchman's salary at the St. Philips Indian Residential School will be discontinued from April 30th, 1935.

Payment of this allowance will be resumed from October 1st, 1935, and will be continued until April 30th, 1936. The amount allowed will be the same as formerly, viz., $40.00 a month, and, if the Principal so desires, you should forward a voucher at the end of each month during the period for which the allowance is made.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

H. A. W. R. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

Sir,

I beg to confirm night letter forwarded last night in connection with the water supply at the St. Philips School, which read as follows:

"St. Philips school water supply given out. May I have authority to tank a supply to relieve temporarily. Writing."

Yesterday I received a letter from the Principal which I forwarded together with my report and later saw Dr. Wallace who for sanitary reasons asked me to notify the Department by wire as some immediate relief has to be given.

In the meantime they are hauling water in a barrel. I thought however if I could get a man with a proper tank and team to haul from other wells to fill the present one, it would relieve for the time being until such time as a decision could be reached as to a permanent supply.

St. Philips, Sask.
3rd April, 1935.

Dear Sir,

I wish to advise you regarding the inside well at this school, the supply of water being insufficient to wash dishes let alone have any pressure in case of fire. The only place we have any water today is in the basement the other three floors being without any. This is due to the well appearing to dry up. It was thought once that we were on a water vein but the difficulty we have experienced in the past months would indicate that we are not and ask you to take the question of water supply and the remedy to the Department, they might have some suggestion to offer.

At present overnight there is only about one foot of water comes into the well and we are hauling water from the well at the stable now in order to have enough to do the washing; this does not give us any for the dormitories.

I do not think that deepening the present well would be any remedy as there seems to be blue clay at the bottom. The present inlet of water seems to be about seven or eight feet from the bottom of the well.

Would the Department supply an expert water finder to try and locate a vein or what other means would they suggest?

Could this matter be taken up immediately as the water supply here is serious?

Yours very truly,

E.A.W.R. McKenzie Esq.
Indian Agent.
Kamsask, Sask.

[Signature]

3rd April, 1935.

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from the Principal of St. Philips Indian Residential school regarding the water supply at the school. It appears that they have been experiencing difficulty this past two months. At times they cannot get a sufficient supply to wash dishes, particularly on wash days at the school. Water on the dormitory floors is out of the question which is necessary for sanitary flushing of the toilets.

Can something be done along the lines of another well being sunk from which their present well could be filled by pumping?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, April 12, 1935.

Sir:

The Department has received a report from Mr. E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Indian Agent, Kamsack, Sask., regarding the water supply at the St. Philips Indian Residential School. The school has been experiencing difficulty during the past two months, as, at times, they cannot obtain sufficient water to wash dishes, let alone have any pressure in case of fire. The Principal states the only place they have water is in the basement; the other three floors being without any.

This situation is due to the well having become dry. The school is at present hauling water from the well at the stable. The Agent states that water on the dormitory floors is out of the question and that they are unable to flush the toilets.

It is doubtful if deepening the present well would be any remedy. The present inlet of water appears to be about seven or eight feet from the bottom of the well.

The Agent has recommended that something be done along the line of having another well sunk. Difficulty is being experienced regarding the water supply at a number of the Indian schools in the Prairie Provinces. This is, no doubt, due to the lack of rainfall during the past few years, and it is hoped the situation will be overcome, should there be a rainy season.

I would request that you enquire into the water situation at the St. Philips School and submit a report regarding the action you would advise be taken to improve present conditions. Please state if you would recommend that another well be drilled and what likelihood there would be of obtaining an ample supply of water. You should give an estimate of the cost of any recommendations you make.

Mr. Agent McKenzie is being informed that the matter is being referred to you for attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

W. Murison, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, April 12, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the St. Philips Indian Residential School, regarding the water supply. I may say that the same situation has developed at a number of the Indian residential schools in the Prairie Provinces, due to lack of rainfall during the past few seasons.

It would, no doubt, be useless to deepen the present well, and there is little guarantee, if a new well was drilled, that a sufficient supply of water would be obtained.

The Department is referring this matter to Mr. Inspector Murison, who will, no doubt, communicate with you. In the meantime, the school authorities will have to make the best arrangements they can to tank a supply. When we receive Mr. Murison's report as to the action he would recommend be taken, consideration will be given to effecting a remedy for the present situation.

The inconvenience occasioned the school is regretted. The Principal should take extra precautions to overcome fire hazard.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

E.A.W.R. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of department letter No. 117-3-5, dated the 12th instant, regarding the water supply at the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

I may advise the department that I plan on visiting the Pelly Agency in the near future. I have been putting off my visit until the roads become passable. At the present time they are in bad condition and it may be a week yet before they are fit to travel on. The Indian Agent, Mr. McKenzie, informs me that they are hauling water by a tank and are getting along alright in the meantime. When I visit the Agency I will make a careful enquiry into the water situation at this school and will submit a report.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan

Sir,

Replying to your letter No.117-3-5 of the 12th inst. regarding the water supply at the St. Philips school, I beg to advise that in accordance with instructions contained in your telegram of the 5th inst. I hired Edward Quewzance of Keesekonse Band to haul 20 tanks from a spring about 3½ miles away @ $1.00 per tank, for which voucher is being forwarded.

This has given relief to their present distress and when there yesterday suggested to the Principal that he arrange to haul one or two tanks each week, particularly on wash day.

With the water hauled, there is about four feet of water in the well and with what comes in it is about holding at that, except on wash days.

It is thought now that the present well could be deepened and create a reservoir as it appears that after four feet depth of water has been reached, it runs away.

With hauling two or three tanks of water each week, am of the opinion they can get along until a permanent remedy can be decided upon.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

DEPT INDIAN AFFAIRS OTTAWA ONT

PLANK TOP SCEPTIC TANK STPHILIPS SCHOOL ROTTED AND CAVING IN
REMOVAL OF EARTH FROM TOP NECESSARY TO PREVENT RENDERING TANK
USELESS MAY I HAVE THIS DONE WRITING

EBEN W R MCKENZIE.

This is a Collect message and will be charged to your account unless we are notified at once to the contrary.
Ottawa, May 10, 1935.

Sir:

I have your telegram of today's date, regarding the condition of the plank top of the septic tank at the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

In this connection it is considered that the school staff should be able to undertake the removal of the earth from the plank top of the tank. No skilled labour should be required for this work. If new plank is required to cover the top of the tank, the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of the quantity necessary, from a firm on the approved list. The school staff should be able to install the new plank and re-cover it with earth. However, if further work will be necessary to place the tank in good condition, the Department will consider same when your letter is received.

It is considered that it was not necessary to incur the expense in telegraphing the Department. It is desired that all expense for telegraphic service be kept to the lowest possible point, and only in urgent cases should use be made of this form of communication.

As stated, the matter of the repairs required to the tank will receive further consideration when your letter is received.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary

E.A.W.R. MacKenzie, (Jr.) Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.
Kamsack, Sask.
9th May, 1935.

Sir,

Please confirm my letter of even date which reads as follows:

Plank septic tank St. Philips school rotted and caving in. Removal of earth from necessary to prevent rendering tank useless. May I have this done. Writing.

Sgd.

This is a cement tank with a double plank 2 inch. top, covered with earth to a depth of about two feet to prevent freezing. From all the information I can gather a cement top reinforced with steel rods is recommended and pending receipt of your advice I have asked Mr. Barton to give me a figure on what the cost of such would be.

One end of the tank has completely caved in, earth needs to be removed and what has fallen in, cleaned out in order for the tank to perform its proper functions and then be retopped with cement and covered with earth. In the meantime I have engaged an indian to clean out the portion that is caved in.

I trust the action I have taken is in accordance with your wishes.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
St. Philip's Sask
May 15, 35

Mr. McKenzie, Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask

Dear Sir,

In reply to the answer to your telegram, re-
Septic Tank here, I beg to remind you of the following facts:- This
is one of the smallest boarding schools and therefore the only man
on the Staff is the farm labourer whose time is fully taken up at
present with seeding operations. As for the pupils, they are all far
too small to undertake any such work as that. I may also state, that
on account of the roof falling in, together with so much earth, it
flooded up the tank and plugged it entirely. This necessitated im-
mediate steps being taken to have the tank emptied and the sewage
system opened up again. The tank was in a terrible state, and even
among the Indians here, I had trouble to find a man who would under-
take to empty it, and his lowest price was twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
A whole day passed before he could persuade two more Indians to help
him. This will perhaps give you a little idea of the repulsiveness
of the job, all of which was caused through putting on a lumber top
instead of one of cement when it was constructed.

Something must be done very soon as the septic
tank remains open at present, and besides being a source of danger, it
certainly is not in the best interests of the health of the inmates
here, especially when the wind is in an unfavorable direction.

In the reply to your telegram, I note there is
no reference to the replacing of the top with concrete and I think
this a pity because in about another five years, we shall be up against
the same kind of trouble again. As I hear from the contractor that
the costs of the material for the lumber covering with rubber roofing
between the cover and earth will cost about ninety-five dollars ($95.00)
whereas the material for a good reinforced concrete cover delivered
here will only cost about ninety-three dollars ($93.00). The only diff-
erence would be about thirty dollars ($30.00) for the extra work with
concrete that would last indefinitely.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Acting Principal
Kamsack, Sask.

May 10th, 1935.
Sir,

Replying to your letter No.117-3-5 of the 10th inst., relative to the septic tank at St. Philips School, I beg to advise this being a small school, there is no staff outside the Principal except a farmer whose time is fairly well occupied at this season of the year.

At the time I viewed the septic tank in which had taken place, the tank had then been blocked and the contents were gradually rising and fearing that the gasses therfrom and odours would back up into the building, I took the action of getting an Indian to clear that portion. With this and some other help the Principal hired the whole roof was later cleared and the whole tank cleaned out to the floor.

As above explained, this was my reason for sending a telegram.

At present the top remains open pending your further instructions and in view of the fact that this school has practically no staff, except the Sisters, would the Department reconsider their decision, as to replacement and the work that had to be done at the time.

In this connection, I enclose a list showing the cost of what has been done and paid by the Principal, together with two alternative plans of replacing roof, from Mr. G. Barton, who is resident one quarter mile from the school.

May I have your instructions herein?

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

MAY 21 1935
Ottawa, May 22, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with further reference to the septic tank at the St. Philips Indian Residential School, also your letter of the 18th instant, enclosing a communication from the Acting Principal. It is noted that the staff will be unable to carry out any of the work in placing the tank in a satisfactory condition.

The Department will approve of you incurring the expenditure required in removing the earth and rotten wood and cleaning out the septic tank, at a cost of $25.00, and also the expenditure required to cover the tank with reinforced concrete about six inches thick, with one-half inch iron rods laid 8 inches apart, both lengthways and across in the cement, also installing two manholes, 3 ft. square and 3 ft. high, of concrete, and replacing the top covering of the earth - the total cost not to exceed $136.00 for material and labour, complete.

You should see that a satisfactory job is completed in re-covering the septic tank, and, when the work has been finished to your satisfaction, you should forward a certified account, in triplicate, showing in full detail the material and labour.

Your obedient servant,

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

MEMORANDUM

June 19, 1935.

DR. MCGLL:

Does the Department propose to carry out any painting at the St. Philips Indian Mission, Saskatchewan. If so, will quotations be asked?

Private Secretary.
June 30, 1935.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

Referring to your memorandum of the 19th instant, in which you request to be informed if it is intended to have any painting done at the St. Philips Indian Residential School, Kisnack, Sask., and if quotations will be asked, I would say that there is an item in the Estimates for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to the amount of $300.00, for painting at this school.

The Department is taking up the matter with the local Indian Agent, requesting him to give details of the painting required. When full information is received, the matter will be referred to the Honourable the Minister for his direction.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, June 21, 1936.

Sir:

Funds, to the amount of $300.00, are available in our Estimates for the current fiscal year, to carry out painting to the main building of the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

I would request that you take up this matter with the Principal and inform the Department of the work you would recommend be carried out, giving full details. If the paint, oils, and other materials were supplied, could the school staff perform the labour? If not, you should state how you would recommend having the work done. The above is the full amount that will be available this year for painting at this school, including the paint and labour.

Your early reply, giving the information requested, will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

Referring to your memorandum of June 19th, last, and my reply thereto of the following day, regarding the proposed painting of the St. Philips Indian Residential School building at Kamsack, Sask., (Electoral District of Yorkton), Mr. E.A.W.R. McKenzie, the local Indian Agent, has furnished a report, stating the painting required. There is approximately 15,000 sq. ft. of surface, 150 windows, screens and storm sash. The Agent obtained a quotation from the Bays Hardware Company, Kamsack, Sask., for the material and labour, as follows:-

1. One coat only on building, not including screens or storm sash - $800.
2. One coat on building, screens and storm sash - $326.
3. Two coats on building, screens and storm sash - $450.

The above are for the outside of building, only.

The Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year provides an amount of $300. towards the cost of the painting; but I would recommend, for your approval, that the exterior of the building and the screens and storm sash be given two coats of paint, at a cost of $450 for material and labour. Our Appropriation will stand the extra cost required, over the amount provided. I would recommend, further, that the work be carried out under the supervision of the Agent - he to purchase paint and other materials required, from firms on the approved list - and that the labour be performed by a competent painter.

I beg to request that you will advise regarding the name of the painter who should be employed; the firms who should be asked to quote on supplying the paint, oils, etc.; and also if you approve of the expenditure, to an amount of $450 in carrying out the work. The staff of the school, consisting of the Principal, the Farmer and a number of Reverend Sisters, will be unable to furnish any part of the labour.

Sir:-

Referring to Departmental letter No. 117-3-5, dated April 12th last, in regard to the water situation at the St. Philips Indian Residential School, Kamsack, Sask., I beg to report that I visited this school and enquired thoroughly into the water situation on May 27th and at that time the supply had returned to the well and the situation appeared to have cleared up.

As the source of this water supply is from an underground spring, it was hoped that with heavy rain falls during the summer months that the situation would be cleared up and an ample water supply assured. I visited the school again in July and a third time in September. Each time I made enquiry and found that they were getting an ample supply of water, but during the present month the supply has become low and it looks as though it would not be safe to enter the winter depending upon the present well.

I do not think that the situation would be satisfactorily met by deepening the present well. It would be a difficult matter to accomplish in that the present well is lined with cement rings and a heavy cement block covers the top of the well.

My recommendation is that a well be dug outside and in close proximity to the present pump house of sufficient diameter to provide a reservoir and have this well dug as far below the water line as possible. I estimate that this would be approximately forty-five feet. This well could be cribbed - with 2" planks -

Ottawa, October 22, 1935.

Sir:

I have your 310-11A R.C. of the 17th instant, regarding the water situation at the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

The Department approves of your recommendation, that another well be dug, outside and in close proximity to the present pump-house, of sufficient diameter to provide a reservoir to a depth as far below the water line as possible. You may therefore incur an expenditure, not exceeding the sum of $300.00, in having the well dug and cribbed with two inch planks. The water from this auxiliary well should be connected with the present pumping system and utilized when the supply in the present well becomes low. I would request that you arrange to have the work proceeded with at an early date. You should have the auxiliary well completed and placed in a satisfactory condition. It is hoped that it will not be necessary to incur any expenditure for the purpose, in excess of the amount mentioned above. If possible, Indian labour should be used in the digging of the well. However, the matter will be left in your hands, to make the best arrangements to have the work satisfactorily completed and at the lowest possible cost.

After the work has been finished, you should forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. The number of days or hours each labourer was employed should be stated on the voucher for the labour. You will be forwarded, later, an encumbrance certificate, authorizing the expenditure to the sum of $300, and, in forwarding your vouchers, you should state, on each copy thereof, that the expenditure was incurred under authority of this certificate.

Dear Sir:

Re: Painting Contract-St. Phillip's School.

In the early part of July we tendered for the painting of the above building. The Department of Indian Affairs approved of this tender at the beginning of October. We hesitated at that time to accept this due to the lateness of the season, but finally accepted it, taking a chance on the weather holding out for us to complete the job. You know that the weather turned very unfavourable towards the end of the month so that we are not able to complete the job until the month of May, 1936.

While we have finished about 65% of the work we have invested in all the material to finish the job; and now we are obligated to pay for the labour completed so far. Under ordinary circumstances we would not expect any payment until the job was completed, as it stands now, not expecting to be in a position to complete the contract until May, we would consider it a favour if the Department would advance us 50% of the contract price.

As security the Department has 65% of the contract completed and we would be willing to place in your care the balance of material necessary to finish the job. This would provide ample security.

We would be very much obliged if you would take this up with the Department of Indian Affairs and explain the circumstances to them. Trusting that you will do this without much delay, we remain,

Yours very truly,
Bay's Hardware Company
per A. Bay.

Sir:

Referring to Departmental letter No. 117-3-5, dated the 22nd October, 1925, in which was authorized the sinking of a well at the St. Phillips Indian Residential School in the Pelly Agency as a result of the recommendation made in my letter to the Department dated October 17th, I may advise the Department that the auxiliary well was duly completed and for a time it appeared that the water question at this school was satisfactorily solved.

A well was dug six feet in diameter and for a time there was seven feet of water in this well and it seemed to come in quite fast. I am now in receipt of information that both this and the original well are not supplying sufficient water for the requirements at the school and the Principal now requests that a deep well be sunk with a view to getting a sufficient supply for the requirements.

Dear Sir:

I have your 310-11A R.C. of the 15th instant, regarding the condition of the wells at the St. Philips Indian Residential School. The Department is concerned over the situation that has developed in connection with the two wells at this school, as we were of opinion that the auxiliary well which was recently dug would provide an ample supply of water.

The Department has noted the Principal's suggestion, that, in order to obtain a permanent supply, a deep well be drilled. No provision has been made in the Estimates to cover the cost of drilling this well. We have no information on which to base an estimate of the costs. Our funds during the balance of the present fiscal year are practically assigned, and, unless there is a real emergency, it will be impossible to provide the expenditure. You might advise if there is a well drilling outfit in the vicinity of the school and if the Principal or yourself can state the approximate depth required to drill a new well to obtain a permanent supply of water. If, after consulting the Principal and the local Indian Agent, you can furnish a concrete plan for a permanent water supply, either by deepening the present wells or drilling a new one, and if you are able to give an estimate of the cost of any work you would recommend be carried out, the Department will further consider the matter of providing funds for the purpose. In the meantime, the Principal will have to conserve the present supply and exercise every care to see that no danger occurs to the building or the pupils and staff, on account of fire.

The closest well drilling machine that I could locate is one now at Muscow near the Qu'Appelle Agency office.

I have been in touch with Mr. Clark who owns this outfit and who gave us very satisfactory service at the Qu'Appelle Agency. He informs me that he will do the work at $2.60 per foot and he will provide the metal casing. He states however that he would require the Department to pay the freight charges on his outfit from Muscow to Kamsack and one half the freight on the return trip.

As stated in my former letter, it is difficult to ascertain the cost of drilling this well as we have no knowledge of any deep well having been drilled in close proximity to the school. The drilling of a well 200 feet deep, including casing and freight charges, would be $628.00. A 300 foot well at the same figures would cost $888.00. The Department have had plenty of experience in connection with deep well drilling. It is pretty much a question of guess work. We might obtain a supply of water of course at 100 feet, but no one can be assured of even the approximate depth we may have to go without some data to go on in the area where the drilling takes place and even that is not always an indication. Mr. Clark is an experienced well driller and I feel like acting upon his advice as to where the well should be sunk. I am quite satisfied.

Ottawa, February 8, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your No. 310-11A R.C., of the 4th instant, with reference to the question of a permanent water supply at the St. Philips Indian Residential School, by the drilling of a deep well.

As it is impossible to ascertain definitely what the cost would be but as it would likely be a large sum, the Department will have no funds to authorize the carrying out of the work. The school will have to carry on under present conditions. The Principal should conserve the water supply now available and continue to exercise every care to see that no danger occurs on account of fire. It is hoped that, at the spring thaw, the present situation will be cleared up and an ample water supply obtained.

Our funds for the balance of the current fiscal year are entirely assigned, and the appropriation for the coming fiscal year is being drastically cut. The Department feels satisfied that the Principal will do his best to see that the present water supply is conserved and that he will augment same by the hauling of water in tanks, sufficient to meet the needs of the school. We regret the inconvenience occasioned the Principal and staff and hope that the present difficulty will be overcome in the spring.

Yours truly,

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 117-3-5, dated the 8th instant, with reference to the question of a permanent water supply at the St. Philips Indian Residential school by the drilling of a deep well.

I may report that upon receipt of your letter I proceeded to the St. Philips school in order that I might thoroughly understand the situation there. I was rather worried about the situation from the reports which I had received and felt that I should make a personal visit and size the situation up.

The wells at the school are supplying sufficient water for the boiler and the toilets throughout the school, but there is no surplus for any other purpose. They are hauling ice from the river and melting same for washing and other requirements. This involves considerable extra work, but they will be able to carry on until the spring opens up. The great danger of course is should a fire break out they would have no surplus of water to use for fire extinguishing purposes. They are however well supplied with fire extinguishers on each floor. A close watch is kept of the building both night and day. They have a night watchman who patrols the school during the night and of course during the day the staff are distributed throughout the building in connection with their daily occupations. They realize the danger and I am satisfied will keep a close watch over the building. There is nothing further than can be done at the present time.

There is a considerable amount of snow on the ground, which made it rather difficult to really size up the situation in so far as getting prospects of a water supply are concerned. I did look into this question however by making an examination of the surrounding land. I again visited the spring which 'out-drops' in a ravine between a quarter and half a mile from the school. I beg to advise the Department that I have received a report from Indian Agent Ostrander to the effect that the sewerage system at the St. Phillips Residential School has been frozen up for about a month and the septic tank has to be emptied every day. This is a disagreeable and slow job with a bucket. An endeavour has been made to thaw out the discharge pipe, but without success, and it appears that it will be necessary to wait until the end of May for the ground to thaw, or dig up the line from the frozen ground which will be rather expensive.

The Reverend Principal has asked if it would be possible for him to be supplied with a suction pump, as per illustration, at a cost of $39.75. If this pump were supplied the difficulty would be overcome satisfactorily, with no further expense and the pump would be on hand for cleaning the septic tank at suitable intervals in the future.

I would recommend, if possible, that authority be granted for the purchase of this pump and may point out that the Principal of this school has had a great deal to put up with during the past winter with a shortage of water all the time and a month of working with a frozen sewerage system. I consider his request a very reasonable one and trust the Department will supply the pump.

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General:

Due to the failure of the present shallow wells at the St. Philips Indian Residential School, Electoral District of Mackenzie, Province of Saskatchewan, a very serious situation has developed. Owing to the lack of water, the lives of the sixty-five (65) children attending the school are endangered and there is no adequate protection for the buildings in case of fire.

In order to ensure a proper water supply, it will be necessary to provide a deep well as soon as possible. Mr. Inspector Murison, in reporting regarding the necessity for a deep well at this school, states that there are no well drillers in the vicinity of the school. The closest well-drilling machine is located at Muscow. This well-drilling machine is owned by Mr. Clark, who had previously given the Department very satisfactory service in digging wells at the Qu'Appelle Indian Agency.

It is difficult to state definitely the cost of drilling a deep well at this school, but it would, possibly, cost as high as $900.00.

Funds for the purpose can be obtained from the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year and, in view of the urgency and importance of this matter, I would appreciate receiving your approval to authorizing Mr. Inspector Murison to engage the services of a competent well driller and to proceed with the work of drilling a well at once.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Kamsack, Sask.,
3rd June, 1936.

Dear Sir:

There has been a considerable amount of correspondence between this office and the office of the Inspector at Regina, regarding the great need for a well at the St. Philip's Residential School, but there is still no improvement in the situation, so far as the school is concerned.

A new well was sunk close to the old one last fall and there seemed to be sufficient water for a time, but this well has now failed and the school has been without an adequate water supply all winter, neither sufficient for washing nor fire protection, and usually not sufficient for flushing the toilets, consequently the fire danger is much greater and the school can not be kept clean and sanitary.

Many proposals have been made to relieve the situation, but there seems to be only one solution, in my opinion, which is to drill a deep well and thus obtain a permanent supply for all times. We have had a test hole sunk near the buildings, and to a depth of about 100 feet, and the whole distance was blue clay, not very promising, to say the least, and it would therefore be unwise for me to attempt to make an estimate of the approximate cost of a deep well. Including casing, the cost is approximately $2.70 per foot, for a drilled well with steel casing, and the depth might be anything from 150 to 400 feet. So far as I can ascertain, there has never been a deep well sunk anywhere in this locality and no one seems to know what formation the sub-soil takes, consequently I can give no useful information as to possible depth.

However, the need is very great and, if funds can be made available, something should be done at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, regarding the need of a well at the St. Philips Indian Residential School. It is noted that the new well, which was sunk close to the old one last fall, has now failed and the school is without an adequate water supply. The Department understands that the only solution towards the obtaining of a permanent supply of water appears to be to have a new deep well drilled.

The Department will approve of the drilling of a new well, to a cost which it is hoped will not exceed the sum of $900. Mr. Jens Johnson, of Kelvington, Sask., who lives in the vicinity of the school, should be employed to do the well drilling. You should see Mr. Johnson and arrange definite terms with him, before he undertakes the work. He should state the price he would charge, per foot, including steel casing. It is hoped that it will not be necessary to drill deeper than approximately, 350 ft. If an ample supply of water is not obtained at this depth, you should have the work delayed and report the results of drilling to that depth to the Department and receive further authority before proceeding with the work. I would request that you arrange with Mr. Johnson to start work as soon as possible. Properly itemized accounts, in triplicate, should be forwarded, covering the expenditure incurred. You should supervise the work, as far as possible, and see that a satisfactory job is done.

Mr. Inspector Murison is being forwarded a copy of this letter, for his information.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit my report for the month of August, 1936, as follows:

The well which is being sunk at the St Phillip's Residential school, is progressing fairly well at the present time, after a great deal of delay. At the time of writing it is down to a depth of about 270 feet, with no water, but present prospects are rather good.

J. P. B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.
Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 9th July, last, No. 117-3-5, in connection with the well at the St. Philips School, and telegrams which have passed between this office and the Department, during the course of the work, I beg to say that prospects at the present time are not good. The hole has now been drilled to a depth of 370 feet, having gone through a very hard clay and some stone practically all the way. At the depth of about 250 feet there was some stone and gravel and easier drilling making it appear that the clay, where there is never any hope of finding water, had been passed. However this hope did not continue for very long until the drill was again in the hard clay, where it is at present.

I have told the driller to stop work until he receives further instructions and he is now repairing his machine. I do not know whether it would be wise to continue, but there is now so much money spent in the dry hole, and the need of water is so great at this school, that I would feel inclined to try further if funds can be made available for the work. It seems a pity to have spent so much on the effort and still be without water. I have talked with the Reverend Principal and of course he is very anxious to continue, but we are aware that there is now considerably more spent than at first estimated. If the Department will give me authority to continue a further 100 feet, if necessary, I will watch the work closely, as I have been doing, and, if there is no change in the soil by the time that the machine reaches 400 feet, I shall have the work stopped.

The machine will be repaired in two days and I would be glad if authority could be given me by telegram in order to expedite the work, in the event that the Department decides to continue.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Referring to file 117-3-5, and several letters and telegrams on the subject of the well drilling at the St. Philips Residential School, I beg to say that work has been stopped and vouchers are being forwarded for payment of this work. The well was drilled to a depth of 569 feet. For the last hundred feet the drill was in a black shale, which looked promising for water, but at last it reached another kind of shale which contains oil in considerable quantity and there is no possibility of striking water as the water would be useless, if any were found in the oil.

I have prepared a sample of the oil-bearing shale and forwarded it to the University at Saskatoon for analysis as I believe there are real prospects for oil, having seen similar formations in Alberta.

It is to be regretted that the water situation at the St. Philip's School remains acute and something will have to be done for this winter. There was a quantity of rain water stored during the past summer, but it will be finished in about two weeks, after which there will be no water for washing, only sufficient for cooking and drinking.

The Assinaboine River is over two miles from the school and it will be necessary to haul water from there for washing and flushing the toilets. The Reverend Principal has asked for authority to hire an Indian with a team and tank for this purpose. The cost will be about ten dollars a week to furnish an adequate quantity of water and I beg to enquire whether the Department is prepared to pay the cost of this. It would appear that this will have to be a permanent arrangement, or at least until the rainfall increases to a point where the shallow surface wells improve. Any change in the surface wells in the past ten years has been the reverse. In any case there is no use trying to locate a well at another point as there is no doubt that the same conditions prevail over a large area, as regards both surface wells and deep wells.

There is a small spring about half-a-mile from the school, the possibilities of which will be explored next spring, but nothing can be done with it at the present time.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources.

I have to refer you to memorandum of June 3rd, last, with reference to providing a well at the St. Philips Indian Residential School, Electoral District of Mackenzie, Province of Saskatchewan. You authorised the employment of Mr. Jens Johnson, of Kelvington, Sask., to do the well drilling. Mr. Johnson was employed, and it was estimated at the time the work commenced that it would cost approximately $900.

Water was not struck at the depth expected, but, as the well driller proceeded downwards, indications were that, with further drilling, water would be obtained. As it was considered necessary to obtain water for this school, the Department, on receipt of recommendations from the Indian Agent, authorised continued drilling, until, at the depth of 569 feet, it was finally decided that there was no hope and the work was discontinued.

Mr. Johnson's account, amounting to $3,039.00 has now been received for payment. I realise that this exceeds the original estimate by a very considerable amount, but the work was done at a reasonable rate per foot and authority to proceed to the depth mentioned was given in the hope that water would be secured. I would appreciate receiving your approval for payment of the account.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 22nd. instant #836,
I beg to report as follows:

In my opinion there was certainly a showing of oil
and shale around the 550 ft. level, shortly before the drilling
was stopped in the new well at St. Philip's Residential School.
A log was not kept by the driller, but I visited the scene of
the work very often and the following are the approximate depths
and strata in the course of drilling in the order mentioned:

- 30 ft. of blue clay;
- 6 ft. of gravel and clay;
- 200 ft. of blue clay;
- 200 ft. of blue clay with an occasional 6 or 8 ft. of
what is commonly called "hard pan" at intervals of
perhaps 20 ft., after which there was approximately
100 ft. of mostly a black clay with layers of
shaley rock;
from there to the end of the well, which was
stopped at 569 ft., it was practically all shale.

A jet drill was being used and the hole was filled with
a mixture of the drilling mud and water, which was continually
running out of the top of the hole in the course of drilling.
Toward the latter stages of drilling, when the drilling would
stop bubbles of oil were rising to the top through this mud, and
when the bubbles would burst on reaching the air a scum of oil
would appear on top of the mud. As there was no oil used on any
of the machinery on the interior of the hole, this oil certainly
came from the bottom of the well, through over 500 ft. of thick
mud.

Consequently, I have no doubt that the shale in which
the drill was working contained oil in fair quantities. Otherwise,
it would not have risen all this distance through the thick mud.
We were concerned with obtaining a supply of water for use at
the school, and striking oil was only incidental, but I am
satisfied that we were not far from oil in commercial quantities
when drilling was stopped.

I procured a sample of the mud referred to and am
forwarding it to you in the container which you sent me, but it
does not indicate much so far as I know. A similar sample was
sent to the University of Saskatoon, but I have received no
report thereon.

I feel certain that as drilling ceased some weeks ago
and the water and mud has receded in the well and at the same
time the oil would have been rising to the top of the water and
mud, there will be a considerable quantity of oil at the top of
the water and mud at the present time, but I have no equivalent
which can be used to procure a sample of this. If you are able
to suggest any way for me to do this, I shall be only too pleased
503 Calgary Public Bldg.,
Calgary, Alta.

December 31st,
1936.

Dear Sir:

I am very glad to receive your letter of the 24th inst., giving certain particulars of the well drilled at St. Philip's Residential School. I also thank you for sending me a sample of the mud and fluid taken from the well while drilling.

This sample does not show any evidence of oil. From your letter, I am not able to advise you how you can procure a sample or any fluid from the well at the present time as you do not tell me whether the hole is cased or not or the approximate depth to the top of the water and mud. If this is not too far down, it might be possible for you to lower a weighted tin receptacle of such a diameter that it will pass down the casing and attached to a light wire or small rope. In this way you might be able to procure a sample of the fluid, from which, by analysis, we may be able to determine whether it is crude petroleum or whether it is oil from some other source.

In the system of drilling adopted at this boring, there is always the possibility of the oil used to lubricate the rod joints showing up in the drilling mud, giving the impression that an actual showing of petroleum has occurred, although I note from your letter that no oil appears to have been used in the interior of the hole but you may have overlooked the possibility which I have mentioned.

In making the above, I am not trying to be unduly critical as nobody would be more pleased than myself to find that you had a true showing of crude oil at this shallow depth but I am simply pointing out this possibility with a view to eliminating any doubt as to the true source of the showing. I would be very glad to hear from you further in the matter and, of course, if you can get a sample of the fluid from the top of the mud, it would help considerably.

Wishing you the compliments of the season,

Yours very truly,

J. P. B. Ostrander, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

The reverend principal of the St. Philip's Indian Residential School considers that he is paying an unfair share of the cost of the electric current for his school.

As you are aware, the line was built from Kamsack to the Agency and on to St. Philip's. A meter was installed at the Agency for measurement of the current used in the Agency buildings and the Cote Day School, and the St. Philip's School is charged with the difference between this amount and the total reading at the commencement of the line, where it leaves the town of Kamsack. In this manner the total line loss is paid by the St. Philip's School, which, I am informed, is in the neighbourhood of $7.00 or $8.00 per month, as near as can be calculated.

The only way the line loss can be subdivided between the Agency and St. Philip's School is by the installation of a meter at the end of the line at the School and a division made of the difference between the two meter readings and that of the meter where the line leaves the town of Kamsack.

The cost of the meter will be approximately $115.00 and as I believe the complaint of Rev. Father Paradis, principal of St. Philip's School, is a legitimate one, I would recommend that the meter be installed for this purpose.

November 25 1937

Mr. J.B.F. Ostrander,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

Dear Sir,

Would you kindly inform the Department of our Estimates for the year 1938?

1) We need a house for our Farm Instructor:
This request was omitted in last year's list of estimates for the reason that, as I was told, the Department would consider no building request, but this is an urgent need and was listed since 1932. Our farmer is now living in a section of the 35 year old school building out of the Reserve, a regular ice-house in the winter. It is not wise to go to any more expense in trying to improve it, since the foundations are giving away. I believe a suitable house for a family could be built for $400.00.

2) We need electricity in our out-buildings:
It is deplorable that the Department, when giving us a Power Line two years ago, should have let the enterprise remain incomplete and not extend the wires to our out-buildings as well as to the school, we would now have the full benefit of the line. This will have to be done sometime, why not now? and let us do away with those miserable oil lanterns which carry little light but much danger to stables and hay-lofts, also harmful fumes to the ice-house. This matter would be settled once for all, with $265.00. This of course includes labor; it has to be done by an electrician.

3) We need a certain amount of paint and varnish:
It is a disgrace to let Government properties deteriorate for lack of paint; there is no paint left on the North side of our barn; there is no more varnish on our floors and corridors, the walls are simply repugnant in many rooms. The School management would take care of the labor if the Department provides the material, I should think $400.00 would improve much surface and save the dignity of the property.

4) We need some Battleship linoleum to cover the dust carrying cement floors of the kitchen (13x21 ft.) and the adjoining scullery (13x6½ ft.) $80.00

5) The $480.00 or 40 dollars a month (as per temporary arrangement with the Department) for the hauling of water to the School, must not be forgotten in the provision for the year 1938.

Hoping these will be considered favorably by you and the Department, I remain

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Alfred Paradis
O.M.I.

Dear Sir;-

I beg to submit application from St. Philips Residential School to have £2125 included in the 1938-39 estimates for building, repairs, etc.

1. Farming Instructor's House - The house now being used is unfit for habitation, it is just an old school houses discarded some years ago when the new building was erected.

This house is badly needed but I do not believe a house could be built for £900. It would require in the vicinity of £2000 to build any kind of a suitable house.

2. Electric lighting in outbuildings - This should be done to get away from the fire hazard if for no other purpose. His estimate should cover this.

3. Paint and varnish - The barn is badly in need of paint one side looks as though it had never had any and the siding is cracking and warping for need of it. There has been very little interior decoration done and it is badly needed in some rooms, particularly. The estimate of £400 should cover this.

4. Linoleum - This supplying of this would assist in keeping the upper floors clean as this sand is carried on the feet but aside from this I do not consider it very necessary.

5. Hauling water - This is a necessary expenditure as the whole water supply has to be hauled - £40 per month is paid for this work.

Dear Sir:

As you are no doubt aware, the water situation at St. Phillips Indian School on the Keeseekeoose Indian Reserve No. 66, is very unsatisfactory. A representative of this Department has recently inspected the situation and reports that the water supply is obtained from the creek, a distance of two or two and a half miles away, and is placed in the old well and then chlorinated. This arrangement is not particularly satisfactory and I am sure, is rather costly. I would like to urge that every consideration be given to further investigations for the purpose of obtaining an adequate and better protected water supply if at all possible.

I am informed too, that the absorption field used in connection with the septic tank gives considerable difficulty, which may be due to the fact that the subsoil is non-absorbent or that the field is too small. I suggest that consideration be given to carrying the effluent some 300 yards distant to the valley bank where probably a more suitable site for disposal can be found for direct discharge.

Yours truly,

J. G. Schaeffer, B.Sc.,
Sanitary Engineer.

The better plan would be a properly constructed disposal field near the septic tank in the school farm field, a distance of about 100 yards and the slope is away from the creek mentioned.

It would appear to me that any expenditure on a disposal field before a water supply is secured would be foolish and that before any action be taken an engineer should be sent in to make a complete survey.

If a period of wet years returned the probabilities are that the well at the school would again supply sufficient water at very little expense.

Dear Sir;-

I am in receipt of a report from the Provincial Health Department on the water situation at St. Philips Residential School.

As the Department is aware the conditions there are bad. The whole water supply for the school has to be hauled a distance of some 2½ miles at a cost of £40.00 per month, with the result that there is not the amount of water used for drinking purposes of the best quality.

It has been suggested that water be piped to the school from the river, a distance of about 2½ miles, the cost of doing this, together with the cost of pumps and upkeep in my opinion makes it prohibitive.

The solution might be found in locating water in the hills about 1½ miles east of the school from whence it could be brought by gravity. This land is owned by whites.

Criticism is also made of the disposal field as being inadequate and suggestion is made that the effluent be carried some 300 yards to a valley bank.

To do this would mean draining it into a spring creek, the water of which is used by the Indians for drinking purposes all summer and most of the winter.

Dear Sir:

The Reverend Principal of the St. Phillips Indian Residential School, in an effort to improve the water situation at that school, has dug a well at a distance of 1500 feet from the school, where there was an indication of water in a spring in the side of the ravine. It appears that the water supply at this point was much greater than was anticipated, and, while the well was dug to be used as a reservoir for the spring, to have a supply available for hauling in the tank, we find that the stream is quite powerful, and is running in and out of the reservoir at the rate of about 15,000 gallons to 19,000 gallons a day.

For some time past the water supply has been provided for this school by hiring an Indian to haul it at a cost of $40.00 a month and this is not very satisfactory for various reasons, chief of which is fire protection. I would like to have an engineer sent to this school to investigate the possibility of installing a pumping system from the reservoir to the school, if funds could be made available for the purpose, bearing in mind the fact that the Department now pays $450.00 a year to an Indian to haul the water, so at least that amount is available. I have no estimate to give as to the cost, other than that, if the engineer finds the installation of a pumping system is practical, and likely to prove a permanent solution of the water question at this school, it will be necessary to put in a pipe line, below the frost line, for a distance of 1500 feet.

I would be glad if you would recommend to the Department, that at least they have an engineer sent to this school to report as to the possibilities of this water supply, and make a recommendation and estimate as to the cost of a system such as I have suggested.

Yours truly,

J. P. B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Re: St. Philips Indian Residential School,
Pelly Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan.

In the year 1936 the water situation became so serious at the above mentioned residential school that it was considered necessary to dig a new well. Report re St. Phillips Residential School
Pelly Indian Reserve, Saskatchewan

The following report is the result of my inspection of the water supply conditions existing at the above school:

The well that formerly supplied water for the school had gone dry (from this well the suction line of the pump took its water) and it had become necessary to haul water in tanks from a well approximately 1500 feet away. This water was then placed in the dry well and then pumped into the pressure tank that feeds the school water system.

As there is no source of water other than the well 1500 feet away, the question was one of the feasibility of laying a pipe line (below the frost) from this well to the school.

As a result of my inspection, there is no doubt that this could be done and that the well, if it continues to flow as at present, would more than supply the demands of the school (the maximum demand being approximately 5000 gallons per day) occurring on wash days.

However there is the question of the possibility of the well going dry at some future date, in which case the pipe line would be of no use. This does not seem very likely to me as the well is located near the bed of a small stream and the well itself has a strong flow.

The water system at present is operated as follows:
Water is pumped from the well by means of a small daleo pump of capacity approx. 400 gallons per hour. This pump is driven by a single phase 60 cycle 1 H.P. electric motor. Water is pumped into a pressure tank in the basement (capacity of tank approximately 1500 gallons). The electric motor is so controlled as to shut down automatically when the pressure in the tank becomes sixty pounds per square inch and to cut in again when the pressure lowers to forty pounds per square inch. When the pressure drops to forty pounds per square inch in the tank there is not sufficient pressure in the top floor of the school to satisfactorily flush the toilets, etc., to say nothing of its being useless for fire protection. To my mind the pressure in the pressure tank in the basement should range from a minimum of sixty pounds per square inch to a maximum of ninety pounds per square inch, which should provide ample pressure without endangering the tank or other plumbing (the tank being tested to one hundred and fifty pounds per square inch).

The flow of the only available well 1500 feet from the school is approximately 400 gallons per hour. The well itself is approximately 9 feet in diameter, with 11.8 feet of water in the well. The well was tested, according to Mr. Stranzer, the Indian Agent, by pumping it out to within 2 feet of the bottom by means of two sludge pumps and the well filled itself (8.8 feet) in a period of six hours. This works out to be approximately 400 gallons per hour. The storage in a well of this size is approximately 5400 gallons aside from the flow of water entering the well.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, No. 117-3-5, enclosing letter of complaint from an Indian Andrew Quewezance regarding the hauling of the water for the St. Philip's Indian Residential School.

Some time ago, a spring was improved in the ravine near the house occupied by this man, with a view to obtaining an adequate supply of water for the St. Philip's School. Curbing was installed and the spring supplies a good quantity and quality of water for the school. Recently, an engineer was sent by the Department to report on this supply and the matter of piping and pumping the supply to the school is under consideration.

About the time that this spring was developed, the Indian, John Musqua, who has been hauling water to the school for some time, informed me that he was considering quitting his job, as the work was too hard on his horses. His son-in-law is a son of Andrew Quewezance, the complainant, and had spoken for the job, if John Musqua was quitting. Subsequently, after the spring was developed, the hauling of the water was not so difficult, and John Musqua decided to continue until the pumping to the school was completed, and I told him he could do so, as his work has been quite satisfactory, considering the amount he was receiving.

Although the water is hauled from a point near Andrew Quewezance's dwelling on the Keeseekoose Reserve, I do not think he has any more claim against it than has John Musqua, and he has not horses as suitable for the work.

Regarding the complaint that I said I was going to see this man and did not. Probably this is partly true, as I said I would advise him, if John Musqua did not continue with the hauling, and would give him the first chance. But, as John Musqua continued, there was nothing further to see him about. He has more time to come and see me than I have to go and see him, at least at the present time.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Yours truly,

J. P. B. Ostander,
Indian Agent.
St. Philip's is one of the small schools in the Department and its upkeep is becoming increasingly difficult because there is not the proper relation between overhead expenses and ordinary revenue. A small increase in pupilage would, therefore, be very welcome and would enable the Principal to carry on with less difficulty.

Hoping that you will give this matter your immediate attention, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Mr. Philip Phelan:
Chief Welfare and Training
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the St. Philip's Residential School dated the 9th instant in which he draws my attention to the following:

1. Nothing has been done so far to pipe the water to the school from the spring which was discovered last June, a distance of about 1500 feet. The school water supply is still being taken care of by hauling water from this spring. The quantity is necessarily limited causing hardship to the staff and making the school a greater fire hazard than it should be. The Department is, at present, spending $40.00 a month for the hauling of water. This amount represents $480 a year, a sum equal to the annual interest on $12,000. Surely the Department should make an effort to install a pipe line immediately so as to save the interest on the difference between the amount required for the installation of this pipe line and the amount being spent annually for hauling water.

2. Father Paradis, the Principal, forwarded to the Department a short time ago labour vouchers to the amount of $81.00 representing wages for deepening the spring which is now supplying the school with water. He informs me that these wages have not yet been paid.

3. You agreed last year to stand the expense of hauling water for the school's skating rink. Labour vouchers were forwarded to you but you have not yet reimbursed the school.

4. It was verbally understood that the pupilage of the school would be increased from 70 to 75. Up to the present time you are paying for only 70 pupils. The Principal would be very much obliged if, beginning with October, you would increase the pupilage to 75.
Ottawa,
September 21, 1938.

Attention: Mr. R.A. Hoey.

Dear Sir:

You are no doubt aware that a year ago last May, a well supplying about twelve thousand gallons of water per day, was discovered close to the St. Phillip's Indian Residential School. This well is about fifteen hundred feet distant.

Since this discovery, the school has taken its whole water supply from this well. The Department has allowed $40. per month for hauling it by team. This money is paid monthly to an Indian from the Reserve. The quantity hauled per day is never quite sufficient for the needs of the school. During the very wet weather and also during the winter months, when there is heavy snow on the ground, only a small quantity can be hauled. This results in a great deal of inconvenience from a sanitary point of view, as sufficient flushing cannot be done. The fire hazard for the school is also much greater, because the water tanks are never filled to capacity.

Under the circumstances, we hope that the Department will supply the necessary funds to pipe the water from this new well to the school. This will ensure not only a permanent supply, but also a sufficient quantity of water for all purposes.

It would be most unfortunate if a fire originated in the school, and it was shown upon investigation, that a sufficient quantity of water was not on hand to use the fire extinguishing apparatus, provided by the Department for the safety of the children and staff of this school.
Ottawa, October 25, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, regarding the water supply at the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

When preparing our appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41, consideration will be given to providing funds to carry out one of the recommendations of the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,

Attention Mr. Harry Hoey,

You were kind enough last year to include in
the 1939-1940 estimates a sum sufficient for the construction
of a Manual Training Room and a small Assembly Hall for the
St Philips Indian Residential School.

Sometime last Spring Rev. Father Lamontagne,
Provincial of the Manitoba Oblate Province under whose
general jurisdiction comes St Philips, asked that the addition
to the St Philips be not proceeded with this year and that
the sum voted for that purpose be used for the construction
of a new unit to the Kenora School which lost its staff
quarters by fire. You agreed to this change.

As St. Philips is just as much in need of a
Manual Training Room and a small Assembly Hall as it was
a year ago I would ask that the amount of $5,000.00 which
was voted for that purpose in the 1939-1940 estimates be
included in the estimates of the coming year.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: St. Philips Residential School Water System

You are no doubt aware that the above school has been without a permanent water system for the last seven or eight years. The original well dug at the time of the construction of the school went dry during the dry spell and subsequent attempts at digging new wells have all proven unsuccessful.

Two years ago, in the month of May, a spring of considerable size was discovered at a distance of about 1500 feet from the school. Acting on the advice of the Agent this spring was uncovered and a casing 8 feet in diameter and 9 feet deep was installed where the flow of water seemed to be the largest.

It took 9 hours with two sludge pumps to empty this casing. It was calculated that the flow was about 480 gallons per hour.

In August, 1938, your Mr. Dempster was asked to make a report on this well and on the feasibility of installing a pipe line from the well to the school, a distance, as stated above, of 1500 feet. Mr. Dempster was also asked to submit an alternate proposal. His report dated August 1 goes into all the details of, first, the construction of a pipe line, and, secondly, into a method of using the water without the pipe line. It was proposal No. 2 which was accepted by the Department, the reasons for this being twofold; first, the funds available at the time were not large enough to install a pipe line, and, secondly, it was deemed advisable to test the flow of water from the well before spending any large amount on piping the water to the school. In the meantime
the sum of $1,500.00 which might be utilized to undertake this work, and I am today in receipt of a letter from the General Superintendent of Catholic Indian Missions, in which he states that the Oblate Order would be prepared to undertake the work and complete it this fall, on the understanding that provision for the additional amount would be made in the estimates of next year. They have made the suggestion that they would be prepared to complete the work if we continued to allow them the $40.00 per month that has been allowed them in recent years for the hauling of water. This arrangement however in my judgment would be in no sense satisfactory.

It is regrettable that we have been prevented until now from submitting this matter to you for consideration owing to our inability to discuss the project with a representative of the Catholic Church. In view of the lateness of the season, therefore, I would recommend, subject to the approval of the Minister, that the Church Authorities be authorized to proceed with this work, at a cost not to exceed $2,985.00. This work in the main consists of excavation of soil to a depth of 8 ft. and installation of 1800 lineal feet of 2-inch pipeline. It is just possible that we may be able to pay an amount in excess of $1,500 from this year's appropriation, but, should it be found impossible to do so, I recommend that the amount exceeding the appropriation of $1,500.00 now available be included in the 1941-42 estimates.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that I had a long distance telephone call this morning from Father Paradis of the St. Philips Indian Boarding School, Kamsack.

This call was in connection with the water supply at the school. I shall refer you to your letter No. 117-3-5 of September 12th, 1936. You say in this letter that it has been decided to accept Scheme No. 2 which was to carry the water from the Spring to the school, for which, I believe, the Department has been paying an Indian $40.00 a month to haul water from the Spring to the school. Evidently Father Paradis has been in communication with the Department regarding this matter and from the information I have, the Catholic Church are advancing the money for the purpose of carrying out Scheme No. 1. I do not know under what terms this is to be carried out but evidently you have the information there. Father Paradis now informs me that he received authority from his Church this morning to go ahead with the work, as the money is available.

To do this he will have to have an engineer. Evidently our Department had Mr. Dempster, of the Survey & Engineering Branch, visit the school some two years ago and are familiar with what has transpired. As the season is getting late and the freeze-up is fast approaching, I would ask you to take immediate steps to have an engineer visit St. Philips School to lay out the work in question. Dear Sir:

re: St. Philips' School Water System

In your letter of September the 23rd last, you authorized the Church authorities, or the Reverend Oblate Fathers to proceed with the installation of a pipe line from the school to the well which was discovered in May 1938. This well is about 1500 feet distant from the school.

Acting upon this authority, the Rev. Oblate Fathers began work on this project September 28th and it was completed on November 9th last. The sum of $2,965 was authorized for this purpose, $1500 of which was to be paid during the current fiscal year and the balance, $1465, out of the 1941-42 estimates. It was understood that if the completed job amounted to more than the above sum, the balance would be supplied by the Oblate Fathers and no claim would be made on the Department for this over-expenditure.

At the time that the Oblate Fathers made this promise it was thought that the cost of the installation of the electric power line from the school to the well, according to the estimate of your engineer, Mr. Dempster, would be only $50.00; that is the amount which appears in his report as the estimated cost for this work. Unfortunately we were not able to do the work for this project on anything like it. For instance, the wire alone cost $257.30. In all $441.13 of electrical supplies were needed for this part of the work. Owing to this and a few other unforeseen expenses the total amount spent on this project is $3288.69. Invoices and labour vouchers for the above amount are hereby submitted for your approval.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo our records indicate that Mr. Mitchell's account was received and passed for payment. However, in checking with the Treasury Branch this morning I find that they have no record of having received the account, although two copies of it were sent to them. This means we only have on file the triplicate copy and it will, therefore, be necessary to secure another account from Mr. Mitchell. I am extremely sorry that this has occurred but mistakes will happen.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water Supply, St. Philip's Indian Residential School

In further reference to your memorandum of the last ultimo regarding the difficulty experienced in maintaining a suitable pressure in the system, Mr. Wallace has reported that he found the pressure tank practically full of water with the pump having to create the required pressure against a very small volume of air. He also found that the snifter valve on the pump was not operating properly.

After discussing the matter with the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company in Winnipeg he recommended as follows:

"(1) The pressure tank must be completely drained of water and fresh volume of air allowed to enter before it is refilled.

"(2) The snifter valve on the pump must have the Adjuster Cap replaced - this was missing at the time of my inspection.

"Regarding the draining of the pressure tank, there is a difficulty due to the elevation of part of the piping, and the school authorities claim that they cannot drain the tank completely. However, this may be done by allowing the water to drain back through the force main and escaping through the check valve at the pump house. The flap in the check valve should be removed for this purpose. Also, during this operation it must be ascertained that air has free access to the pressure tank, either through some regular inlet to the tank, or if necessary, through the water gauge glass connections. When the tank has been completely drained and the pressure tank again made airtight, it is believed that on refilling the tank about two-thirds full that the necessary 60-80 lbs. will be maintained for longer periods in the system.

It is suggested that Mr. Wallace's recommendations be carried out and the results noted carefully before any action is taken on the proposal to install an air compressor unit.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Dear Father,

The Fairbanks Morse Co. keep on sending to me the account covering the cost of the motor you purchased for our School pump. It seems that the Department is not yet prepared to pay this account, I do not understand why? It is to be understood that the School management cannot and will not take care of this expense. I thought a report from the engineer Mr. Wallace would have brought some result as I have explained the case to him. I shall give you those reasons again:

Referring to Mr. Hoey's letter to you (Sept. 20 1941) the original motor purchased in 1938 has not been rendered useless; it has actually been repaired and is to be used as a stand-by. It must be noted that this same motor has been going to Winnipeg twice for repairs; In Feb. 1941 a careless move of one of my employees overloaded the motor and caused it to burn, the rewiring cost was assumed by the School ($ 44.47). Last August went out of order again through defective bearings. Mr. Hill the Kamsack electrician examined the motor and advised to send it in to Winnipeg as it could not be repaired locally. He also advised to order an extra motor for the pump, as it takes ten days or two weeks before the motor returns from repair.

Do you understand Father Flourde the inconvenience of having our pump stopped? and haul water for two weeks constantly with teams for the house and stock? It was done last winter and I proposed not to have to do it again. Also consider the danger of stalling the pump too long in the cold winter as the water may freeze in the conduits.

Father Flourde I am not asking for a refund for the first repair expenses ($ 44.47) but for the last, that is I am enclosing Mr. Hill's account which I have not paid. Mr. Hill himself took care of the last repairing with the Fairbanks Morse Co.

Also find enclosed duly signed motor account.

Yours very truly,

Alp Paradis O.M.I  
Principal
