Dear Father,

The St. Philips Indian Res. School has no motor truck, it has only one automobile for the use of the School, the farmland and the missions. The greater part of our operations are on the Indian Reserves where there are no filling stations nor do we come anywhere close to such stations on the way. One of these missions is 20 miles away. We have no filling station in St. Philips, the closest is in Kamsack, a distance of 11 miles.

Considering the distance the school is from all filling stations, I would ask you to use your influence through the Department or directly to the Oil Controller, to authorize the delivery of a supply of gasoline to the School, with the use of ration coupons. The School has an underground tank put up for that purpose and always had its gas delivered previous to the rationing. This gas tank is for private use only and has an inside pump.

We cannot properly discharge our essential duties without sufficient gas handy. Since we started taking our gas from the filling stations in Kamsack we have had to make a special trip just to fill up. I am trying to save as much gas as possible with a Bl Coupon Book while I am entitled to more, so I do not intend to burn one whole gallon of gas every time my tank runs low, just for the sole purpose of filling up.

Sincerely yours,

Alp. Paradis, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Enclosed please find copy of a letter which I have just received from the Principal of St. Philips Indian Residential School. This letter speaks for itself.

My first idea was to write directly to the Oil Controller but as this gentleman is not likely to know very much about the mode of administration of our Indian schools it seems to me that Father Paradis has a better chance of obtaining his request in the matter of gasoline supplies if the matter is brought to the Controller's attention by the Indian Affairs Department.

When our school principals buy gasoline directly from the oil companies they get it at a wholesale price, and do not pay the Sales Tax. That is a considerable economy and one which our schools, under the present difficult conditions obtaining in the country cannot be lightly overlooked.

Hoping that you will give this matter your kind consideration, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Enc.
Ottawa, June 24th, 1942.

Dear Father Plourde:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing a letter from the Principal of the St. Philips Residential School with reference to securing permission to use the gas tank at the school and thus avoid buying from local dealers.

A similar request was recently received from the Principal of the St. Cyprian C. of E. Residential School and, at that time, we communicated with the Oil Controller. In a letter dated May 9th, he replied as follows:

"We would advise you that the Oil Controller's Orders prohibit the servicing of passenger cars at any point other than a service station. We cannot permit the purchase of gasoline for use in private cars by drum or otherwise. We would suggest that if the car used by the principal of your school could be licensed as a commercial vehicle he would be relieved of the obligation to purchase his supplies at a service station."

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Estimates of some of the repairs and improvements for St. Philips Residential School which are required in the very near future as follows:

1. Extra storage space required for the expected heavy crop this fall, a new granary on skids 19x10x8 will be required for that purpose ........................................ $79.26

2. The present granary has a bare cement floor, which causes damage to the grain through moisture, material for a wooden floor will cost .................................. $16.05

3. Plank flooring in barn to be renewed, this will require 1100 feet of lumber ........................................ $64.47

4. The earth retaining wall at the pump house is of stone and mortar, and is falling apart, it should be replaced by a permanent cement wall, for this job, cement will cost $30.00, lumber 25.00, labour 40.00 ........ $95.00

5. An increase in livestock last year made a new barn necessary, this was built of logs with a temporary roof of straw, a proper shingle roof will cost $89.26.

6. Estimates for other requirements will be forwarded as soon as possible.

It is proposed to purchase the lumber and cement from the Monarch Lumber Co, at Kamsack, full details of prices and quantities are attached.

Dear Sir;

Referring to your letter of June 19th in regard to funds available for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at St. Philips Residential school, I am enclosing herewith estimates of some of the repairs and improvements which the Principal would like to have approved as soon as possible so that the work could be done before harvest.

The boiler that supplies the steam heat requires new grates, there is also some repairs to the plastering of the walls in the school to be done.

It is very difficult to get competent workmen to do this work at the present time, however I hope to be able to forward an estimate of the cost of repairs to the boiler and the plastering in the near future.

You will note that in the estimate that the only labour included is in connection with the erection of a retaining wall in the pump house. The other work will be done by the staff at the school.

Dear Sir:

Re Voucher #332.

The attached voucher for $86.40 covers the varnishing of the floors at St. Philips Indian School and the wood work in the chapel. The former was authorized by you in letter 117-3-5 of August 15th.

At the time the estimate was submitted for approval no consideration was given to the needs of the chapel. It was, however, decided upon subsequently, and since the outlay was very nominal, I approved of the work. The wood work in the chapel was in bad need of resurfacing, and I trust you will concur in my decision.

Yours truly,

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
Kamsack, Sask.,
November 3, 1942.

Dear Sir:-

Re St. Philips School.

I have been approached by Fr. Tetreaux, with a request to arrange for lumber to build a drying room. Under present arrangement all clothes that are washed must be lugged up to the top storey of the school where it is spread out and dried. This involves hard labour and sometimes accidents to those who do the work. It is believed that the sisters in charge of this last winter suffered illness directly in consequence of this arrangement.

The new drying room is to be built on the present pump house which is partly below the earth's surface and partly above, and situated back of the school, adjoining it. Washing is also done in this room. The new super structure will not affect the appearance of the premises, but will be much more convenient than having to cart clothes through the school and two storeys up. The principal adds that they will provide their own labour.

I am attaching herewith the estimate of material required and cost of same.

Kindly advise if the Department approves of this plan, and if so, an immediate reply would be very much appreciated, so that work could be commenced before cold weather sets in.

Yours truly,

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed find the bill for electricity used at our school last month.

I send this bill to the Department because I refuse to pay it. I refuse to pay it, because I was told to do so by my Superior. He has ordered me this because in the contract past between the Department and the Town of Kamsack it is said, and I quote: "the Department shall pay to the Municipality, seven cents per K.W.H." etc. This contract was signed by a representative of the Department, Mr. W. McGill, and not by a representative of the school. Furthermore, the Belly Agency is on the same contract as we, and the Department pays their light bills every month, and have done so always as far as I know.

Now you may say that it is our duty to pay our own light expenses. I say; not according to the contract. And if you find hard to pay such a bill every month... what about us, with so little money. Then something should be done about the whole question.

First of all I say that there is no sense whatever to pay 7 cents straight to the Town of Kamsack for the electricity. Those who made that contract were certainly sure not to pay the bills. We have here some electric motors. One 7 horse power, two of 3 horse power, and others of ½ horse power. And they are all on the same rate, as for the lights, there is no sense in that. There should be a special rate for our motors. And we should follow the rate table of the Town of Kamsack which I enclosed.

I have spoken to an official to lower our rate according to this table. The answer was: "We will not do so unless this contract is made void and another one made. They are in their rights, and also are making and have been making big money on us since 1939. So do you not think that something should be done about it. It seems to me that a man should be appointed."

I wish to inform you I have received two or three letters from the Reverend P.E. Tetrault, O.M.I., Principal of the St. Philips Indian Residential School, inviting me to go over to visit the school.

Today I am in receipt of another letter from him informing me he has made many repairs to the school to improve it during the past year and he is now wondering whether the Department will refund this money for the amount he expended on these improvements.

Father Tetrault also states some laundry equipment is badly needed, which is absolutely essential, and I know he is right because between the children and staff there is somewhere in the neighborhood of ninety people there. He states a small high pressure boiler, a drying tumbler, and a water softener are required for the school. The water softener is needed because the water is so hard they have to melt snow during the Winter time with which to wash and the clothes have to be dried during the Winter time in the halls of the school. He further states one of the sisters died some years ago and one nearly lost her life recently due to what he believes is over-exertion, and you can readily understand the Sisters have to work hard carrying baskets full of wet clothes all over the school during the Winter time so that they can be hung up to dry. Also, they have to use hard water for the boiler and as a result of this the flues are gradually corroding, therefore it will not be long before the boiler will have to be re-flued.

I know the reason the Reverend Principal is so anxious for me to visit the school is so that he can talk these different matters over with me and I have informed him I will be there some time in June, so when I submit my report to Ottawa after my visit you will know what to expect.

The second question is that of the natural gas found on the property of the school. Last Sunday search was made by a man employed by the Companies drilling for gas near Kamsack. This man also works for different Companies in Alberta to find gas or oil. With his instrument he immediately found a large field of natural gas extending west, south-west and south of the school. The gas would be in great abundance according to him. The depth would be about 800 feet deep at the most and most probably less said he. The cost of drilling might be $4.00 a foot. Next would come the piping to the school. This would mean about 1/4 of mile long or more of pipe. Due to the depth of the gas it would give better service than in Kamsack, more pressure. According to Mr. Mills of Kamsack a three inch pipe would be sufficient for our needs. He will give me an estimate of the piping cost. If you desire to have it I shall send it to you.

What a blessing this would be for our institution. The fuel wood is practically all gone from the Reserve. This winter I wanted 300 cords of wood. I may have now on hand about 150. So I am short of fuel right now for next winter. In a few years we will have to buy coal.

If the Department could pay the initial cost, some arrangement could be made to refund a part of the cost, little by little.

If I have presented such facts it is that you may consider them and the possibility of their execution.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 117-3-5 of the 7th instant regarding my recent inspection of the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

Evidently the information you received from Mr. Bryant in connection with building the drying room was the thing that lead you astray because the present drying room without a tumbler for drying the clothes is more or less useless. This room is for the purpose of housing the dryer, etc. and if you will look at the plan of the school you will see that the school is a three-storey building and the front of the school and a wing one-storey above the ground run back from the centre of the building. The drying room is built in the corner where the one-storey building joins the three-storey building. However, I am writing to Agent Bryant and asking him to send you a sketch showing where this room was built on to the school.

Naturally as I have said above, the room in question is more or less useless without a tumbler. I have discussed this with the Principal of the School and the Sister Superior, and after thinking the matter over carefully I believe the most important items for the school at the present time are the drying tumbler and the steam boiler. We can let the water softener wait for another year if necessary.

Referring to the boiler and my recent report I only mentioned the difference between the vertical boiler and the horizontal boiler because the boiler inspector is of the opinion that a horizontal boiler would be much better than a vertical one. However, that is something for experts to attend to. I know how necessary this equipment is to the school and I think if you and I were in charge of the school we would see that it is practically impossible to get along without the proper equipment when a school is housing up to 100 people.

In conclusion I might say I am only trying to stress the importance of the situation and I would think that it would be well for our Branch to go into the matter with the Church Authorities. If we have not enough money to spend on the school this year, instead of leaving the matter in abeyance for another year surely the Church authorities might put up some money to instal

the equipment that is necessary....
the equipment that is necessary this year. Then another year our Brethren could refund the money to the church. The Catholic Church has many Brothers experienced in engineering, electricity, etc., and I would suggest that they send one or these Brothers to the school. I know he would see the necessity of furnishing the equipment mentioned above for the school this year.

In my report I simply tried to show how important it is to have something carried out this year and at the same time whatever is done there should only be carried out on the recommendation of a thoroughly experimented man, that is one who will recommend something to give perfect satisfaction. The more I think over the matter the more convinced I am something should be done for these people to relieve them of their difficulties.

I hope I have made myself clear.

General Superintendent of Indian Agencies,

J. Christenson,

Specifications for a water softener for St. Philip's Indian Residential School, Kansas, Saskatchewan.

The water softener shall be capable of reducing to zero hardness by the Zeolite (natural or synthetic) process, water which on analysis has been found to contain the following:

- Compensated hardness = 36 grains per U.S. gallon
- Actual hardness = 30 "
- Temporary hardness = 22.9 "
- Permanent hardness = 7.1 "
- Chlorides = 2.4 "
- Iron = 0 "
- Alkalinity = 22.9 parts per million
- Acidity = 24.0 grains per U.S. gallon
- Sulphates = 6.8 "
- Parts of hydrogen = 7.1 "

The consumption of water to be treated at the school is stated to be approximately 4000 gallons per day.

The unit shall have a grain gallon capacity of not less than 132,000, and a flow rate of 50 Imperial gallons per minute.

The brine tank shall have a storage capacity of not less than 400 lbs. of salt.

The tanks shall be made of heavy gauge rust-resisting iron, and shall be hot dip galvanized inside and outside.

The water softener shall be similar or equal to the Duro S.C. Series Water Softener, Model 24-42.

Tenderers shall supply literature fully descriptive of the equipment offered.

Note: If the Department does not wish to call for tenders on the unit installed, full instructions for installation and operation should be supplied by the successful tenderer.
September 15th, 1943

Re: St. Philip's Indian Residential School,
Water Supply

In reference to your notation on Dr. McGill's memorandum to you of August 26th last, regarding specifications for a water softener, we have obtained the following information from Mr. Gow:

1. The total hardness of the water is 36 grains per Imperial gallon.

2. He has no definite knowledge of the daily consumption at the school and states that it may easily exceed 4000 gallons per day, owing to waste in leaky or open taps and lawn watering.

In this connection, Mr. Gow states that the Indian Affairs Branch should be interested primarily in softening the water to prevent the rapid deterioration and replacement of metal piping, heating boilers, hot water boilers, high pressure steam boilers and certain laundry equipment, and secondarily - although this would be of primary importance to the school authorities - in having softened water for washing and laundry purposes. The average daily consumption for these purposes should not exceed 1000 Imperial gallons with a peak of 2500 gallons on wash days. Limiting the use of softened water to these purposes would necessitate alterations in the piping, and the cost of this could only be determined after an inspection. The difference in the use of salt between a daily softening of 4000 and 1000 Imperial gallons would be about 37 lbs., or a saving of $0.75 per day. This would justify a considerable expenditure on alterations to the piping. He further suggests that a twin unit should be installed so that no untreated water would be used in the equipment mentioned above, although he realizes that it may be more difficult to secure a permit for a double unit than for a single unit.

In view of the foregoing, and the fact that the school has been using this untreated water for many years, it would seem reasonable to delay the installation of this equipment until after the war when material will be more easily obtained, or at least until arrangements have been made to alter the piping to reduce the softened water requirements. However, if the Indian Affairs Branch wishes to proceed at once with the purchase of a unit to treat 4000 gallons per day, a specification is attached which may be used by the Purchasing Agent to call for tenders. As the Dure equipment mentioned by Messrs. Crane Limited, is manufactured by Messrs. Pumps and Softeners, Limited, London, Ont., it is suggested that they be asked to quote.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Dr. McGill

Re: St. Philip's Indian Residential School,
Water Supply.

In reply to your memorandum of August 26th last relative to the above, I may say that the Duro S.C. 24-42 water softener on which Crane Limited have quoted is considered to be of a type suitable for the requirements of St. Philip's School.

Enclosed for your information and consideration is a copy of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, dated September 15th, which is self-explanatory, together with a specification for a unit to treat 4,000 gallons of water per day for use if it is decided to call for tenders for such unit immediately.

The difference between the cost of the unit Duro S.C. 24-42, as quoted on by Crane Limited and of the equipment purchased for Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba, is due to the former having a much greater mineral capacity, 11 cubic feet of mineral while the latter (2 softeners) has a mineral capacity of only 5½ cubic feet. Dear Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of September the 28th, and also the copy of the letter of Mr. T.S. Mills Chief Engineer.

In the second paragraph of this letter it is stated: "That the daily consumption of water may easily exceed 4000 gallons per day, owing to waste in leaky or open taps and lawn watering."

I am not of this opinion. Before making any such statement a thorough investigation should be made by one of your Engineer to find out how much water is used by our school. For on this statement was built the argument for refusing this water softener. Such an argument does not stand for I am positive that we do not use so much water. For example: I have not watered the lawn once this summer, and very little water will ever be used for that purpose.

It is stated again in that information of Mr. Gow that: "Alterations in the piping" would be necessary. It seems to me that very little alteration would be needed. For the water softeners should be connected only on the hot water system. For the hot water is used for cooking and laundry, and it is the hot water that deteriorates the metal and piping. In making the connection on the hot water system only it has the advantage of reducing the cost of operation of regeneration. Also the advantage that smaller water softener can do the work, for only about one third of the water used is thus softened.

"That a twin unit should be installed", is correct, for that no untreated water would be used.

As for the permit... Crane Ltd. from Winnipeg had already obtained one from the Metal Control Board of Ottawa. So it would really be easy enough to your Department to obtain the necessary permits, if only you wanted to.

It is also said that due to "the fact that the school has been using this untreated water for many years, it would seem reasonable to delay the installation of this equipment until after the war..." etc...

For these reasons your Department has decided not to purchase a water softener at the present time.

I wish and I hope that the members of your Department will change their minds on this. One must be in our position to know and feel the absolute necessity of such a machine. And Mr. Christianson has emphasize its absolute necessity. Think for a moment of the long months of our long winter during which we will be without soft water... rain water... and that we will be obliged to melt snow to obtain our soft water. Think of the work, and unnecessary work, impose on our boys. My intention is to do away with these unnecessary gobs. The parents of our boys complain that their boys do unnecessary work, and in so doing do not learn the more essential things they should know, as wood work etc. Another go! I want to do away with is the splitting of the wood for the kitchen stove. I want to put up a machine to do that work, that our boys do not have to learn, so that during the time they use at the work we may show them something more useful, and more in line with the desires.

Replying to your letter of October 16th which was received this morning, in connection with the type of boiler to be installed in St. Philips Residential school, I regret to advise that up to the present time no representative of the surveys and Engineering Branch has made an inspection of the school.

The laundry equipment now in use in the school consists of a washing machine manufactured by the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co., No. 1213 - M.7181. This is a barrel shaped machine about four feet long and three feet in diameter. There is also an extractor put out by the same company. The two machines are run by a five horse power electric motor. They also have two large hot water boilers with a wood fire box under each. The water for the washing machine is heated in these first thing in the morning and then put in barrels as the water has to be changed after each tub goes through. The big water boilers are then filled up again and heated, as all clothes are boiled in these before going into the washer. The usual weekly wash consists of at least ten of these boilers full. These are like two large feed cookers that are used on the farm for cooking pig feed, and are about four feet in diameter and two feet deep. Washing was under way when I visited the school today and it was evident that the job was being done under difficulties, due to lack of proper equipment.

Memorandum:

In reference to your notation on Dr. McGill's memorandum of the 8th instant, regarding the proposed water softener for this school, Mr. Gow states that Mr. Wallace will be available to examine the water supply system and report as to what alterations are necessary and the materials that will be required. He is not prepared to accept the Principal's statement that it is absolutely impossible to wash clothes with the water supplied, as prairie homes in rural and urban districts are carrying on with water much harder than that in use at the school.

Specifications for a water softener for St. Philips Indian Residential School, Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

The water softener shall be capable of reducing to zero hardness by the Zeolite (natural or synthetic) process, water which on analysis has been found to contain the following:

- Compensated hardness - 36 grains per U.S. gallon
- Actual hardness - 30 "
- Temporary hardness - 22.9 "
- Permanent hardness - 7.1 "
- Chlorides - 2.4 "
- Iron - 0
- Alkalinity - 22.9 parts per million
- Acidity - 24.0 grains per U.S. gallon
- Sulphates - 6.8 "
- Parts of hydrogen - 7.1 "

The consumption of water to be treated at the school is stated to be approximately 1000 gallons per day with an occasional peak of 2500 gallons per day.

The unit shall have a grain gallon capacity of not less than 94,000, and a flow rate of 20 Imperial gallons per minute.

The brine tank shall have a storage capacity of not less than 400 lbs. of salt.

The tanks shall be made of heavy gauge rust-resisting iron, and shall be hot dip galvanized inside and outside.

The water softener shall be similar or equal to the Duro S.C. Series Water Softener, Model 24-30.

Tenderers shall supply literature fully descriptive of the equipment offered.

Memorandum:

Re: Water Supply and Laundry Equipment, St. Philip's Indian Residential School, Pelly Agency, Saskatchewan.

Further to our memorandum of the 30th ultimo in connection with the above, you are advised that in reply to our request for additional information regarding the use of certain component units of the complete installation, Mr. Gow has now supplied us with data, which with information obtained by this office from Pumps and Softeners Limited of London, Ontario may be summarized for the use of the Departmental Purchasing Agent as follows:

(a) Water Softener: The type of water softener in use at the Little Residential School, and which Mr. Gow considered should serve satisfactorily in the present instance, is apparently no longer available. In reply to an enquiry from this Service, Pumps and Softeners Ltd. have recommended the use of their unit No. 24-32 S.C. with a grain capacity of 96,000 which can treat 135 U.S. gallons between regenerations, having a flow rate of 25.1 U.S. gallons per minute, all based on water of 36 grain hardness. This unit would cost $655.75 net, f.o.b. Winnipeg tax paid. Delivery would be subject to the issuance of a permit by the Steel Controller for the manufacture of the tank after placing the order. Mr. Gow has confirmed the manufacturer's opinion that this type of softener would meet the requirements of the school.

(b) Drying Tumbler: Laundry type, with steam heated coils similar to that manufactured by the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. Ltd., with cylinder 36" in diameter 30" long, complete with electric motor.

(c) High Pressure Steam Boiler: Vertical type with full length tubes, capacity 10 H.P., to operate at 100 lbs. working pressure, complete with fittings and accessories as follows:
1. Steel hood with smoke stack connection; 2. Cast iron boiler base and ashpit door; 3. Cast iron circular grate; 4. Cast iron grate rest; 5. Steam gauge; 6. Safety valve; 7. It may require certain alterations to the smoke breaching from the low pressure heating boiler to make satisfactory connection with the chimney, and can only be worked out on the job.

Dear Sir,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter in which you state that you have written again to Mr. Wallace for further information.

He told us here that he knew nothing about boilers, for this was not his line. In one of your previous letters you stated that the boiler presented by us was too expensive. Mr. Wallace told us that lately a vertical boiler had been installed in a school. If the department finds that the boiler proposed by our school is too expensive—let the department give us then—a Vertical instead of the horizontal as propose by our school we will accept it, for we need it badly. We also need badly the trying troubles with all the damp temperature on croaking days we had again cases of pneumonia, and the Rev. Sister Superior sick with Pleurisy and still in bed.

And now that we have exhausted our soft water we have to melt snow and ice. So to say that we are in need of the water softener is to say very little. This one should be send, if possible—immediately. Mr. Wallace was telling me that "he could not even share with our water."

This boiler should be of 15 horse power.

Sincerely Yours,

My dear friend,

During the course of our conversation this morning, I mentioned the necessity in which I find myself of providing larger accommodation for one of the Indian Residential Schools of which I am in charge as Provincial of the Oblate Fathers for Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

This school is known as St. Philips Indian Residential School, and was built in the fiscal year 1927-28. At that time no adequate provision was made in the building for a laundry. As a result, primitive methods had to be used in handling the washing and during the winter months it was necessary to carry all the wet wash up two and three flights of stairs where the clothes were hung in halls and dormitories until they were dry. Of course, in the summer the clothes were hung outside.

Conditions just mentioned had become so aggravated that in the summer of 1943 the Department was requested to supply some modern laundry equipment and also a small quantity of material to enlarge the boiler room. There is an authorized pupilage of 70 and for some time past we have had this number in attendance. When the new laundry machinery arrived it was found that to provide the necessary space for it would still further cramp the quarters required for the pupils and the staff.

The management of the school consulted me and for the past few weeks very careful consideration has been given to what could be done to remedy the situation in such a manner that proper working of the school could be facilitated.

We feel that the only manner in which to provide the necessary additional accommodation is by the erection of a wing approximately 60 feet long by 28 feet wide. It has been estimated that the materials for this addition would cost not more than $6000. Dr. Dorey, in a letter dated April 20, 1944, states:

"The financial situation at Alberni is a most serious one and, what is more, it is getting worse all the time. With the present setup the school cannot and will not make ends meet. There is a deficit at the present time of at least $6,000 and this is only half the story, for all the stocks are badly depleted. In other words, they have been living on what was taken over from the other school at Coqualeetza to such an extent that very soon—in fact it should be now—three or four thousand dollars will have to be expended on dry goods and household equipment. It would appear to me that now that a break is being made it is the only logical thing to face the situation and at least give the new man a fighting chance to deal with the problem without being hamstrung by debt. .... If you think we should present the case to the Minister personally, wire me when I could see him. I think this matter should be straightened out very soon".

I may add that the Principal of the Alberni School, Rev. R. C. Scott, was one of three principals of
Ottawa, April 27, 1944.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL.

Re: Additional Accommodation,
St. Philips Indian Residential School.

I regret that I find myself unable to draft a reply for the signature of the Minister to the Honourable Mr. Fournier's letter of April 21. It seems to me that the decision as to whether or not we shall proceed with the construction of an addition to the St. Philips Residential School is one that should be made by the Minister or by his immediate advisers.

May I point out that no provision has been made in the 1944-45 estimates for an expenditure such as the one requested, and if a decision is reached to proceed with the construction, then a supplementary estimate will be necessary.

You may remember that the Onion Lake (C.E.) Residential School was destroyed by fire toward the end of the last calendar year. A decision was reached at that time whereby the representatives of the Church of England were authorized to use St. Alban's College, Prince Albert, for residential school purposes, until the Onion Lake School could be rebuilt. This decision resulted in an outlay of $14,294.00, for which no provision had been made, with the result that we were compelled to take this amount from the comparatively small appropriation set apart for the repair and upkeep of other residential schools. It is our intention at the moment to do all that is humanly possible, with the limited funds at our disposal, to undertake certain repairs at our schools that we were unable to undertake during the last fiscal year.

Reverend Father Brown, who was recently appointed Principal of the Shubenacadie School, visited the Department
Ottawa, April 28, 1944.

Deputy Minister,

In connection with the above noted I am enclosing a memorandum directed to me by Mr. Hoey and which is self-explanatory. Ottawa, May 9, 1944

My dear Colleague,

I have your letter of April 31st again urging that approval be given to enlarging the St. Philip's Indian Residential School. There is little that I can add to my letter to you of the 11th of April. It would seriously embarrass myself, as well as the Government, if at this time we changed the policy decided upon at the beginning of the war, not to increase our Residential School accommodation. There are many places where the need is greater than at St. Philip's school. Because of reduced votes, most if not all of the present school buildings are badly in need of repairs. I have hesitated asking for additional money for this purpose because of the more urgent demands of our war effort.

I am sure you will agree with me that our present buildings should be brought up to a higher state of repair before we embark on a program of providing further accommodation. Then, as I mentioned in my previous letter, we have an obligation to rebuild those schools which have been destroyed in recent years.

Very strong representations were made to me to rebuild the Anglican school at Jaroross, which was destroyed by fire about two years ago. This request I had to refuse. As a result, the church is putting up the building with its own funds. To be consistent I could not approve of expenditures being made to increase the accommodation at another school, regardless of how small the amount involved might be.

Hon. Alphonse Fournier, M.O.,
Minister of Public Works,
OTTAWA.

REPORT ON PELLY INDIAN AGENCY

St. Philip's Residential School - is a good building of frame construction - kept in a spotless condition. The outside requires paint, as do all the buildings. In my opinion, it is economical to supply paint to keep these buildings in proper condition.

The upper structure of the barn above the plates has warped about seven inches and should be pulled back into place and braced properly. Agent Bryant was requested to submit an estimate of the cost after obtaining opinions from qualified sources. The earth has rotted the bottom boards and sills. Father Tetrault is taking off the bottom boards and will report on the condition of the building. Repairs will have to be made. If a quantity of lumber is required, then it should be supplied. The labour would be supplied by the Fathers.

The girls' outside toilet is in a dilapidated condition and should be replaced by a new one. Father Tetrault was requested to write to Ottawa for permission to construct a new one. The old toilet might be salvaged to make two toilets and given to destitute Indians. See remarks on toilets on the Reserve.

The present root-house - is not large enough for the needs of the school. It is recommended that a cement root-house be constructed in the north west corner of the school, using two walls of the school foundation and building only two walls and a roof. If this is done, a door can be constructed so that it will open into the kitchen. This would be the most economical construction to supply additional root storage. The Agency and Father Tetrault will investigate the cost and submit a report to Ottawa.

Hen-house - is facing the wrong direction to benefit from the sun. The windows are now facing the west, when they should be facing the south. This building, at little cost, could be moved to another location and so placed that it would have a southern exposure.

Pig-House - too small and infested with rats. It should be moved to a new location and enlarged.

J.E. Morris,
Welfare Division.

St Philips Residential School

I wish to refer to your letter of July 18th, to Rev. Fr. Tetrault, of St. Philips school in regard to his request for repairs at the school this year in addition to what has already been provided out of this year's appropriation, and I wish to advise that certain repairs are indeed necessary.

The cement floor and mangers of the stock barn will have to be repaired. The cement mangers were not strongly constructed in the building, and these are broken in several places. The gutters are narrow and deep and the cement at the bottom is nearly all gone entirely, with the result that a cow goes down a foot or more in muck if she steps in the gutter, this is dangerous, and it is also impossible to properly clean out the gutters.

It is estimated that it will take 30 bags of cement for this repair work at an estimated cost of $1.15 a sack. The gravel will have to be hauled, and the cost of this and labour in doing the work will run into approximately $100.00.

Father claims he is in urgent need of a granary 30 x 12 for storage of this year's crop, the material would cost locally about $200.00. He would supply the necessary labour in order to get this constructed this fall.

The inside of the building should have more paint especially the laundry, kitchen and store rooms, and if it is at all possible to supply the paint, good use could be made of 20 gallons of cream, and 10 gallons of white paint.

Dear Father Tetrault:

I received your telegram of the 6th instant, suggesting the transfer of the water softeners from the Qu'Appelle School to the St. Philips Residential School. I immediately wired the Qu'Appelle School and ascertained that the water softeners they have were installed when the building was erected, about 10 years ago. While the Principal of the Qu'Appelle School states they are in good condition, he further advises that if they are removed he will require one of a larger capacity.

The type of softener ordered for the St. Philips School was decided following information received from the Surveys and Engineering Branch. We were advised by them that the softener ordered would be suitable for softening the water that you have at the St. Philips School. There is no guarantee that the softeners at present at the Qu'Appelle School would be suitable for the St. Philips School. Besides, if the softeners are transferred, we would simply have to secure another softener for Qu'Appelle. We have given very careful consideration to your request, but we cannot see our way clear to authorize the transfer. As previously stated, I am extremely sorry that there has been such a delay in securing the water softener for your school, but this is due to circumstances beyond our control, although we are making every possible endeavour to have the softener shipped as soon as conditions will permit.

Yours sincerely,

Feb.2, 1945

Mr. Philip Phelan
Chief of training division

Dear Sir,

If I remember well we have been waiting now for our water softener for nearly a year.

Mr. A. Hoey, Sup't of Welfare & Training, tells me in one of his letters, quote:

"Due to the present conditions, there may be some delay."

Yesterday I had the surprise of my life when entering into Mr. Parkinson's Hardware in Saskatoon, in seeing there in front of my eyes a water softener. Asking him how many he had, he replied: TWO. When did you order them? I again inquired, he answered about a month and a half ago. I got them from Farbauer Horse of Regina.

There is something I cannot understand. He obtains two water softeners for small private homes, which can go without them, when we cannot get ours for our Institution. I was told also that the delay was caused by the difficulty of obtaining some kind of materials with which they are built. I cannot yet understand why one company can obtain the material when another cannot.

We are still melting snow and ice for soft water, this means a great deal of work and hardship for the Rev. Sisters and children alike. We all hope the end of such a situation is near.

Hoping that you will soon be able to announce to us the delivery of this water softener.

I remain sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Shipment promised by Mr. Cody, Crane Ltd between Mar. 15th, 30th. He is trying to get the factory to improve upon this delivery. A promise arrives as soon as shipment is made.
Ottawa, February 14, 1945.

Dear Father Tetrault:

With reference to previous correspondence regarding a water softener for the St. Philips School, we have again communicated with the manufacturer of this machine and we have been definitely promised that it will be shipped some time between March 15 and 31.

I have noted your remarks regarding the water softener you saw in the local store. If this was only a small machine, suitable for a private home, it is quite possible that the material in it could be more easily secured than the larger one with which you are being supplied. As far as we can ascertain, every possible endeavour has been made to secure the machine for your school, but, due to urgent war demands for some of the materials required for this particular machine, the delay, while aggravating to you, has been due to circumstances beyond anyone's control.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. E. Tetrault,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
St. Philips, Sask.

J.E.Morris Esq., Acting Inspector, Indian Agencies, REGINA.

St Philips School repairs

With further reference to your letter of February 22, File 310-11 ARC and our discussion in connection with certain necessary repairs when you visited this agency last summer, I wish to advise that I have gone into this matter with Father Tetrault and I am enclosing an estimate covering repairs that should be taken care of as soon as possible, and also a built-in insulated box to be operated by a frigidaire unit. The latter is very urgently required as there are no proper facilities for the storage of meat and other perishable foods.

All the old buildings are very much in need of at least one coat of paint. To paint them all would take hundreds of gallons, but the Principal would like to do some of them this year, and requests that he be supplied with 25 gallons of Barn red paint, and 5 gallons of white for trim. In all cases the labour will be furnished by the school if the material is supplied.

The Barn will require new studding for most of the east end and part of one side; partial cement foundation is also required. The east end of the barn is down below the ground surface; this has caused the studs to rot, and these will have to be replaced up to where they are sound.

If it is possible to find the necessary funds I would strongly recommend that the material asked for is supplied.

J.L.Bryant, Indian Agent.

Regina, March 15th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re: Repairs, St. Philips School.

Herewith is Mr. Bryant's letter of March 12th enclosing an estimate of the cost of repairs to buildings and the frigidaire plant at the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

In my report during my visit to the St. Philips School last year I indicated the need of immediate repairs to the barn, the reconstruction of a larger pig pen and the construction of a root cellar. I would therefore recommend that approval be granted for the purchase of necessary material to do this work as well as the purchase of 25 gals. of barn red paint and 5 gals. of white for trim. All the work, of course, will be done by members of the staff without cost to the Department.

Regarding the frigidaire, you will recall that I mentioned Father Tetrault was badly in need of this equipment so that meat could be properly kept. However, I am not sure if the suggested construction is practical and I had no idea that the cost would be, as estimated, $1088.81. Perhaps Mr. Doucett may have some ideas on the proper construction of an insulated box which could be operated with the frigidaire unit, the cost of which should be a great deal less than the amount estimated. Further consideration, therefore, should be given to the proper box to be installed. In the meantime, however, I would suggest that the other work be proceeded with and would recommend that the materials be supplied.

J. E. Morris,

Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Mr. Philip Chelan
Chief Training Division

Dear Sir,

I receive your letter announcing the purchase of paint for our school. I am very grateful and thank you very much.

With our boys, we have this year painted nearly all the interiors of the school. We have started to paint in red the buildings surrounding the school. Next year we should have paint to paint the exteriors of the school if needed. We do all the work ourselves because we feel that this is a good training for our boys. I must say that some are now very adept at the work.
The war in Europe is over. So much equipment will be put aside. We here need a 2-ton truck. I just phoned Mr. Bryant—he has no forms for such application. If you have such forms, would you please send me a few. If you know what equipment will be available for schools would you please—send me a list.

We are in great need of a truck. We are at 11 miles from town. So a two-ton truck is badly needed to bring in supply—coal—building materials—to haul our grain—stock etc.

Awaiting your reply I remain

Sincerely yours,

P. L. Tetrauld
Ottawa, May 14, 1945.

Dear Father Tetrault:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to securing a two-ton truck.

As far as we know at the present time, this equipment will not be available for free distribution. All trucks surplus to requirements of the Armed Services are turned over to the War Assets Corporation, Montreal, to whom application should be made directly by yourself.

This Department is not handling any of this equipment, as the War Assets Corporation have placed a price on each item of equipment, and the purchaser has to accept the article in the condition in which it happens to be. It is therefore felt that by dealing directly with the Corporation any school principal would be in a better position to decide if he wished to pay the price requested for any equipment.

Yours very truly,

Rev. E. Tetrault, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
St. Philips, Sask.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

May I inquire once more about the water softener. In your letter of Feb. 14th you wrote: "We have been definitely promised that it will be shipped some time between March 15th and 31st."

Months have gone by and the water softener is not here. Our soft water supply holds till October. We would like to receive this machine soon so that we may put it in operation in Sept. when the children come in.

I know the department has been very generous for our school since
I am in charge. I have obtained much to better our condition, and to improve the buildings and all.

I have one more thing in my feet. I mean we have great trouble to keep our meat and food—because we have no frigidaire. I know it is difficult to obtain them, but now they are coming back on the market—-or could you not obtain one from the army—if such thing—is put aside at some closed camps. If now we were to receive this water filters and frigidaire that would greatly better our situation.

Anxiously awaiting your answer

Remain Sincerely Yours,

R.L. Patricell
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 10, 1945.

Dear Father Tetrault:

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant, I wish to advise you that the firm supplying the water softener for the St. Philip's School notified us that this machine was shipped to the school on August 7. Consequently, you should receive it in the near future.

I regret the delay in supplying this equipment, but, as you were previously advised, it was due to circumstances beyond our control.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

October 16th, 1945

Mr. Philips Phelan  
Chief of Training Division

Dear Sir;

I am back again in your office with a letter.

I suppose that at this time of the year, you prepare the estimate, or the cost of operation of the next fiscal year.

Would you be kind enough to include in the budget the cost of a frigidaire for our school. We have an ice-house, but it is inadequate to keep meat. From the first days of April till the middle of November it is very difficult for us to preserve our meat or the left over from tables. In fact it is practically impossible. This is a serious problem when a hundred persons must be fed and fed properly. Especially these days we cannot let meat or any other food stuff go to waste when so many others in the world go hungry.

I hope that you will consider as important this new need for our school, for on food and especially meat well kept depends the health of our children and the members of the staff.

Sincerely Yours

P.E.Tétrault O.M.I.

Lavigne, O.M.I., Manitoba Provincial, under whose management the St. Philips Indian Residential School is placed, has asked me to request the building, by the Department, of an employees' residence. Although this school was erected over 15 years ago, no structure was ever provided for that purpose and the few employees have had to either reside in the school or else in the Fathers' own residence. Re: Frigidaire for St. Philips and Brocket Indian Residential Schools.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing the original of a letter received this morning from the Keyes Supply Co. Ltd., of Ottawa, re frigidaire equipment and cost of installation for the two above schools. You will notice that after providing $150.00 for the installation or building proper of this unit, the total cost is $1540.00, which is considered less than the bids received from Western Canada.

This unit would also serve all the needs of the Beauval School.

You will notice that the installation would consist of dual purpose refrigerator, in which one part would be kept at 0° F. for freezing purposes and the other at from 32° to 40° F. for normal food storage. I think that this is ideal for our schools.

As these three schools are not providing ice for next summer, I hope that you will be able to supply them with this unit.

Further to our recent conversation concerning food storage equipment suitable for your Indian schools, the writer has prepared a sketch and specification covering such installations which we trust you will find of value.

The installation as proposed would consist of a dual purpose refrigerator to be erected on site and equipped with electric refrigeration to lower the temperature within one area to approximately 0° F. and maintain temperatures ranging from 32° F. to 40° F. in the remaining area for normal food storage.

The erection of these rooms should not entail any great amount of skill insofar as carpentry work is concerned and it is suggested that a loose fill insulation be used such as Palco wool.

The sketch attached will give approximate dimensions indicating the amount of insulation to be used and the placement of the actual cooling coils.

We would estimate that these rooms should not exceed $750. in cost including cold storage doors and it is quite possible that in some sections of the country where lumber is far cheaper than in this locality this price may be depreciated by as much as 25%.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

On various occasions, during the past five years, I have mentioned to your Department, the necessity of providing chapel accommodation for the St. Phillip's Indian Residential School. Due to war conditions, I did not press for an appropriation for this purpose.

With the rapid increase in the school population, the chapel project is becoming every day more urgent and we feel that its execution should not be delayed any longer. We have on hand, for charitable purposes, a sum of money which we believe to be about sufficient to carry out our plans.

We therefore ask the department to grant us permission to erect this building, as an addition to the school. We will follow the same architectural lines so that the chapel, from the outside, will appear to be an enlargement of the school building.

Of course it is understood that no claim will be made by the Oblate Order, no matter what disposition may be made later on of the St. Phillip's School property by the Department.
Ottawa, April 25, 1946.

Dear Father Flourde:

Re: Chapel Accommodation - St. Phillip's Indian Residential School.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 17th, in which you intimate that chapel accommodation is urgently needed for the pupils of the above-mentioned school.

It is noted that the chapel will be erected as an addition to the school and that the same architectural lines of the school building will be adopted.

The officials here inform me that a somewhat similar concession was granted at other residential schools during the last ten-year period and I can see no objection to the granting of your request in this case. It will be satisfactory to the department, therefore, for you to proceed with the construction of the chapel at an early date.

Aug. 4-86

Mr. Philip Phelan

Dear Sir,

As you know we have built an addition to our school, the size of which is 36' x 30'.
The basement will be the playroom for the girls.
The first floor the chapel, and the second floor a dormitory.
We were unable to find for our floors - hard wood. So they were made out of spruce. So now to protect these floors from wear we would need some linoleum - feltship or other good and heavy material, and this has two floors 36' x 30' each.
I spoke to Mr. A. Macdonald about it at Regina, and he may discuss the problem with you at his return at Ottawa.

Hoping that you will be in a position to help us,

Remain

Sincerely Yours,

W. E. Petrie, Principal
Ottawa, August 15, 1946.

Dear Father Tetrault:

I have your letter of the 4th instant requesting approximately three hundred and eighty square yards of linoleum for St. Philips Indian Residential School. This would cost in the vicinity of $750.00.

In the current year's appropriation we provided an amount of $800.00 for repairs and improvements and the purchase of new equipment for the St. Philips Residential School. We placed an order for a refrigerating unit at a cost of $640.00 and in addition we have paid an account of $1009.86 covering the cost of lumber, etc. Under these circumstances, the amount specifically provided for this school has already been exceeded. We have received many heavy demands on our appropriation and at the present time we are not in a position to favourably consider the linoleum. However, you might write to me again before the last of October, at which time we will again review our appropriation and see if we have the necessary funds.

Yours truly,

Rev. E. Tetrault, O.M.I.
St. Philips, Ask.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

ST. PHILIPS P.O., SASK.

Le 27 août 1896

Cher Monsieur,

J'aimerais savoir si le département nous fournirait des catéchismes pour la Catholic Faith School et bien fait sous forme d'exercices, etc.

Notre école a remporté 200 prix cette année aux deux expositions de Regina et de Prince Albert.

J'ai reçu une réponse de M. Shelan au sujet du Lionnem. Il dit que les finances du département ne permettent pas l'achat d'un nouveau ouvrage déjà reçu. 500.00 plus 640. reste encore à payer pour le frigidaire. Tout de même il me demande de lui écrire de nouveau en octobre.

Je viens de recevoir la facture pour les "Panic Belts". Toute
faire ces dernières ne sont pas arrivées, je suppose qu'elles le seront ce jour-ci. Est-ce que je peux envoyer cette facture au département ?

Notre fournisseur pour le chauffage de l'école a été condamné par l'inspecteur des boulilliers. Je lui ai parlé à l'agent M. Bryant, il m'a autorisé à demander à la Co. Northern Locomotive de réparer le tout.

Mais nous ne ferons pas comme le demande l'inspecteur, ça coûterait le prix d'une nouvelle. Ce fournisseur garantit que son ouvrage rendra le boulillard encore bonne pour au moins dix ans. Les flues doivent être changées. Il faudra un clou de 2 pouces traverser. Si l'on apprend encore plus tard, il sera trop tard de mettre un autre système de chauffage.

Bien voilà,

P.S. P.F. Tétuacel
Ottawa, 17 September 1946.

Dear Sir:

I was in your office sometime last week, to discuss the transfer of some beds from St. Mary's Indian School at Kenora, Ontario, to ours at St. Philips Saskatchewan.

The beds are now on their way here. We went ahead with Rev. Father Provincial's approval and had these beds shipped here. As you know Kenora Indian School received quite a number of these beds last summer. This year on account of the very small number of children in School they did not need them all. As for our School our number has increased considerably and so we are short of beds. I tried to buy some in Winnipeg without success. The Department was unable to send us some. Also Father Perreafel O.M.I. having repaired many of his double-deck beds, by using the upper spring down, doing away with the double deck beds, thus making first class beds out of old ones, he had therefore some new ones left over, so they were sent here to help us out.

I hope this will meet with your approval.

Fr. Tetrault, the Principal, has considerable knowledge of heating boilers and does not want the present one scrapped and a new boiler installed for two reasons. In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of August 11th, 1947, bearing your notation of the 13th instant, together with attached quotation from the Northwestern Iron Works, Ltd., with reference to the above, you are advised as follows:

Mr. Ian Turnbull of Kamsack has now submitted a tender for the exterior painting of St. Phillips Residential School which is attached herewith. The School have the necessary white lead on hand but it would be necessary to supply the Zinc Oxide, Linseed Oil, Japan Drier.

This is a very high building and I would not be in favour of the older school boys being used for this work. They have done most of the exterior painting on the other buildings and also the interior painting of the school building.

Weather may not allow this work to be completed this fall, but we might at least get one coat on before freeze up.

Mr. Turnbull is a good reliable workman and I consider his estimate for the labour is quite reasonable.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Dimension of Building:

Main Building. 33 ft. by 100 ft. 40 ft. high
Addition. 35 " " 56 " 25 "

Adjoining Back Building Total 135 ft. by 70 ft. 8 ft. to 6 ft. High.
Regina, September 29th, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter received from Indian Agent Mr. J.L. Bryant, of the Pelly Agency, together with requisition for painting the exterior of the St. Philip's Indian Residential School. Also enclosed is tender from Mr. Len Turnbull, of Kamsack, Saskatchewan, for $765.00 for performance of all the labour connected therewith.

It will be noted that Indian Agent Bryant does not recommend using the Indian boys for the painting of this building as the building is high and most of the work will be on scaffolds where there is danger of an accident. I agree with Mr. Bryant's comments in this connection.

It will also be noted that the material is on hand for the job with the exception of 100 lbs. Zinc Oxide and 1 gal. of Japan Dryer. The cost of this material will not be high and I would recommend that Mr. Bryant be given authority to buy the quantity required by local purchase. Please grant authority for this at the earliest possible date in the hope that it may be completed before the weather becomes bad.

Memorandum

Re: St. Phillips Indian Residential School, Kamsack, Sask.

You are advised that on January 19th, 1947, Mr. Hoey forwarded a memorandum to this Division, in which a request was made to have our Mr. Hargreaves visit the above on one of his trips to the West.

While at the Gordon's School on his recent visit to Punnichy, Mr. Hargreaves was authorized to go to Kamsack at the urgent request of Mr. Ostrander, and the following report covers the result of his inspection.

Complete data was obtained with regard to the mechanical services, although no complaints were noted in connection with the functioning of either the heating or domestic hot water systems outside the boiler room.

The building is heated by a two-pipe low pressure steam heating system, which is served by one low pressure 50 H.P. steel fire-box boiler, fired with wood in four-foot lengths. The boiler is over twenty-seven years old and has shown signs of failure for several years. The Provincial Boiler Inspector has ordered various repairs after his yearly inspections, and the unit has now reached the stage where no further satisfactory or lasting repairs can be made. From 1944 to 1947 inclusive, the Boiler Inspector's reports have summarized the condition of the boiler from fair to very poor. Pitting at the lower section of the boiler has resulted in many thin spots in the boiler plate and any further attempts at patching would be impracticable.

It was found that one new wing had been added to the building and that one or two future extensions are contemplated, all of which must be taken care of by the boiler plant. This, coupled with the isolated location of the school, justifies a two boiler installation, each boiler having an approximate capacity to handle eighty per cent (80%) of the entire load. With such an arrangement, future repairs to either one of the boilers could be made at any time without shutting down the system. It was also noted that the original plans made no provisions for removing any equipment from the boiler room.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
It is our recommendation, therefore, that the following operations be carried out as soon as possible after the close of the present heating season.

1. Enlarge the present boiler and fuel room and provide proper entrance to same.

2. Remove existing worn-out boiler and replace with two new low pressure steam steel firebox boilers, each having a net stoker fired rating of 3058 sq. ft. E.D.R.

3. Provide two under-feed stokers ranged for single hopper and of a type suitable for burning lignite coal at a rate of not less than 180 lbs. per hour when operating at high speed.

4. Replace existing boiler return trap and air eliminator with one new condensation return pump.

5. Make necessary changes to boiler room piping to accommodate the new installation.

To carry out the above operations and have the plant ready for service by next fall, tenders should be called for as soon as possible and work started shortly thereafter. It is estimated that an approximate amount of $15,000.00 would cover the installation, and it is expected that competitive prices could be obtained from several firms in the area.

If Indian Affairs have funds to apply to the work recommended, this Division will undertake the preparation of layouts and specifications which will undoubtedly be a basis for a more accurate estimate of cost.

Chief Engineer.
Ottawa, April 26, 1948.

Memorandum:

Re: St. Phillips Indian Residential School, Kamsack, Sask.

With reference to Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 26th, bearing your marginal notation of the 28th inst., and further to our memorandum of April 30th, you are advised as follows:

We are informed by the Indian Affairs Branch that there are not sufficient funds in this year's appropriations to carry out the recommendations outlined in our memorandum of April 17th; and they have requested that the work, at the above, be held to an absolute minimum.

It is our considered opinion that the present heating boiler cannot be repaired to give any degree of satisfactory service. It is again pointed out that the Provincial Boiler Inspector's last report described the unit to be in a "very poor condition" and recommended that a new boiler be installed.

To carry out the minimum requirements one new steel low pressure steam heating boiler must be installed and some alterations to the coal bin must be made in order to provide access doors large enough to admit the new boiler and to provide coal storage.

The School authorities reported to our heating engineer that the wood used for fuel was becoming somewhat of a problem as its source was gradually receding, thus necessitating increased charges for cutting and hauling. For this reason it is considered advisable to recommend a stoker suitable for burning Lignite coal. Lignite coal is widely and successfully handled throughout the Prairie Provinces and is in plentiful supply.

We are proceeding with the design along the above lines and it is expected that the work will cost approximately $8,000.00.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum

Re: St. Philips Indian Residential School, Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

In reply to your marginal notation of the 6th instant which appears on Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 30th with reference to the above, we are in a position to advise that there is not sufficient space in the boiler room to accommodate two boilers of any kind without extensive structural enlargement.

Since the expenditure must be kept to a minimum, owing to lack of sufficient funds in this year's appropriation, the only solution which will satisfy the recommendations is to install one high fire-box type low pressure steam steel heating boiler, along with one underfeed stoker.

The Canadian Brown Steel Tank Company Limited of Brandon manufacture a steel boiler designed to meet these requirements and suitable for burning lignite coal. The Vulcan-Drawz Stoker, which is also manufactured in the West, has been specifically designed to burn lignite coal and is widely and successfully used.

In order to get this equipment into the building, it will only be necessary to make an opening in the existing fuel storage bin, thereby keeping the structural alterations to a minimum. It would be advisable to erect a shed at the rear of the present coal bin for the purpose of storing a winter supply of fuel. The operations outlined herein are estimated to cost not more than $5,000.00.

T.S. Mills,

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, September 21, 1948.

Re: St. Phillips Indian Residential School, Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of August 31st, bearing your marginal notation of September 2nd, with regard to the above, you are advised as follows:

In our original memorandum of April 17th, which was prepared after our Mr. Hargreaves had inspected the school, provision was made for enlarging the fuel room which was to be carried as part of the contract. The recommendations included two boilers and two stokers, along with the necessary auxiliary equipment, and our estimate was given as $15,000.00.

In Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 26th, he advised that it would not be possible to provide that amount from this year's appropriation and that they were prepared to purchase one new boiler only. Since the work was considered urgent, our plans were revised to include one boiler and one stoker and to provide only the minimum of structural changes, which involved the enlarging of one door and the installation of one new door in order to permit the old boiler to be taken out and the new boiler to be taken in. As a result of this re-design, our estimate was brought down to $8,000.00, and in a subsequent memorandum from Mr. Hoey dated June 10, he agreed that this sum could be provided. Consequently tenders were called and the lowest bid was received from Messrs Neale Stothank and Chapman, of Brandon, which was for the sum of $7,702.69.

Since the work had not been started when our heating engineer left for an inspection trip through the West, it was not considered necessary to have him call at Kamsack, as no purpose could be served. When the work is completed, it is expected that he will visit the school to make an inspection before final payment is made to the contractor.

It is noted in Mr. Hoey's memorandum of August 31st, that Father Ruest has on his staff a Brother who is qualified to carryout inspection work. It is suggested that they be requested to provide an estimate of the cost of a coal bin made of frame construction and that if satisfactory to the Indian Affairs Branch, funds be provided to have this work carried out apart from the contract.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,

MEMORANDUM

Re: St. Phillip's Indian Residential School, Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

You are advised that the Principal of the above school has requested permission from the Indian Affairs Branch to construct an addition to the coal bin.

The Indian Affairs Branch informed this Division today by telephone, that they would comply with the Principal's request, and authorize him to carry out this work, which of course, will not be included in the contract, under which Neale Stothard and Chapman are carrying out revisions to the boiler room and boiler room equipment.

The Principal has requested the contractor to defer structural alterations to the existing boiler room and coal bin as he contemplates building the proposed coal bin in this area.

It is our definite recommendation that the contractors work in connection with the structural alterations be carried out in accordance with the plans and specifications prepared by this Division, and that the Indian Affairs Branch be advised to instruct the Principal that the proposed auxiliary coal shed must not be built around the ramp.

It is suggested that the new coal shed be built in the form of a lean-to and located adjacent to the rear wall of the existing drying room at ground level.

Attention: Owner, Manager or Superintendent

Dear Sir:

The following extracts from the Boiler & Pressure Vessel Act 1948, are particularly drawn to your attention.

Section 14 An inspection certificate may set forth repairs or alterations to be made in, upon or in connection with any boiler, pressure vessel or plant, and the owner shall cause such repairs to be executed forthwith.

Section 17 Every inspection certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plant or near the boiler or pressure vessel to which it relates and shall be produced by the owner or other person responsible for or in immediate charge of such boiler, pressure vessel or plant upon demand of an inspector.

Section 20 (1) No owner shall cause or permit any high pressure boiler or steam plant to be operated unless:
(a) a chief engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as chief engineer, and who is not responsible for the operation of any other boiler or steam plant, is responsible for and personally supervises the operation thereof; and
(b) either such chief engineer or a shift engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as shift engineer is in immediate charge thereof and the chief engineer, shift engineer or some other person acting under the direct supervision of the chief engineer or shift engineer is in personal attendance on the boiler at all times, whether or not any such boiler is equipped with automatic control.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), no owner shall cause or permit any low pressure boiler or steam plant having a capacity of twenty horse power or more to be operated unless a person who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant is responsible for the operation thereof and in personal attendance thereon at all times.

(3) A low pressure boiler having a capacity of not more than seventy-five horse power which is equipped with an automatic low-water cut-out device approved by an inspector and designed to shut off the fuel fire in the event of low water, may be left unattended and in operation for a period not exceeding ten consecutive hours if:
(a) the safety valve is set to relievel at not more than fifteen pounds to the square inch;
(b) the safety valve and automatic low-water cut-out device are tested daily to ensure their efficient operation;
(c) the automatic low-water cut-out device is installed in such manner that it cannot be rendered inoperative by the manipulation of any manual control or regulating apparatus and the water column, water glass and the float chamber of the cut-out device may be thoroughly blown out each day.

Section 27 Every owner of a boiler, pressure vessel or plant shall provide and keep at all times in a readily accessible location an adequately equipped first aid kit for the treatment of minor injuries and shall produce such first aid kit upon demand of an inspector.

Our inspectors report that in some instances owners are employing persons to operate boilers who do not hold certificates issued under the Act and we sincerely hope that after receipt of this notice such violations will be corrected making further action unnecessary.

Your full co-operation in respect to all the requirements of the Act is solicited in the interests of public safety and will be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

The following extracts from the Boiler & Pressure Vessel Act 1948, are particularly drawn to your attention.

Section 14 An inspection certificate may set forth repairs or alterations to be made in, upon or in connection with any boiler, pressure vessel or plant, and the owner shall cause such repairs to be executed forthwith.

Section 17 Every inspection certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plant or near the boiler or pressure vessel to which it relates and shall be produced by the owner or other person responsible for or in immediate charge of such boiler, pressure vessel or plant upon demand of an inspector.

Section 20 (1) No owner shall cause or permit any high pressure boiler or steam plant to be operated unless:
(a) a chief engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as chief engineer, and who is not responsible for the operation of any other boiler or steam plant, is responsible for and personally supervises the operation thereof; and
(b) either such chief engineer or a shift engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as shift engineer is in immediate charge thereof and the chief engineer, shift engineer or some other person acting under the direct supervision of the chief engineer or shift engineer is in personal attendance on the boiler at all times, whether or not any such boiler is equipped with automatic control.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), no owner shall cause or permit any low pressure boiler or steam plant having a capacity of twenty horse power or more to be operated unless a person who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant is responsible for the operation thereof and in personal attendance thereon at all times.

(3) A low pressure boiler having a capacity of not more than seventy-five horse power which is equipped with an automatic low-water cut-out device approved by an inspector and designed to shut off the fuel fire in the event of low water, may be left unattended and in operation for a period not exceeding ten consecutive hours if:
(a) the safety valve is set to relieve at not more than fifteen pounds to the square inch;
(b) the safety valve and automatic low-water cut-out device are tested daily to ensure their efficient operation;
(c) the automatic low-water cut-out device is installed in such manner that it cannot be rendered inoperative by the manipulation of any manual control or regulating apparatus and the water column, water glass and the float chamber of the cut-out device may be thoroughly blown out each day.

Section 27 Every owner of a boiler, pressure vessel or plant shall provide and keep at all times in a readily accessible location an adequately equipped first aid kit for the treatment of minor injuries and shall produce such first aid kit upon demand of an inspector.

Our inspectors report that in some instances owners are employing persons to operate boilers who do not hold certificates issued under the Act and we sincerely hope that after receipt of this notice such violations will be corrected making further action unnecessary.

Your full co-operation in respect to all the requirements of the Act is solicited in the interests of public safety and will be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,
