March 28, 1942

Mr. J. Bryant, Indian Agent  
St. Philips, Sask.

Dear Sir,

Having more girls at work in the sewing room this year, we are short of sewing machines. There are ten girls who are able to sew and eight who would be able to learn. We now have six machines, one of them in poor condition, and two were bought by Rev. Father Principal. If one or two machines could be obtained, this would allow the girls to do much more work "sewing and mending". Giving them also more time to work for the war services, in which they have taken a great part and interest.

So knowing your great interest you take in our school we thought you could obtain us this favor from the Department of Indian Affairs.

Thanking you for your kindness, also taking this opportunity to thank Mrs. Bryant for her kindness and help she has given for the Junior Red Cross and war services.

Yours very respectfully,

Missionary Oblate Sisters

Sister Mary of the Rosary.
Kamsack, Saskatchewan,
May 9th, 1942.

Dear Sir;

I have received a request from St. Philips Boarding School for one or two sewing machines. They have six now, one of which is in very poor condition. The girls at St. Philips get a great deal of very useful training in sewing and needlework and I would strongly recommend the supply of at least one new machine at this time if it is at all possible. The Singer Sewing Machine Co. at Yorkton will supply a suitable new machine at $76.50 less a discount of 45% where the machine will be used in a school.

I am attaching the Reverend Sister Superior's letter for your perusal.

Yours very truly,

J.L. Bryant
Indian Agent.

Chief, Training Division,

In reply to your letter of the 25th instant, I wish to say that three 36" looms have been ordered through the Purchasing Branch. You should receive them in a short while.

The military authorities have not yet released any of the Moving picture machines and even if they had I greatly doubt if they would be of very much use to us. It must be kept in mind that these machines have received very rough usage because of the conditions under which they were used. They would probably cause our schools a great deal of trouble. We have, however, put in our estimates for the coming year sufficient money to purchase a number of these machines. We intend to introduce them gradually. I do not know as yet which schools will receive these machines as this has not yet been decided.

You may spend an amount not to exceed $40.00 to procure Manual Training material for the boy's workshop.

A.J. Douset,
Training Division.

Cher Monsieur,

Nous avons commencé notre programme dans la boutique officiellement, lundi passé. Les garçons ont bien fait cela, et il n'est pas à dire qu'ils aiment cela, ils sont tous enthousiastes de ce nouveau genre d'étude et de travail. Le frère P.B. Lacasse est bien content des résultats tout fraisage que tout ira pour le mieux. Les garçons du premier groupe, les plus vieux, recevront bien leur deux chaises comme travail un "bon lundi". Il le terminera le même jour, et recevra très bien.

Il est question ici que l'on rende notre mission pour dernier huit jours nos indiens. Le P.P. Plante ont demandé une maison pour notre ferme. Si cela se passe, cela veut dire de la pratique en construction pour nos garçons, car tout le travail sera fait par le frère et nous. Aussi nous serions obligés de construire une grange, il faudra construire pour installer encore de la pratique. Nous devons aussi terminer les réparations à l'étable des premiers travaux pour le printemps pratique encore. Nous devons aussi construire un hangar pour les machines, une maison pour les Pères, une école de chapelles sur les réserves, pratique encore et toujours. Dès au printemps les garçons apprendront à se servir des outils, à mesurer et à faire certains travaux, puis dès les travaux finis, viendra la pratique sous le feu.

Je viens de recevoir le "Shipping Bill" - pour métiers - ils nous arrivent bientôt - je suppose. Nous n'avons pas d'endroits pour les installations, notre école est si petite - trop petite. Le P. Dauzet ne savait pas bien derrière. Elles iront apprendre s'il est prochain.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st 1945.

Education

Indian education is a subject that has, I am sure given our department and all who are really interested in the Indians, very serious thought, the problems are many and it would appear that there is still room for some improvement in our present set up. Very few of the day schools have qualified teachers and I think these should be employed by the department and not by any church organization if we are going to get suitable men and women for this very important work. A day school teacher could be employed for the full 12 months, and they should devote considerable in organizing sports and healthy recreation for the young people.

We have one Residential school and two day schools at this agency, but have several pupils from all reserves attending residential schools at other points in Saskatchewan and Manitoba. In a residential school good management and an efficient teaching staff are a prime necessity and in St Philips school here, we fortunately have a good teaching staff and a school that is exceptionally well managed. Apart from academic subjects the pupils are taught cooking, sewing, general housework, manual training, field work, care of livestock, and poultry etc. This school is filled to capacity at present and there are several pupils at home at present that should be in school if accommodation was available. There should be provision made for at least another 40 pupils and this may not be sufficient in another ten years. We would also like to see pupils that are anxious to make something of themselves, given the opportunity of staying on in school after they are 16 years old, in fact I think it would be a great help to many of the girls if they were kept in Boarding school at least another year longer.

J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I beg that you would recommend to the Department through the Indian Commissioner the purchase for the new St. Phillips Indian Residential school of horses and milk cows. Prince Albert,
21st January, 1896.

Hon. Sir:

I have the honour to make application to the Government to authorize us to prepare the means for the official establishment of a boarding school for the children of the catholic Indians of Battleford reserves, for the following reasons:

1. The number of catholic children resident on the reserves of Roundmaker, Little Pine, Moosomin, &c., is considerable.

2. The day schools of Roundmaker and Sweet Grass reserves, although more or less satisfactory, do not give an efficacious result in regard to the education and civilization of the Indian.

3. The heads of catholic families of these reserves, ask for a boarding school, such as the sisters of charity conduct at Onion Lake.

4. The Rev. Father Cochin has written to me that, contrary to the second clause of, No. 14 of the heading (cap.) relative to the Department of Indian Affairs, Statutes of Canada, page 4, the protestant ministers, Macdonald, Clarke, Matheson, of the Battleford Industrial School and their teachers have gone, several times, among our catholics, for the purpose of inducing them to give up their children for the Industrial School, Battleford, and that two have yielded to their importunities.

5. The Industrial Schools of Qu'Appelle and High River, are too far off from us. The school at Duck Lake, although not yet approved as an Industrial School, has already too many demands for a place so limited.

Trusting to your goodness for the successful result of my legitimate request,

I remain, &c.,

(Sgd.) X Albert, C. M. I. Bishop of Marianopolis,
Vicar apostolic, Sask.
Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of a translation of a letter from His Lordship, the Bishop of Mariopolis, making application for the establishment of a Boarding School for the Roman Catholic children of Indians of Battleford Reserve; and in reply I beg to inform you that this Department approves of the action taken by you in this matter, in which nothing further can be done.

Your obedient servant,

Deputy Supt:Genl:
of Indian Affairs.

Prince-Albert, Sask., 25th September 1893.

To the Hon. Clifford Sifton,
Minister of the Indian Dept., Ottawa, Ont.

Honorable Sir,

I have the honor to call your kind attention upon the anomalous situation in which our catholic indian children actually stand at the Battleford reserves of Saskatchewan.

You are well aware that we have no other Boarding-School than that of Duck-Lake, if we except the small one of "Ile a la Croix".

It is quite painful to us to see that our catholic Indians are obliged to send their children to the Industrial School of Battleford, when I feel that the Government could do justice to them.

Prince Albert, 1st May, 1903.

T. O. Davis, Esq., M.P.

Hon. and Dear Sir,

I am exceedingly pained at the refusal of the Dept. of Indian Affairs in regard to the St. Henri School, Thunderchild's, and the Ile à la Crosse school. After the explanations that I received from the Hon. G. Sifton and the Hon. D. Laird, I did not expect such a reply.

Consider, dear sir, and be good enough to make the gentlemen of the Dept. of Indian Affairs understand the justice of my request.

1. The St. Henri, (Thunderchild's), boarding-school was granted us in order that we might receive 50 Roman Catholic children, the number of those who were then at the Battleford Protestant school.

2. Now that this school is working admirably, and that the Sisters have made great sacrifices for this work, the Dept. leaves them with only 15 children, instead of authorizing them to receive 50 in the school, for this purpose.

3. We desire to close the Sweet Grass school, in order to save the Dept. the $500 for the teacher, in favor of the St. Henri boarding-school, and that was not even accepted.

4. I learn that the R.C. Indians of Poundmaker's reserve offered several children to the Principal of the St. Henri school, and that they were refused.
5. Is it more economical for the Dept. to give $136 per child to the Battleford school than $72 to St. Henri school?

6. Ought this school to be allowed to perish, which cannot maintain itself on 15 children, without running into debt; or ought it to be encouraged?

7. Is it possible that the objections of the Ven. Archdeacon McKay and of other clergymen are the cause of this refusal? Is this school the cause of umbrage to these gentlemen? I do not see why; since we do not accept Protestant Indian children, and as we shall be content with 30 children.

8. For all these reasons and others that I cannot write, I beg you, dear sir, to make a supreme effort with the Dept. of Indian Affairs in order that justice may be done our R.C. Indians of Battleford, as well as the R.C. population of this district, which, as you know, counts a great deal on this school. I wrote a line to the Principal and I shall not be surprised if a cry of indignation comes out of those hearts that have everywhere been devoted to you up to the present time.

9. As for myself, I believe that this increase of a few children will be granted us, without difficulty, at our request; but I see by this double refusal, without grounds, that we can no longer count on your esteem and interest.

10. I am the more saddened by these refusals, as the object of my request was most legitimate, and a very small matter.

II. I let you think over these lines, and I shall prepare a petition in connection with the matter to the House, which will not be a compliment.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

In further reference to Bishop Pascal's letter on the subject of an increase for the Thunderchild's and Isle-a-la-Crosse boarding schools, in which he states that he is exceedingly pained at the refusal of the Department to accede to his request for the following reasons:

1. The Bishop claims that he was granted the Thunderchild's school in order that 30 Roman Catholic children might be received, which number, he states were then in the Battleford Protestant school.

There is nothing on file to show that this school was established for the purpose of receiving this number of children. It was established by the Roman Catholics on their own responsibility and is situated on property belonging to their mission just outside the reserve, and although the Department has contributed $1500.00 to the building and provided a per capita grant for 15 pupils, it was done on its own initiative that it made these contributions, but only after pressure was brought to bear by Bishop Pascal. I believe he was correct in stating that there were a number of so-called Roman Catholic children at the Battleford school, but they were there with the full consent of their parents.

2. The Bishop states that the school is
working admirably and that the Sisters have made great sacrifices for the work, but the Department leaves them with only 15 children instead of authorizing them to receive 30 in the school established for that purpose.

It is admitted that this school is in good working order but 15 pupils are all that are provided for and if it was erected to accommodate 30 children the Department was not consulted in the matter.

3. The Bishop says that they wish to close the Sweet Grass school in order to save the Department $300.00 for the teacher's salary, and to assist the Thunderchild's school, but that the Department did not accept this offer.

The Sweet Grass day school is poorly attended but it is as much the fault of the missionary as any one. The Bishop evidently wishes to use the plea of inefficiency of the day school to attain his ends. They have also a day school on Thunderchild's Reserve, which they are endeavoring to freeze out.

4. The Bishop says he is informed that the Indians of Poundmaker's reserve offered several children to the Principal of Thunderchild's school, and that they were refused.

I have no doubt that His Lordship is correct, as this school already has the full number of grant earners enrolled.

5. The Bishop asks whether it is more economical for the Department to pay $135.00 to the Battleford school than $72.00 to Thunderchild's.

It is not altogether a question of economy.
If it were so it would be cheaper to carry on day schools than boarding schools. It is still a question whether the day school should be altogether ignored in favor of boarding and industrial schools as Indians who wish their children educated at day schools have to make some sacrifices, while they are relieved of all responsibility when they place them in the other schools.

6. He questions whether the boarding school should be allowed to perish, as it cannot maintain itself on 15 children without running into debt.

I have already pointed out that no school can be made a financial success with this small number of pupils, but no one was better aware of this than the Roman Catholic authorities when they established the school.

7. Bishop Pascal wants to know whether the objections of Ven. Archdeacon Mackay and other clergymen are the cause of the refusal.

I may say that the Church of England authorities objected to the establishment of the school in the first instance, but since it has been recognized by the Department, no further protests have been received from them.

8. The Bishop states that for the above reasons and others that he cannot write, he begs Mr Davis, M.P., to make a supreme effort with the Department in order that justice made be done the Roman Catholic Indians of Battleford, as well as the Roman Catholic population of the district, and he adds that he shall not be surprised if a cry of indignation comes from these hearts that have everywhere been
devoted to Mr Davis up to the present time.

I can see no just cause for indignation on the part of the Roman Catholics in the way they have been treated by the Department in regard to the establishment and maintenance of boarding schools in the Territories, or in fact in any other part of Canada. The last census gives the Indian population of the Territories as 17,992, of whom 4,279 are said to be Roman Catholics, while the Protestants number 4,788, the balance being pagans. To meet the boarding school requirements the Roman Catholics have established 17 schools, towards the maintenance of which the Department makes provision for 617 pupils; while the Protestants with over 500 more adherents, have only 15 schools and provision for but 468 pupils. This surely shows no unjust discrimination against the Roman Catholics. I think that in dealing with all religious school questions, the Department is justified in taking a broad view of the treatment meted out to the different denominations. The Methodists and the Presbyterians, whose Indian missions are conducted under regularly organized systems, recognize this view of the case, but the Church of England and the Roman Catholics, whose schools are under the immediate charge of the bishops of the different dioceses take much narrower views and consider that the needs of their own particular charges are all the Department has to consider.

9. The Bishop says that as for himself he believes that this increase of a few children will be granted without difficulty at their request, but that he sees by this double refusal without grounds, that they can no longer count on Mr Davis' esteem.
and interest.

The Department considered that it had ample justification for refusing the Bishop's previous demands and if it accedes to them now, it can only be on account of his importunity, as his letter does not strengthen his case in any way, and I cannot see that the refusal of the Department shows any lack of interest on the part of Mr Davis, who has at all times been most insistent in endeavoring to have his recommendations carried out.

10. The Bishop says that he is the more saddened by these refusals as the object of his request was most legitimate and a very small matter.

Provision for 15 more pupils at this school may be a small matter but it is one of principle and should not be made even to stop the clamor of a bishop.

11. He concludes by saying that he will let Mr Davis think over these lines and that he will prepare a petition to the House in connection with the matter, which will not be a compliment.

I think when His Lordship has been put in possession of the facts above stated, he will hesitate about having this matter brought up in the House.

Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

With reference to the letter from the Rev. H. Delmas addressed to Mr. Davis, M. P., May last, regarding the Thunderchild's boarding school, I beg to say that in January, 1896, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Saskatchewan made application for the establishment of a boarding school for the Catholic children of the Battleford Reserve; but it was not until the supplementary estimates for 1900 were passed that any appropriation was made for the Thunderchild's school $3,300 was then provided, $2,500 for buildings and $750 for the maintenance of 25 pupils at $30 per capita.

The buildings were erected by the Roman Catholic Church authorities on property owned by them outside the reserve. A protest was made against a school being started in this locality and it was not until the year 1901 that the grant was allowed for the buildings and only fifteen pupils were provided for them.

The Roman Catholic authorities have asked the Department to assume the liabilities of about $1,800 incurred by them in the erection of this building in addition to the $2,500 already granted and I should consider that these two amounts about represent the total cost of the school.

The school is now recognised by the Department and is in receipt of a per capita grant for twenty pupils, five additional pupils having been provided for in this year's estimates.

You will see that this school has been forced on the Department and that it has already paid more than half the cost of its erection which is the usual extent of its contributions to boarding school buildings.
At present the Department does not exercise full control over any of the boarding schools in the West which are all conducted by different religious denominations and I do not see that it would be any advantage to obtain the title to this school property at present.

Provision is now made for about all the pupils they can accommodate and twenty are all that are now in residence.

There is no special appropriation for paying the indebtedness on the buildings and the church should not have undertaken their erection if they had not money enough to complete them.

The application for an increased grant and for payment of the existing debt has been refused repeatedly by the Department and there is nothing on file which would lead it to reverse its decision as any further grant or payment to this school would only be forming a precedent for other schools to ask to have their liabilities wiped off.

Dear Sir,

The Reverend Father A. Watelle, Principal of the Thunderchild Boarding School at Delmas, announced to me today that the Department is refusing to pay the grant for more than thirty children, this being the number authorized for our school.

Not long ago, Mr. Inspector Chubbeler of the Prince Albert Inspectorate, told very plainly to the Indians on the Red River and Assiniboia that they were free to send their children to any Indian school, either Day School or Boarding School.

Here, the Thunderchild Boarding School is approved by the Medical Health Officer and School Inspector for at least forty children. I have many demands for admission on hand already, shall I tell the parent of these poor children that the Department refuses to give them what they are entitled to?

In connection therewith I wish to inform you that the contract for the maintenance and management of this school, signed by his Lordship the Bishop of Prince Albert, provides for the maintenance of thirty pupils, and our records do not show that any direct application for an increase in the pupilage has ever been made. True the officer who checks the returns and computes the amount of the quarterly grant based his computation on the pupilage provided in the estimates sanctioned by Parliament. Dear Sir:

Several times the ecclesiastical authorities were constrained to blame the young Father Lacombe for his interference with Departmental business on the reserves. The young Father was instructed by the Acting Provincial to manage his own affairs, and to restrict himself to his missionary work. As, instead of carrying out the instructions, he was still meddling in matters which did not concern him, then he was removed from the reserves. After six months, on his earnest desire, he was put again to the work of the missions, but under some conditions, of which I must give you notice.

Father Lacombe has no authority at all by himself. I am not only the Principal of the Boarding School, in Delmas, but also in charge of the Missions in the reserves, and in charge of the Father; and Father Lacombe is working on those reserves wholly under my authority. Besides that, on account of the past trouble and to prevent any in the future, Father Lacombe is forbidden to make any request to the Department without his letter bearing my written approval. Therefore would the Department have the advice or the support of the missions for anything
concerning the welfare of the Indians, I am the only channel the authorities of the Department should communicate with.

I hope by this to avoid any trouble in the future, as I highly appreciate the support and fair play given to us by the Authorities of the Indian Department.

Yours truly,

A. Watelle

The Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs

Sir,

His Lordship Bishop Pascal has forwarded to me the letter you wrote him on September 24th, about Father Watelle, principal of the Indian School of Delmas. As I am the superior of Father Watelle, his Lordship thought that it was my business to attend to this matter. In fact I had written a few weeks before to the Deputy superintendent general of Indian Affairs about this same school, and I was expecting some communication from the Indian Department, when your letter was forwarded to me. Allow me, Sir, to express frankly and sincerely my surprise at the contents of your letter to Bishop Pascal. The staff of the St. Henry School have done their full duty by the children intrusted to their care. The Department have no word of blame or reproach for the work done by the principal or teachers. They have fulfilled their part of the contract entered into by the Department and the mission, and yet the Department refuse to do their share by paying the grant agreed on by both parties, for work done. Even if the principal was guilty of the conduct imputed to him, the Department could not without injustice withhold the salary of the teachers, and the payment of expenses incurred for the feeding and clothing of the Indian children, and without any proofs, on the word of politicians, you, as head of the Indian Department, assume the responsibility of refusing to pay the grant due the St. Henry School for the last six months, depriving thereby the teachers of their salaries and the traders of the payment due them for the supplies bought for the maintenance of the Indian children. For the last 30 years, I have had to deal with the Indian Department, as principal of Indian schools, or as superintendent of our Indian missions in Alberta and part of Saskatchewan, and I have never seen or heard of anything of the kind. I have fought one your predecessors in the office of superintendent
of Indian Affairs, and I must render this justice to the Honorable Frank Oliver, that although he knew from his men and from me, that I had done my best to defeat him in one of his elections, he had the manliness to acknowledge my right to differ from him, and he never showed that he had the least wish to make my schools suffer for my conduct.

As regards the accusations made against Father Watelle, I am afraid, Sir, that your good faith has been imposed upon, and that you have given credence to tales concocted by a sorry lot of politicians. As a rule we do not meddle with politics, and it is only when the platform of a party or a candidate makes it an obligation for us to speak, that we say what in conscience we are bound to say. Let the party or candidate respect our rights, and none of us will take part in any election but if a party or candidate publishes that one of their aims is the destruction of our schools, our duty is clear and we cannot run away from it. This was the case in the last election in Saskatchewan, and to this platform, must be attributed the crushing defeat of the conservative party in the province. As to the facts in the present case, Father Watelle has not taken any part in any campaign for or against any party. Once in a meeting of his parishioners about church matters, in answer to a question put to him by one of the members, he said that in view of the programs of the two parties, he thought that our schools had a better chance with the liberal party, but he did not even urge his people to vote for the liberal candidate, leaving them absolutely free to vote as they liked. To say that Father Watelle's conduct has destroyed the harmony in the district, is an absolute untruth, but it would be true to say that, if to satisfy the rancor and malice of a very few men whom I shall not name or qualify otherwise, I were to remove him from his school, then indeed there would be anger and disunion, and the end you have in view would be farther removed than ever before.
I hope, Sir, that this true explanation will prove satisfactory to you and that you will give orders that the grant too long due the St. Henry's school be paid at once, and that you will not insist on the removal of the principal of said school. I have greatly at heart to keep friendly relations with the Department, but I cannot sacrifice one of my men to the antipathy of defeated politicians who are trying to make you the instrument of their ill-will and disappointment.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

[Signature]

H. Grandin

Dear Sir,

Allow me to call your attention to my answer to the letter written to Bishop Pascal, by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, about Father Watelle principal of the St. Henry boarding School of Delmas. I cannot believe that the Department will persevere in the line of conduct indicated by the letter of the Honorable Dr. Roche. If we had to change the principal of our schools on the recommendation of dirty politicians, we would never be able to do anything with those schools. There are many defeated candidates in every election, and if these were allowed to take revenge for their defeat on missionaries who may have displeased them in any way, I would have to make changes every time we had an election. As I see it, this would be the best way to kill our schools, and that is exactly what is wanted by the party or parties making accusations against Father Watelle.

Moreover there is in that case a question of justice which cannot be ignored. The full grant has been earned by the staff of the school, and this full grant must be paid, or else the Department keeps money which does not belong to them. I would hate indeed to make trouble and to start a fight with the Department, but, dear Sir, you understand as well as I do, that I cannot allow one of our schools to be robbed of its due, without taking the means to have such a wrong redressed.

Trusting your love of justice, I will wait for your answer, and I remain,

Yours respectfully

I say not that if the whole story of this misfortune was made known to the public, it would give a very strong and sharp weapon against the present administration. I have the honor to be,

Sir, your obedient servant

Ottawa, June 7, 1920.
Memorandum:

Honourable Mr. Meighen,

In December, of last year, Rev. Father Grandin, who has supervision of the Roman Catholic boarding schools in Saskatchewan and Alberta, asked whether, if an addition were built to the Thunderchild's boarding school at Delmas, Sask., the Department would increase the pupilage of the institution. I replied, asking for definite information as to the extent of the proposed enlargement, so that I might know what financial obligation would be involved. I have just received a communication from Father Grandin, submitting a sketch of an addition which would accommodate 40 or more pupils.

The total population of the Battleford agency is 882, of whom 384 are Roman Catholics. Our last census showed a Roman Catholic school pupilage of 157, with 170 children under six years of age. There is only one day school in operation on the agency, on Poundmaker's reserve. A few years ago the Thunderchild and Moosomin bands, near Battleford, surrendered their reserves, which were sold and they moved a number of miles northward to new reserves. On the new Thunderchild reserve no day school has been established. On the new Moosomin reserve we conducted a day school under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church for about four years, but it was unsuccessful, and was closed two years ago. It will thus be seen that a residential school with a capacity of 90 would hardly be sufficient to provide for the needs of the Roman Catholic children of the agency.

The present pupilage of this school is 50, with a per capita grant of $145.00. The additional pupilage
asked for would, therefore, entail an increased annual expenditure of $5,800. We would not be called upon to make any payment before the December quarter, and can arrange for the increase involved from this year's appropriation. Next year, provision for the increase would be made in the Estimates.

I feel that in view of the fact that the Church is willing to undertake the cost of building under existing conditions, and having in mind our proposed compulsory attendance at residential schools, we should accede to Father Grandin's request, and I would submit the matter for your consideration. I have no doubt that they will wish an early decision if they are to proceed with the building this year.

Deputy Superintendent General.

DELMAS BOARDING SCHOOL (Thunderchilds)

This school is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church and is situated on land owned by them in close proximity to the village of Delmas on the Canadian Northern Railway. The building is in three sections 32-36 ft. 3 stories high with full sized basement. It is heated with hot air furnaces. Has running water through the building. Sanitary closets and bath in each dormitory as well as in the basement. Ventilation is provided by two shafts one of which is alongside the furnace chimney. With the new addition which was just about ready for occupation at the time of my visit this school will be able to provide adequate accommodation for at least 90 children. The fire escape is a safe stairway extending from the ground to the upper storey on the outside and access to it is obtained from a door on each flat. This school is provided with modern conveniences with the exception of electric light. The principal informs me that he has in contemplation the purchase of a plant at an early date.

The Rev. Father A. Watelle is in charge as principal and has as his assistants one lay brother and eleven Sisters of Charity. Attached to the same building and under the same management is a separate school for white children.

The Rev. Sisters in charge of the school had originally built the school for the use of white and Indian children. Acting upon repeated requests from Ottawa the Sisters decided to dismiss the white pupils and to make alterations to suit the Indian children. Over $7000.00 were spent last year, the school authorities not doubting a moment that the place of the white children would be taken by the Indians.

The pupilage was increased from 76 to 90 but with space large enough to accommodate 120 children and after having sacrificed the revenue coming from the white children, the Sisters are refused the increase in pupilage to which they are entitled.

The reasons set forth for such refusal were: 1. Lack of milk for all the children. This objection does not exist any more as the Department has provided the school with the necessary number of cows;

2. Lack of farming facilities. That is the principal objection. I regret to note that it is given so much importance and thereby deprive the school of proper revenue and many children of educational advantages. The school authorities are not adverse to developing any farming activity but lacking a suitable farm believe that the Department should supply same.

And then of what weight is that objection in the face of the fact that the school authorities can clothe, board, educate and give proper training to the children confined to their care? Moreover, as the children in Thunderchild are rather young, farming operations would have at least for a time, to be carried on by hired men.

I could suggest that until such time as proper development of farming activities is assured at Thunderchild, the grown up boys of the latter be sent to Duck Lake to train more actively in farming. The Principals of both schools are most willing to cooperate along the lines of that plan at least for a certain time.
The Department is aware that in the reserves adjoining Thunderchild School there are more than the number of children necessary to fill it to its capacity.

I therefore leave the whole matter to your judicious consideration with the hope of a favourable decision.

This school is situated at Delmas, on the Canadian National Railways. I visited this school on March the 15th and when there enquired into the question of land available for cultivation. ANNUAL SCHOOL REPORT.

By S. L. Macdonald, Indian Agent.

SIR:

I have the honor to submit herewith the Annual school report for the Battleford Agency, for the year ending March 31st 1928.

There are four schools operating in this Agency, the Thunderchild Residential School and Day Schools at Red Pheasant, Little Pines and Thunderchild reserves, with an attendance of approximately 190 children.

THUNDERCHILD RESIDENTIAL.

This school is at Delmas on the Main line of the Canadian National Railway and about 15 miles west of Battleford. It is owned and run under the auspices of The Roman Catholic Church, the Principal at present is the Rev Jos Angin O.M.I., who is the most capable Principal we have had there yet; he is assisted by from 12 to 16 Sisters. The Superior, three teaching Sisters, one Nurse and the others take charge of the various duties of the building.

This school has authority for 120 pupils, with 111 attending at the present time.

The old main building is 2 stories and has two three storey wings on the north and south of it; the building is all frame construction and has full basement under it, is heated by six hot air furnaces distributed through the basement.

The Water supply is from the Canadian National railway tank by gravitation; it is now modern with running water all through the building and the Lighting plant installed by the Department during the year has reduced the fire danger by half and a big saving in work for the Sisters. At the present time a reserve pressure tank system is being installed to tide over occasional shut off of the water supply and this will be a further fire protection.

The building itself is more or less run down, the floors are worn through in many places and all is badly in need of paint.

This school does no farming but have about 14 cows for milk supply for the school and the big boys and girls are all taught some dairying.

The health of the children is usually very good; there were two deaths from the school during the year, one from Paritonitis and the other from Heart failure, otherwise the children have been fine and the progress at the school has been very good.

A school garden of about two acres is maintained but does not nearly supply the needs of the school so much of the produce required is purchased from farmers in the district near the school.

Honorable Duncan Scott,
Deputy Chief, General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honorable Sir:

We have just learned through the Rev. Father Beys, Provincial of the Oblate Fathers that he had received a recent communication from the Department in which it was stated that the Inspector had advised them that everything was ready for the opening of a farm at the Thunderchild Residential School.

The stating of this readiness of affairs rather astonishes us inasmuch as at Mr. Morrison's last visit in February this question was not at all discussed. He only emphasized the fact that we needed a new barn as the one we have, having been improperly built, is now only suitable to be used as a hen-coop. The latter being urgently needed.

So far as farming is concerned I beg to openly express my opinion. I am strongly opposed to it for the following reasons:

1st.- We actually have but a tract of land sufficient for the cultivation of potatoes for our own supply, and pasture-land barely large enough for our cattle.

2nd.- We have but a few large boys who are able to work and it is expected that they shall not return after the holidays.

3rd.- The parents have said in the past: "We do not place our children at school to have them work and if they are to make use of them for this purpose we will withdraw them. They might as well work for us as for the school officials."

4th.- We would be compelled to hire outside help and be continually handicapped about the means of raising funds to pay the required salary especially when the crops have failed.

5th.- It is difficult to find competent and trustworthy hired men who will take the interest they ought without being supervised by one of the authorities, and you will readily agree with me that few men will submit to female authority. They act more as proprietors than as caretakers and if one tries to uphold his rights they will feel slighted and not remain in service; thus it is a perpetual change of employees. Furthermore, I do not believe it befits the dignity of a religious to manage a farm.

6th.- We have but one school where this farming business has been introduced, and we are convinced, after having interviewed the staff, that it is a source of all sorts of troubles from which we hope to be exempted.

We do sincerely hope that you will not make this compulsory, as actually, state of affairs at our school is very good and this opening of a farm would but bring on trouble.

It is not our intention to act contrarily to your wishes but trust you will kindly take the matter into consideration and make known to us your decision which will be that this question has been settled by your agreement with us. This is the reply we anticipate and thank you for same.

Trusting that the frank way in which I have expressed my opinion will not cause our mutual good relations to cease to exist, and with apologies for same I remain,

Yours very truly,

Acting Principal.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 19th inst. re. the establishment of a farm in the Thunderchild School.

You are undoubtedly aware of a double difficulty we have to cope with in the present case:

1st. By special arrangement of our bishops, in the early days the Sisters had the full management of the schools. Little by little this has been changed in most schools but still prevails in the schools of Delmas, Onion Lake and Robbema. I am writing immediately however, trying to remedy the situation.

2nd. The other difficulty is a financial one. In other schools, as in the Blood and Piegan reserves, the Department has provided for the most essential requisites to run the farm; but to make of it a real success, we have been obliged to provide ourselves very important items, such as tractor, wheat separator, crushers for grain and even buildings for married employees. We are not in a position to make such expenses at the present time, should similar needs be felt in the running of a farm at the Thunderchild school.

We shall however do our utmost to overcome even this second difficulty and follow the instructions of the Department in regard to the running of an educational farm.

Dear Sir:

Do you think that arrangements could be made with the Department to grant the children two months summer holidays, say, from June 27th. to August 27th.?

In compensation, all would be willing to do away with the two weeks' holidays at Christmas, and the one week at Easter, as granted by the Register.

The children being compelled to remain here at Christmas, do not enjoy their vacation, the cold being too intense for much outdoor sports. Moreover, very few of the children are exact in making their entry at Mid-August, the majority of them come back only in September, modelling themselves on the Public School children.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo in regard to the new R.C. Boarding School near Thunderchild's Reserve, and to enclose the specifications, original and translation, a plan of the building and a photograph of same. I have been unable to procure receipts for the material and labour. As the Mechanic's Lien Ordinance of the N.W.T. Cap.59,a.3., is rather strict there might be some danger in handing over the cheque as, if the material and labour have not been paid for, the persons concerned have a lien on the building. However the building has been handed over by the Contractor (see Indian Agent's letter enclosed) and probably there will be no trouble.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Aug. 17th, 1901.

Ref: Letter Aug. 7, 1901, No. 122/65.

Sir,

I have the honour to state that on receipt of your above quoted letter I immediately communicated your instructions to Mr. Pomerleau, who is now in Edmonton, and enclose herewith his reply.

I may say that Mr. Pomerleau erected and completed this building in a very satisfactory manner and handed it over for School use some time ago.

The material and workmanship are first class in every particular. I have requested the Rev. Principal to forward the plan and specifications to you, and I expect you will receive them by the following mail.

I have twice been over this school, but will if you wish make another special visit and report on the subject.

I am certifying to the vouchers and returning them herewith, and I trust that they will be favourably recommended by you for payment, as Mr. Pomerleau has faithfully carried out his part of the contract, and as he said, before leaving for Edmonton, he is not a rich man, and the delay in receiving payment for his contract has put him in a very serious and awkward position.

I have the honour, &c.

(Sgd) J.P.G. Day.

Indian Agent.

Foundation.
To be in stone - 1½ ft. width by 15 in. height, with an inside wall across. To be made according to plan.

Beams.
6 x 8 ft. of spruce - 1st quality.

Air Holes.
Two air holes in stone wall, with frames 2 in. thick, 10 in. wide, 12 in. high, with two 5/8 in. iron bars, in the frame, to be placed according to instructions, the frames to be placed and adjusted.

Frame Work.
To be very solid. Scantlings 2 x 4, 16 inches between length, 16 ft. for the square of the building. Beams 2x10 in. 16 inches between and of sufficient length, same for both floors and strengthened by St. Andrews Crosses, well nailed, to make solid. Scantlings for inside partitions, 2 x 4. To bind scantlings with pieces of wood, the size as indicated on verso of plan. The roof plates to be doubled and 2 x 4, cut joints not less than eight feet, in order to be solid. Gables: scantlings 2 x 4 and 2 x 6. Roof supporting planks, 1 x 6, well nailed; a five inch moulding near the roof. A 15 in. cornice according to plan, with frieze and 3 in. moulding.

Ceiling.
Shiplap, with paper, well nailed - 2 nails by the board to each scantling, clapboard over. Roof of boards, tar paper and shingles 4½ in. to the weather and well nailed.

Floors.
Double, both stories. 1st floor, boards whitened on one side. 2nd.
2nd floor, spruce boards 1 x 4, break the joints, plough and tongue, well nailed to the rafters, with 2½ in. nails. Nails for ceiling, 3 in., and for the heavy timber work, 4 in. Supports of beams 1 x 4, incased 1 in. in scantlings.

Partitions and Walls.
Upright joists - two coats of plaster, one rough cast and one smooth - hair in mortar in sufficient quantity to make it solid. Two stove pipe holes of iron in the partitions. Mortar to be prepared at least 15 days before using.

Wainscoting.
Skirting, 8 in. with moulding, around each room, 3 in. moulding next to ceiling around each room - kitchen to be wainscotted on wall, 3 ft. high.

Ceilings.
Ceiling 1 x 4 - Every room on all floors.

Staircases.
Steps to be made of fir, 2 in. thick, 10 in. wide - Height of step, 6 in. - one single board for each step - plank between, solid 2 x 10. Balusters, 1½ in. turned - with post at stairhead, turned at lower end. Hand-rail in moulding. There should be an enclosure around opening of staircase in dormitory, i.e. frame covered with oil-cloth or heavy cotton painted same as doors. Staircase to be wainscotted 3 ft. high on wall side.

Chimneys.
Two chimneys - good bricks - size 17 x 17 in. - beginning on first story - 4 ft. from ceiling and to have necessary height over roof to give satisfaction. A stove pipe hole on each side of chimney on 1st. and 2nd. stories and one stove pipe hole on each floor in kitchen chimney. A cleansing drawer at lower end of each chimney, galvanized iron, 4 in. high. Each chimney to be supported by stone work down to level of first floor.
One iron ventilating opening through each chimney in all the rooms the chimneys pass through on first floor (3).

Windows.

15 windows (guillotine), 14x28 - 5 windows (do) 12 x 24.
Oakum in sufficient quantity to stop the chinks of windows and doors.

Doors.

3 outside doors - 3x7, 2 in. thick, knobs, solid hinges and locks - 4 inside doors, 2.8x6.8, knobs, hinges and locks - 4 doors, ceiling, knobs, hinges and locks.

Closets.

Behind the building - about 50 or 60 ft. away - 8 x 6 ft. in three compartments with partitions to separate boys and girls compartments; two small windows (4 glasses each) in front and door at each end of passage.

Ventilation.

A large eolian ventilator on the roof with aspirating openings of perforated iron in each dormitory.

Cellar.

10 x 16 ft. and 7 ft. high, under kitchen, boarded all round with 1 in. lumber and scantlings every two feet. One staircase. Air hole to lead to cellar. Beams 4 x 4. Floor of one inch boards. Rafters 2 x 4, every two feet, well nailed. Two double cellar doors with ironings on the inside.

Sink.

Cast iron, in kitchen - and accessories.

It is agreed that this building, 36x28, will be erected at a cost of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.) according to the plans and specifications, on the Thunderchild Mission property. Work to begin as soon as the river is navigable - the building to be completed by the end of July 1901.

Une maçonnerie en pierre de 1/2 pied de largeur sur 15 pouces de hauteur, une traverse de maçonnerie intérieure à part l'entourage. Le mur de refend fait suivant le plan.

Sols.

Des sols de 6 x 8 en épinette, première qualité.

Sous-sol.

Un soutirage dans le mur de pierre, avec cadre de 2 pieds d'épaisseur et 10 pieds de largeur, 12 pieds de hauteur, avec 2 barres de fer de 3 lignes fixées dans le cadre, suivant les instructions qui seront données pour la place, avec châssis posé et ajusté.

Marche.

Une charpente très solide. Scantlings 2 x 4 posés de 16 pieds entre en centre pour recevoir la latté, longueur des scantlings pour carré 16 pieds. Soliveaux de 2 x 10 basés de 16 pieds entre en centre, longueur nécessaire, les deux planchers avec les mêmes solives de soliveaux, posés avec du cèdre de St-André, placés de manière à ce que ce soit solide, bien cloués. Les scantlings pour les divisions de chaque étage 2 x 4. Fixer les scantlings avec la même grosseur de bois qu'il y a pour les murs, comme indiqué sur l'œuvre du plan. La sablière de la butte doit être double 2 x 4, joints coups au moins de 5 pieds de manière à ce que ce soit solide. Le cornichon avec scantlings 2 x 4 et 2 x 6. Les affûts du toit bien cloués; une moulure de 3 pieds près du toit. Une carrosserie de 13 pieds suivant le plan, avec frise et une moulure de 3 pieds.

Lambris.

Les lambris en shiplaps, avec hafnir, bien cloués, clous pas de scantling, chaque planche, etabord posée sur le lambris. Couverture en planches, hafnir goudronné et bardaune de bois 4 ½ pouces d'échantillons, triple cloués.

Planchers.

Les planchers du deuxième étage devront être doubles, le 1er plancher avec des planches blanchies sur un côté et le 2ème plancher avec des planches d'épinette 1 ¼ à joints de bois, de bois de hêtre ou tous les solivages.
pour lambris de 3 pes et pour la charpente de la bâtisse, clôture de 4 pes. Supporte des solives de 1x4, encastrées de 1 pes dans les murs.

Divisions & murs.

Toutes les divisions et tous les murs en colombage, deux conduites de cuivre, le dernier conduit à glace, du plafond dans le mortier en quantité suffisante pour rendre le mur solide. 2 trous de tuyau en fer dans les murs de séparation. Le mortier devra être fait au moins quinze jours d'avance.

Boiseries.

Une boiserie de 8 pes avec une moulure autour de chaque appartement, au-dessus du plancher; une moulure de 5 pes, fixée au plafond, autour de chaque appartement. La cuisine aura une sur le mur à la hauteur de 3 pes.

Plafonds.

Les plafonds en cèdre 1x4, dans tous les étages et tous les appartements.

Escaliers.

Les marches de l'escalier devront être faites avec du maillot fin de 2 pes et épaisseur sur 1/2 pes de largeur, hauteur sur chaque marche 6 pes. Des marches et une seule pièce de bois ordinaire, solides 2x10, barreaux 1/2 tournés, avec un tournis dans le bas, un en haut. Le bras de l'escalier en moulure. Dans le dortoir, il devra y avoir une ouverture de l'ouverture de l'escalier. Une porte légère de l'ouverture de l'escalier (c'est-à-dire un cadre de bois) ou de gros côtés peints de la couleur du plafond, sur le mur à la hauteur de 3 pes.

Cheminées.

2 cheminées en bonnes briques de 17 pes x 17 pes. Elles seront du 1er étage à 4 pes du plafond et elles devront être hautes nécessaire au dessus du toit, pour bien fumer. Un trou de tuyau chaque côté de la cheminée dans le 1er étage, le 2nd étage de la bâtisse et un trou de tuyau dans le 3rd étage, dans la cheminée de la cuisine. Un tuyau de cuivre de 1/2 pes de diamètre.
chaque cheminée devra avoir un filtre en pierre jusqu'au
debas pour la ventilation. Une bouchée de ventilation en
place chaque cheminée et chaque appartement ou pas de
ventilation en bas.

Châssis.
13 châssis à l'anglaise 17 x 28. 5 châssis à l'anglaise 17
Il faudra de l'étoupe en quantité suffisante pour bien caler
l'entourage des châssis et des portes.

Portes.
3 portes extérieures 3 x 7, 2 portes d'entrée, poignées et ponts
solièges, serrure.
4 portes intérieures 2 x 6, une poignée, ponture et serrure.
4 portes en vitrage avec poignées, pontures et serrures.

Closets.
En arrière de la bâtisse, à la distance de 30 à 60 pds., deux
de 8 x 6 pds., divisés en trois compartiments, avec cloisons ag-
nitré au petit châssis vers le tiroir pour séparer les écoles
des garçons de ceux des filles, 2 petits châssis en avant
chaque et une porte chaque bout du passage.

Ventilateur.
Un gros ventilateur collé sur le toit, avec une bouchée
de fil parfumé dans le plafond de chaque dortoir.

Cave.
Une cave de 12 x 16 pds. sur 7 pds. de haut, sous
cuisine, boisé tout autour avec planches de 1 pds. de haut,
à tous les deux puits. Un escalier. Faute de mur de
sur la cave. Toit de 4 x 4, plancher avec planches de
2 x 4 placées à tous les deux puits, bien clos. 2 pds.
joints, avec fermeture en étain.

Salle.
Un sink en fonte dans la cuisine, securi-
ctionner.

Delmas, Sask.,
May 6th, 1949.

Honourable Duncan Scott,
Deputy Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

We beg to acknowledge receipt of the cheque for $5000.00 which you kindly sent to the needy staff of the Thunderchild Residential School.

It by far, surpassed our expectations though we might, judging after your recent liberality in our behalf, suspected that a like surprise was in store for us.

Our gratitude can more easily be felt than expressed, therefore we will not attempt the impossible task of interpreting in words our feelings.

Should circumstances favor us by leading you one day to revisit our school be assured of a hearty welcome. In the meantime, we would be exceedingly pleased to receive a copy of the photograph of Mrs. Scott and yourself taken when you were here. Delightful reminiscences of this pleasant visit are engraved in the minds of those who were here at that time, but for those less fortunate who had not the pleasure of making your acquaintance, with the knowledge of your qualifications which we have already imparted to them it would enable them to know better the generous benefactor to whom they, as well as we, are so greatly indebted.

Thanking you again for the cheque and for your unforgettable favors of last August, the long list of which is headed by: "Your delightful visit", we remain

Very sincerely yours,

The Sisters of the Assumption of the B. V.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter #302-114 Gen. re Voucher No. 64 for the well at the Thunderchild Day School.

The above information should have gone in with the voucher, but was omitted in the rush of work.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that the work of enlarging the class-room and making porch for convalescents is entirely completed and we now realize the fact that it had not been estimated high enough. It had been estimated at $750.00 but when it was done the expense ran up to $900. I am aware that the Department had not agreed to give more than $750 towards this work and do not expect that they will; however, I am confident enough to make appeal to them again in this instance, and if, after kindly taking the matter into consideration, a sympathetic turn is taken towards us and the balance covered by them we shall be very thankful.

With hearty thanks for the recent favor of the extension of the class-room and porch for convalescents as well as for all past favors received from the Department, I remain

Yours very sincerely,

Sister St. Simon

Sir:

A request of the Rev. Principal of the Thunderchild Indian Residential School, that he be supplied with laundry machinery, etc., has been received by the Department. I am not sure that funds can be provided next year for this purpose, as the Department contemplates heavy expenditure at this institution in connection with the commencing of farming training. It is proposed to ask Parliament for funds for a new barn, for some work horses and for agricultural implements.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford,
Sask.
I visited this school on the forenoon of the 8th instant, and inspected the building throughout.

I visited

THUNDERCHILD R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

I visited the three classrooms and noted that the children presented a clean and healthy appearance. There were 80 pupils present out of an enrolment of 97. A number of the pupils from the outlying reserves had not returned since the holidays. A few were permitted to be absent to assist their parents at hay making, but I directed the Agent to take steps to have the absentees returned to the school without delay.

The building presented a very clean and tidy appearance inside and out.

The Sisters directed my attention to the lack of laundry equipment. They have not been provided with a power washing machine extractor or dryer. Should the Department see fit to provide this equipment, it will be necessary to also provide a larger engine. They have at present a Delco lighting plant which they claim is not strong enough for the load that is necessary to light this large school.

I was also informed that it is the intention to commence operating a farm in connection with the school next year. This will mean that an enlargement of their stabling accommodation will be necessary.

A large garden was planted last year, but they got very little return from it. Only 312 bushels of potatoes, and they are now purchasing the roots and vegetables necessary for their requirements.
Sir:—

I am enclosing herewith Inspector Murison's report on the various schools in the Battleford Agency.

Personally, I do not think it would be wise to send the boy, Adam Cuthand to a place where he would receive a higher education, with a view of his taking up missionary work. Our experience in the past has been that the educating of Indians for missionary work did not prove very successful.

You will note that the Sisters at the Thunderchild Indian Residential School are asking for additional laundry equipment. This school has had a lot of money spent on it in the past two years in the way of grants from the Department, and as they are not doing anything towards teaching the boys to become farmers, or to milk cows, etc. I do not know that they should be granted much more.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

INSPECTOR HAMILTON'S REPORT ON SCHOOLS - BATTLEFORD AGENCY

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools of the Battleford Agency, inspected while there during the month of September.

Delmas Indian Residential School:

The class-room work is divided into three rooms, each under the supervision of a Sister. The senior room has twenty-five pupils, four in Grade 6, and twenty-five in Grade 7. The junior room has Grade 2, with twelve pupils, Grade 3, with six pupils, and Grade 4, with ten pupils, totalling twenty-eight pupils. The primary room accommodates the little ones with twenty-seven on the roll. The children had only been back from holidays a short time, but all appeared strong and healthy. They were neatly dressed and clean. The Sisters in charge of the class-room work appeared capable, and, I believe, progress is made. The rooms were all well aired and tidy.

The dormitories were clean and all the beds were neatly made, with good bedding. The children all have night robes to sleep in, and the rooms have plenty of light and air. The toilets were spotlessly clean and all in working order.

The kitchen, sewing room, and laundry, I found to be in splendid condition and scarcely a spot of dust could be found. The departments are all under the supervision of a Sister and excellent work is done.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
This school is a frame building, and in many respects unhandy; but it is one of the best kept schools I have been privileged to visit. The place throughout was clean and tidy and the children were happy and apparently contented.

One boy and a girl were sick at the time of my visit, but both were receiving the best of care. In the case of the girl, typhoid fever was suspected, and she was being carefully watched both by the Sister and Doctor.

A new barn is now under construction. The lumber used is all No. 1 fir and the dimension all 2 x 6. This barn should be thoroughly satisfactory and is certainly badly needed.

The old log building used for a chicken house is ready to fall down. A new up-to-date building should be supplied. At present they have about two hundred hens, and this work is supervised by a Sister. I believe a real success is made in this line of work, and it is one which will be of great benefit to the boys and girls in later life. I think every encouragement should be given to this line of work.

The fire protection consists of extinguishers placed at convenient places throughout the building, and a water supply is always available. The fire hose are good and I found all fire escapes in excellent condition.

The yards are large and I found them tidy and well kept. Swings and teeters are provided both for the boys and girls.

At present twelve cows are kept, but it is hoped to gradually increase this number. The extra barn room will enable the Reverend Principal to keep more stock, from which the children will benefit. Pigs are also kept,
and are butchered for home consumption.

I was greatly pleased with the lay out of this school and I believe it is under excellent management.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Sir,

I have to advise you as follows.

On the night of Dec 1st about 8 o'clock, I received a phone message from the Thunderchild Boarding School to the effect that all the girls in the dormitory were ill, some vomiting and others fainting and that there was a strong odour of gas. I immediately proceeded to the school, taking along a tank of oxygen and a mechanic. On arrival I found all but a few fully recovered. The oxygen proved beneficial to those who were still under the influence, and I was able to return after being there about an hour. The Sisters were to advise me in the morning if any of the children showed any bad effects. As no phone call came in I concluded that everything was all right.

The cause of the trouble was a crack in the exhaust pipe of the gasoline engine which generates their electric light and which is left running for about one hour each evening. The man in charge was aware of the defect and left the basement window open advising one of the sisters to leave the window open until the engine was shut off. One of the sisters not being aware of the instructions, happening along, saw the window open and closed it, with the result that the fumes were forced up to the recreation room and dormitory in that section of the school.

Statement regarding the Water-Supply Question at the Thunderchild Residential School,
Delmas, Sask.

The Thunderchild Residential School was founded in 1905.

From 1905-1915 water was supplied from a well of 3 feet diameter & 28 feet deep, situated at proximity of the school. Although there were neither bath-rooms nor water toilets in the house this well was far from furnishing the quantity of water needed; to remedy this the best we could, barrels were placed here and there in the house: kitchen, dining-rooms, and dormitories and were filled as water rose in the well. This water was never good and sometimes undrinkable.

In 1915 the school Officials made arrangements with the Canadian National Railway Company, which providing ready money, furnished, since that date, the necessary water.

On the first of May last, the C.N.R. dismissed its Pumping-man and notified us that we would have to provide water for ourselves as it was closing the Delmas tank; agreeing however to loan us the Pumping Plant that we would operate at our own cost plus a monthly rent, till we could find another way of providing our water supply. We were obliged to accept this agreement, but the expenses it incurs are beyond our means and as the water question is a vital question and very important for the pupils' health, we hope the Department will kindly come to our help to allow us to meet these present difficulties. The cost of running the pump at the present time is an expense of seventy-one dollars $71.00 monthly.

As is shown by the monthly statements paid out to the C.N.R., since 1915, the school consumes an average of 2000 gallons of water daily, and after a thorough study of the question, particularly through experiments made on different surface water wells around the school and in the town of Delmas, we sincerely believe the surest, the most steadfast and after all the most economical way to provide us of this daily supply of water is to install a Modern Water Supply System which to the best of our knowledge and experience could be summed up to the following estimates.

Co. dismissed its Pumping-man and notified us that we would have to provide for ourselves as the tank at Delmas would be closed; however they agreed to loan us the Pumping-Plant if we would operate it at our own cost plus a monthly rent. We were obliged to accept this agreement but the expenses that it incurs are beyond our means and as the water question is a vital question and very important for the children's health and safety, we hope the Department will kindly come to our help to allow us to meet the present difficulties. The cost of running the pump at the present time is an expense of $71.00 monthly.

As is shown by the monthly statements paid out to the C.N.R. since 1915, the school consumes an average of 2000 gals. of water daily and after a thorough study of the question particularly through experiments made on different surface water wells around the school and in the town of Delmas, we sincerely believe the surest, the most steadfast and after all the most economical to provide us for this daily supply of water is to install a modern water supply system which to the best of our knowledge and experience could be summed up to the following estimates.

Of course, dear Mr. Agent, this statement is just to give you an idea of the situation. If yourself or the Department have a better way to solve the difficulties we would be only too glad to adopt it.

REPORT
ON
PROPOSED WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM
FOR
THUNDERCHILD INDIAN SCHOOL, DELMAS, SASKATCHEWAN,

by
P. A. Fetterly, B.Sc.,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report

Instructions were received from the Director, dated January 5, 1934, to prepare a report on a proposed water supply pressure system for Thunderchild Indian (R.C.) School at Delmas, Sask.

An inspection was made by P.A. Fetterly of this staff on January 11. A consultation was also held with Mr. S.L. MacDonald, Indian Agent at Battleford, on the matter at the same time.

2. Necessity for a New Water Supply.

This school was founded in 1905. From that time to 1916 the water supply was of a primitive nature. In 1916 the Canadian National Railway agreed to supply water through an extra pipe from their tank at Delmas. Water was pumped from the North Saskatchewan river, one mile to the north, and 250 ft. below rail level, to the tank. A pipe was laid from the tank to the school, one-half mile.

Recently, the Railway discontinued the use of their tank for Railway purposes, but agreed to rent the plant to the school. The cost to the school is over $70 per month for wages and maintenance. In addition to
the excessive cost, the water coming directly from the river, and lying in the tank, is naturally not very pure. The present arrangement, therefore, is far from satisfactory.

3. Location of Water Supply System

The system must be placed in an outside basement similar to that in which the Delco Light System is housed further along the building as there is no room in the present basement. The north and south sides of the building are very irregular in outline since the buildings which contain the school are of different sizes, although under an irregularly connected roof, additions having been made at various times.

The plumbing system in the building is complete. The source of supply, only, is to be altered.

4. Proposed Scheme

The general proposal, as suggested by Rev. Father Allard, and agreed to by this office, consists of an extension to the basement somewhat similar to that at Duck Lake School and also to the Delco Light basement at Thunderchild School. This basement is to be placed in an alcove on the west side of the building, and will be 30 ft. north and south against the present well and parallel to the length of the school. The north side of the alcove is 8' long and the south side 15 feet. The basement should be "squared" to a width of 15 feet. In addition a small alcove north of this space, and
between it and an entry can be used for the pump and windmill. The superficial area of the new basement would be 30 ft. by 15 ft. with an added area 8 ft. square on the north west corner. The west side will therefore be 38 feet long.

In the main portion will be placed two 48" pressure tanks, parallel to each other and lying north and south. The well, pump jack and gasoline engine will be suitably located in the north-western portion of the basement. A ten foot windmill will be erected on a 40 foot steel tower directly over the well. Three of the legs of the windmill (8 ft. apart) would be on solid ground. The south-eastern leg would be on a concrete post. This windmill is to be used as auxiliary power.

It might be mentioned that the basement wall on the east side of the alcove is only 18" deep. The south side, 15 ft. long is also only 18" deep. Only the north side, 8' wide, is 8 feet deep.

The pressure system will be connected directly with the plumbing system already installed. The main feed pipe is 10 feet east of the alcove wall, under the building.

5. Water Requirements for School

Father Allard stated that 120 persons of all grades inhabit the school. It was ascertained that St. Barnabas (C of E) School at Onion Lake, Sask., used 20 gallons per capita during last summer's holidays, and
was measured by meter. The usual amount considered is 30 gallons. In this report 30 gallons will be used as an average. The average requirements would then be 3600 gallons. Father Allard stated that he would be satisfied if the pump activated for 12 hours or even more. The pumping capacity would then need to be about 300 gallons per hour. The amount of water needed depends upon the care and economy with which it is used. The farm stock should be supplied from shallow wells now in existence.

Incidently, most schools appear to pump their water in from 6 to 8 hours.

6. Details of Construction

(a) Wells.

Water is not economically available from the Saskatchewan river because of the distance, difference in levels, possible impurity of the source and cost of maintenance. No springs being known in the vicinity, the only available source will consist of wells.

Several shallow wells, about 20 to 30 feet deep have been sunk in the vicinity, one being within 30 feet of the proposed basement. This well is 28 feet deep and 3 feet in diameter. The water is 2' deep and can be pumped out in a short time, yielding only about 75 gallons at one pumping. Even two or three shallow wells would not be sufficient because of the paucity of water and uncertainty of supply. Two other similar wells, at least, exist within a few hundred feet nearer the
river. A well 64 feet deep was sunk in the centre of the village of Delmas a few hundred feet to the west of the school for public purposes. This is said to contain the best water in the general vicinity. A sample of water from this well was obtained. An analysis will be made of this shortly by Calgary City Chemist.

Another well was drilled to a depth of 300 feet, four or five miles to the southeast and about 1½ miles south of the river, some time ago. This well yields a good flow of water. A well driller named Garrett, was evidently consulted by Father Allard, Principal, when preparing his original report and estimates (a copy of which was sent to the Indian Department). Mr. Garrett stated that he could guarantee a well with a flow of 250 gallons per hour. Mr. Garrett evidently believes that he can obtain a good flow at 250 or 300 feet, which is about the level of the river.

Considering the total available evidence, a deep well would appear to be the best source for water.

This well should be drilled in the north-west corner of the proposed basement and should be completed before any other work is done in order to insure that water will be available in sufficient volume.

(b) Basement.

This will be constructed of reinforced concrete. It is suggested that the west wall be constructed of brick to facilitate possible removal of the tanks if this be ever found necessary. This suggestion is open to
correction. It will be 8 feet deep to correspond with the existing basement to the northeast. The present wall on the east, 30 feet long, is only 18" deep and will have to be removed. No basement exists on the east and south sides. The south wall, 15 feet long, is also only 18" deep and will be treated similarly. The north wall, for the east 8' is 8' deep, and need not be disturbed. A door will be constructed to this basement. The west wall, 38 feet long and the west portion of the north wall will be of new construction.

The floor will be at the same level as that of the main basement, and the ceiling will be at the same level as the top of the basement containing the Delco Light system. This is a few inches above the ground.

In order to connect the ceiling of the basement with the existing walls it will be necessary to remove the sills or lower the walls. Of course, the west and south walls can be removed entirely as they are only 18" deep.

It will be noted that when the tanks, engine, etc., are placed in the room they can never be replaced without a certain amount of demolition.

The basement will be heated from the school. Two windows can be placed high on the west side and a door constructed at the north-east angle to allow communication with the present basement.

(c) Gasoline Engine

The power for pumping will be supplied by
a three-horse-power gasoline engine as an auxiliary power when a windmill cannot be used. The electrical energy at present in use in the school is supplied by a Delco Light system, consequently no electrical power is available for other uses.

(d) Pump-jack

The well will be cased for the whole length with 5-5/8 inch casing. A 3" pipe will contain the 1-3/8" octagonal rods and the 2-3/4" working cylinder. A pump jack will be placed over the well in the basement. It will be connected to the engine. The usual deep well pump with a motor cannot be used because of absence of electrical power. Simple means will be provided for transfer of connections from engine to windmill.

(e) Pressure Tanks

Two 48" tanks, 24 ft. long, lying parallel, and on concrete cradles, will occupy a large portion of the space. These tanks will consist of 5/16" material with 1/4 inch heads, dished outwards, with manhole and accessories such as pressure gauge, water gauges, etc., and will conform to the Saskatchewan Boiler Act.

(f) Windmill

This is to be used as auxiliary power whenever wind power is available. It will consist of a 10 foot wheel mounted on a 40 ft. steel tower. The matter of whether this wheel will lift the water 250 to 300 ft. (the estimated depth of the well) under pressure has not as yet been fully discussed.
7. The Time Element

The letter received from the Director stated that it was desirable to have the work finished by March 31st in order to take advantage of the existing appropriation of $2500, and also as to the effect of winter conditions on carrying on the work. It is understood that if the work cannot be finished before March 31st., then the vote will lapse.

It is undoubtedly unwise to attempt this work during frozen conditions. The physical labour, and the costs are excessive when excavating through 6 feet or more of frozen ground and when pouring concrete. It was learned during construction at Sacred Heart School and St. Barnabas School that both costs and difficulties increase enormously under these conditions. In these cases work had to be postponed, and renewed in May.

However, if it must be done before that date or not at all, in order to obtain the appropriation, then the only alternative is to complete the work. In that case allowance will have to be made for excess cost.

8. Costs

Plans and estimates are being prepared and will be sent very shortly. Meanwhile it was thought best to prepare this portion of the report for the immediate use of the Indian Department.

9. Recommendation.
It is recommended that the work be proceeded with because of the urgency. The time of completion is left with the Indian Department considering paragraph 7. This office will be prepared to undertake supervision. The total time occupied would be about one month particularly if all of the material were on the site before construction began.
