General

The material supplied, and the work done, in connection with the construction of the proposed water supply system are to be to the satisfaction of the Engineer-in-Charge, Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, Calgary, Alberta. Only material of the best quality is to be used and workmanship is to be also of the best quality.

Location

The School is situated in the town of Delmas, Saskatchewan, about 1/2 mile from the Canadian National Railway Station and siding. No difficulties will be met in freighting.

Nature of Works

The works consist of the drilling of a deep well, and the construction of a basement contiguous to Thunderchild Indian School, in accordance with plan supplied. This basement will contain pneumatic tanks, engine, and pump-jack. A windmill will be constructed over the well for auxiliary power. The new pressure system will be connected with the present gravity system from the Railway Tank, a two-inch pipe from which runs under the building 10 feet east of the wall.

(a) Excavation.

The area will be excavated sufficiently
larger than the size of basement indicated on the plan to allow for construction of forms. The excavation of the cellar to the east of the proposed site does not enter into this contract.

The present concrete platform will be removed and the portion of the present wall which is 18" deep will be removed or shored up, for deepening to 8'.

(b) Well.

The well shall be drilled before any other work is done. Water will be obtained in sufficient quantities to produce at least 300 gallons per hour and 3600 gallons per day. It will probably be 250' to 300' deep. The hole will be straight and the casing properly placed. The casing, plugged and reamed piping and rods will be of good material of approved manufacture. It will be located as shown on the plan.

A log of the well shall be kept in order to ascertain the geological structure.

(c) Concrete.

The concrete comprising of the basement and saddles shall consist of clean screened gravel, clean sand with the addition of Portland Cement in the proportions of one part cement, three parts sand and five parts gravel, except the top slab of the basement and the saddles which will consist of one, two and four parts respectively. One inch
of grout shall be placed between tanks and saddles.

The ends of the reinforcing rods should be wired where feasible, and should not protrude.

The finished work shall be trowelled smoothly. The floor should be capable of draining to the N.E. corner and thence to the main drains of the building.

(d) Gasoline Engine.

The engine shall be capable of producing 3 horse power and shall be of approved make. It shall be set in proper relation to the pump jack and rods.

(e) Pump Jack.

The pump jack shall be of approved make and shall be capable of sustaining the load of pumping 300 gallons per hour against a head of 300 feet (probable depth of well) and a pressure of 60 lbs. per sq.inch.

(f) Tanks

The two tanks shall be 4' diameter and 24 feet long. These will be laid horizontally and parallel to each other and to the north side of the building, on three concrete saddles. They shall be made of five-six-tenths inch shell material, with three-eights-inch heads, 100 lbs. working pressure, tested to 150 lbs. Ends of the tanks to be dished outwards. A manhole sized according to Saskatchewan Boiler Act rules shall be placed at the rear end of
each tank.

Drain plug at the bottom, front end.

Two water gauges on each (half-way each), complete with cut-off valves and blow-down cock.

One piece of zinc 6" x 6" x 2" for each tank to prevent electrolysis (not rivetted to tank).

All connections including screwed brass pipe, gate valves, etc., to connect with existing system 10 feet east of the proposed basement.

One 1/2" connection on each tank for air pressure; also a pressure gauge to be provided.

Necessary connections to be made between pump and tanks, also between tanks and existing supply system. All necessary connections and accessories to be provided in proper lengths and sizes.

Connections to be so arranged that tanks can be used independently if needed.

Tanks, engine, etc., to be placed before basement is finished.

Outside of tanks to be painted with Dr. Smith's Solution.

(e) Windmill.

The windmill shall be of approved make to lift the water from a 2-3/4" working barrel 300 feet deep into tanks under pressure of 60 lbs. per square inch. Estimates are to the effect that a 12 foot windmill on a 40 foot steel tower will produce 1 horse power in a 15 mile wind.
(h) All necessary connections, such as valves, pipe in proper lengths and sizes will be provided by the tenderer. Such connections are to be provided so that changes may be made on rods from windmill to pump jack and vice versa.

All work is to be performed in a thorough and substantial manner and to the approval of the Engineer-In-Charge, Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, Department of the Interior, Calgary, Alberta.

Addendum Report

on

Proposed Water Supply

at

Thunderchild Indian School

Delmas, Saskatchewan,

BY

P.A. Fetterly,
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report

A preliminary report was prepared on January 23rd, 1934, on this subject. Since that date the plans and estimates have been prepared.

In view of the statement of the Secretary of the Indian Department to the effect that only $2500 has been appropriated for this work, it is considered advisable to state all details in connection with the estimates instead of the usual method. This is done in order that criticism may be made with all facts in evidence, so that, if the Indian Department wish to change the sizes to smaller dimensions, the designed details may be known.

2. Details of Estimates.

(a) Concrete and Brickwork.

The floor is designed to be 6" in depth, walls 10" and the roof slab 8". The latter
is 16 feet wide and 30' to 38' long. These dimensions necessitate an 8" thickness for roof, with reinforcement 5" and 18" apart respectively. This roof will be occupied, as a door enters the building above the present concrete platform; but no vehicles or horses should ever be on it. Father Allard expects at some future time to erect a building over this area.

The three tank saddles are 1' wide and are sunk 2' into the earth to hold the tanks. This extra 2' is possibly open to criticism but the bearing weight certainly should not all be on the floor.

The floor itself should be levelled and prepared so that it will drain to the north-east corner and thence to the main drains of the building. The land in general drains rapidly to the North-west, toward the river.

The brickwork is placed at such a point so that if it be ever found necessary to replace the tanks, this can be done with a minimum of demolition.

Windows are provided in the west wall for light and ventilation. Openings are provided in the east wall for entrance of heat from the adjacent heating pipes.

A door is provided in the north-east corner for ingress and ventilation.
(b) **Excavation**

This will be somewhat larger than the size of the basement to make room for forms. The price 75¢ per yard, is certainly not excessive as the total amount to be moved is not large.

Father Allard wishes to excavate a basement to the east of the proposed basement, to be paid for by the School. He estimates that 80 cu.yds. of earth will be moved. This would have to be done while the other excavation is proceeding.

(c) **Well**

The estimated depth is 300 feet. Father Allard estimated 250 to 300' but estimated prices on 250'. It is obviously impossible to estimate the depth to which one must drill to obtain an adequate amount of water. The price of casing, pipe, rods, and the horse power of the engine depend on this depth. The 50 feet possible extra depth will make a difference in total cost. No person, even a driller, ever estimates closely the depth, to which he will go, and rightly so. Drilling is estimated at 1.75 per foot. This should cover contract price.

The well should be under the windmill although an apparatus is available for transfer of power from a windmill at a distance. It consists of a double lever with cross wires.

(d) **Gasoline Engine.**

The power required to lift water 300 feet against a pressure of 60 lbs. (in the tanks),
including friction, is found as follows:

Power required = Gal. per minute x height

1980

= 5 x (300 ft. / 60 x 2)

1980

= 1.1 horse power.

A 1½ horse power engine costs $92.00, while a 3 h.p. engine costs $144.00. Two h.p. engines are not listed. It was considered by all means advisable to purchase a 3 h.p. in order to have some surplus power.

(e) Pump Jack.

The power working head considered, costing $67, appeared to be rather light, but the wholesalers stated that it was designed to do the required work.

(f) Pressure Tanks.

Father Allard wished to have two 4' x 24' tanks, holding 1257 gallons each at two-thirds capacity, for the requirements of the school. In this case no reserve supply other than that in the tanks will be available. One thousand dollars f.o.b. Delmas, is a very modest estimate.

The tanks should be placed before the wall is built.

(g) Windmill.

This question of a windmill as auxiliary power is open to criticism because
of the lack of power. A table of available power is as follows, in a 15-mile wind (a pleasant, brisk gale):

| Size of Windmill | Horse Power | Size of Windmill | Horse Power |
|------------------|-------------|------------------|-------------|
| 4'               | 1/12        | 12'              | 1           |
| 6'               | 1/5         | 14'              | 1-3/5       |
| 8'               | 3/10        | 16'              | 2-2/5       |
| 10'              | 3/5         | 18'              | 3-3/5       |

If the wind velocity be increased or decreased the power of the windmill will increase or decrease in the ratio of the square of the velocity.

You will note that a 14' wheel at least, will be needed. Inquiries elicited the fact that a 14' wheel is not made. The sizes are 10', 12', 15'. Consequently a 12' wheel would just about supply the necessary power.

The costs are as follows:

| Wheel Size | Horse Power | Head | Tower |
|------------|-------------|------|-------|
| 10 ft.     | 3/5 h.p.    | $101.00 | 91.30 |
| 12"        | 1 h.p.      | $180.00 | 110.00 |
| 15"        | 2 h.p.      | $336.00 | 166.00 |

Estimates were made on a 12' wheel, 40 ft. tower.

The location of the windmill and consequently the well, caused some trouble. It could not be placed over the basement because that would necessitate anchoring the legs.
(spread = 1/5 height) on the roof of the basement. The constant shifting strain of the tower would ruin the roof in a short time. Father Allard suggested the west side but this would necessitate an extra alcove 6' x 6' x 8', deep. It was determined at last to add the alcove on the north side adjacent to the entry. Three legs would then be on solid ground and the fourth on an extra post anchored to the present wall angle.

A 12' wheel would probably supply sufficient power most of the time, especially when the tanks are not filled to capacity and if the well be not the full 300 feet deep.

This matter of a windmill is fully discussed in order that the Indian Department will be in full possession of the facts.

(h) Labour

This will include all other work except concrete, the price of which is based on materials plus labour, erection of the windmill and demolition, excavation and the well proper. The sum of $200 appears to be none too large.

The remainder of the estimates are self-explanatory.
Conclusion

The whole matter has been fully discussed in this report since the Secretary of the Indian Department states that only $2500 is available. This office does not understand how work to the extent needed in this case can be done for $2500. It might be considered advisable by the Indian Department to decrease the walls to 8" and the floor to 4", use a 10' windmill, decrease the reinforcement, use a 1-1/2 h.p. engine, consider only a 250' well instead of 300', lessen the width to, say, 13 feet, make the saddles shallower, do without the windmill altogether, and thus eliminate the alcove, etc., etc. The total cost would be lessened but the efficiency and safety would also be lessened correspondingly.

The present estimates, similarly to Father Allard's, are based on summer conditions. The cost of winter work is difficult to estimate as men have to use a pick instead of a fresno or shovel, they lose time warming themselves, concrete must be warmed etc., etc. The percentage of cost increases on a comparatively small job such as this. Criticism for lessening costs without losing efficiency and safety will be welcomed. It is understood that the work will not be done by contract but by direct supervision from this office, supposedly under a good foreman, e.g. Geo. Devlin, of North Battleford, who constructed the water supply system at St. Barnabas School, Onion Lake, Saskatchewan.

If the work is to be completed before March 31 it should be begun about March 1. Three weeks will be
occupied in fabrication of the tanks. Before this is done the tenders have to be called from the firms enumerated in your letter of January 5. Negotiations in connection with this take some time.

The difficulties in connection with winter work have already been dealt with. If at all possible the work should be postponed until May. However, it is for the Indian Department to decide this matter.

P.A. FETTERLY,
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

O.H. HOOVER
Engineer-In-Charge.

Dear Sir,

Received yours of the 6th inst. stating you did not understand my last letter.

I was in Delmas three days ago. They informed me I have to board myself and hire man at Hotel and team of horses at livery barn because feed is scarce in this country. So, at that rate, I will have to put my bid in high.

36" hole at $2.50 per foot to water if there is no dry sand or dry gravel to bother with and when I strike water I will charge $2.25 per hour to make basin for water as you may understand the quick sand or gravel how hard it is to make a basin for water or otherwise the reservoir.

The case of a 4' well you may strike gravel or dry sand 10' below surface so therefore you have to dig a 4' well to get same crib to water, so this would cost $3.00 per foot to water and some $2.25 per hour to make basin.

You want information on well I have dug around Highgate and Delmas. Any well that I have dug around Highgate or Delman there is usually lots of water this is the two hardest districts to get water in.
The well run from 140' to 40' deep also 30' if you are lucky enough to hit the right place where water runs. How to my experience the drill wells are from 300' to 350' 225', but the water is bad, cattle are the only things that can drink it, and then you have to starve them for 3 or 4 days before they will drink it.

Also the drill wells. You cannot force your casing through after certain depth, so if this well requires to be drilled go ahead and drill and find out for yourselves, case anything may happen I may get all the blame for it. I have dug lots of wells in this country. I have been at it for 14 years and have not dug two wells alike any of these wells I have dug they have been located by water which so I do not know how deep you may have to go behind the school.

There are very few wells around Delmas or Highgate the water rise in them.

I will inform you of one thing. There is a good spring our far from the School there is ocean of water in it very best of water too. How I know I cleaned this well our five years ago I baled the well and you could not bale it out the well is only 40' deep. This spring runs a very short distance for school if you people had some way of tracing it it would be very valuable to you.

So there if you want to use the drill or if you want to bore, use your own judgment this is the very best information I can give you.

On other side of this page you will find the depth of some well I dug around Highgate & Delmas.

Yours truly,

BY S. L. MACDONALD, INDIAN AGENT.

---

Sir:-

I have the honor to submit herewith, the Annual school report for the Battleford Agency, for the year ending March 31st 1934.

There are now five schools in the Agency, the Thunderchild and Beauval Residential Schools and Day schools at Red Pheasant, Little Pine and Thunderchild reserves.

Thunderchild Residential.

This school is in the Village of Delmas about 18 miles west of Delmas on the main line of the Canadian National Railway. The building is of frame construction with full basement and stone and cement foundation; the old or main building is 2½ storey and the two wings on the north and south are three storey, the building is steam heated and fully modern. Their water supply is from the Railway track water tank, but steps are now under way to have their own water supply which is being installed by the Department.

Farming at the school is only on a small scale and at present about 40 acres are under cultivation there is a modern barn and there are usually twelve to fifteen milk cows in use.

The Staff consists of the Principal, 12 to 15 sisters, a Steam engineer, night watchman and a laborer and there is authority for 120 pupils at the school which is usually well up to capacity and is full at the present time.

This school is always well kept and everything in perfect condition, the children are well fed, clothed and are a clean healthy looking lot of pupils, happy and contented, there has not been a runaway from this school for years. This school is owned by the Sisters.

Interim Report

on

Proposed Water Supply System

at

Thunderchild Indian School

Delmas, Saskatchewan

by

P.A. Fetterly, B.Sc., R.P.E.

1. Purpose of Report

A Preliminary Report on the above named subject was prepared on January 23, 1934. An Addendum Report was prepared on January 30, 1934.

Since that time material has been ordered and delivered.

The writer visited the school on August 27th and on September 3 to inspect progress of drilling and to confer with the carpenters, etc., regarding the construction of the basement in pursuance to the letter of instructions from the Director dated August 2, 1934.

2. Progress of Well Drilling

Mr. Joseph Mahrick, well driller, began drilling on August 19. He found soil to a depth of 4 feet. He then struck quicksand. This quicksand is different from other quicksand of his experience. As soon as the casing enters it and the sand becomes wet it grips the casing so that a blow only lowers it a fraction of an inch. He was compelled to dig a hole 15 feet deep and 4 feet in diameter around the pipe and insert 20 feet of 8 inch casing obtained from Duck Lake School. The log is now:- 4' earth 22' Sand, 8' Clay and sand to 88'.
He is having a great deal of difficulty in lowering the casing. During the writer's visit on September 3, he arrived from Unity with a hydraulic outfit. He was going to try the hydraulic system. He mentioned that he might find it necessary to insert a slightly smaller casing, say $4\frac{1}{2}$" after a certain depth inside the $5-5/8$" casing.

Mr. Mahrick did not say very much but he was obviously disturbed over the difficulties he has encountered. He is, of course, being paid by the foot.

3. **Progress of Basement.**

The writer ascertained over the phone that Mr. G.A. Webster, of Unity, intended to proceed to the School with his helper only when the basement and tanks were in place and ready for connections. He is a tinsmith and steamfitter.

Mr. L.A. Riches of Riches and Jaynes, the other parties mentioned in the letter of instructions, met the writer at the School on September 3. The details of installation were then described and discussed.

Mr. Riches is beginning construction of the basement on September 10 with 3 men whom he will take from Unity. He will be paid at the rate of 50¢ per hour while the men will receive 25¢ per hour, similarly to the men at Duck Lake School. The work should occupy about one month.

The drilling and construction will be carried
on simultaneously for a time.

There is no way of ascertaining either the length of time occupied by Mr. Rahrick in drilling or his ultimate success in obtaining water. This Department now is well conversant with the hazards in this connection. At any rate, the basement has to be built regardless of the source of the water.

4. Excavation under Kitchen.

When the water supply system was first considered Father Allard, the Principal, stated that the School wished to excavate an area under the kitchen and contiguous to the proposed basement to provide for freer ingress into the tank basement. This excavation consists of about 80 cubic yards of earth. Father Allard at that time proposed that the school bear the expense.

He informed the writer on the present visit that school funds were lower than he had anticipated and that they could not undertake payment of costs. He stated that he was proceeding to Regina on September 4 to interview Mr. Murison on the subject and also on that of a concrete root cellar to the west of the tank basement.

The writer did not commit himself on the matter to Father Allard but it appears logical that this excavation should be done at the same time as the principal work. It certainly cannot be done after the walls are built and everything enclosed. It is therefore recommended that this extra work be undertaken at the same time. The extra cost will probably not exceed $50.00. As a matter of fact, this should be decided upon
immediately as the work of excavation is beginning on September 10.

Mr. Riches will obtain a team locally (Delmas) as the Fresno work will only occupy a few days.

5. Conclusion.

The Director will be kept informed of development and progress. Messrs. Rahrick and Riches were informed that Father Allard would be in practical charge as time keeper and representative of the Engineer-in-Charge, and in the absence of the writer. He understands the work thoroughly. It might be added that the men will attend to sustenance themselves.

Father Allard was requested to send a sample of water, if and when encountered, for analysis, to this office.

P.A. Fetterly
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

O.H. Hoover
Engineer-in-Charge.

Sir,

With further reference to your letter of 27th ultimo regarding the well at the above named school, I instructed Mr. P.A. Betterly, of this staff, to inspect conditions as soon as possible. He visited the school on October 5, spending the whole day conferring with the Principal and with Mr. Rahrick, well-driller, and studying the situation.

He reports as follows:

1. New Well

"I personally measured the depth of the well and found it to be 535 feet on October 5. Mr. Rahrick has been using a Hydraulic jet in drilling.

"The log of the well is as follows:

- 0 - 4' earth
- 4' - 24' sand (a little water)
- 24' - 32' shale
- 32' - 102' sand gravel and quicksand (a little water)
- 102' - 535' Blue clay and boulders; shale with a few hardpans.

"In order to obtain a sufficient supply the drill will have to penetrate sand, gravel or "Coal" of sufficient water carrying capacity."

Mr. Rahrick was informed that this office is not authorized to go beyond 500 feet, approximately.

He, together with his two helpers who are

The Director,
Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa.
experienced oil well drillers and practical geologists, have consistently made a close study of the log and believe that the formation is changing slightly and favourably. After a long discussion Mr. Rahrick stated that he had definitely made up his mind to go ahead for another hundred feet, or even possibly down to 700 feet in his own responsibility. This would seem to indicate that he believes he can reach water. He stated that, if he failed, possibly the Department might reimburse him to some extent while if he obtained water the Department would be sufficiently pleased to reward him even more adequately. At any rate he intends to try to get water regardless of possibility of financial reward as he does not wish to leave a job unfinished. I told him plainly that the responsibility was entirely his and he accepted the situation.

He said he had gone 700' at other times and found water. The water as a rule rises in the hole. He had never been compelled to place a cylinder lower than 300'. As a result of his decision he continued to drill Friday. My note reads:- He is unwilling to give up at present".

He has placed only 90' of casing in the well. He said the rest of the hole is sufficiently firm to hold up at present. He had to use dynamite occasionally (10 sticks in one instance at the 400' level) in order to remove boulders. He ruined his 300' of 2" rope and was compelled to purchase new rope. He put it on while I was there.

The well is now 535 feet deep as certified definitely by myself. Of course the casing is only inserted for 90 feet.

3. **General Situation.**

The general situation may be indicated by the fact that I was very considerably dismayed when receiving the views that no water had been struck down to 500 feet. Father Allard was in much the same state of mind and welcomed my appearance on the scene.

Sub-surface waters are too small in volume to be much of a factor. Several wells would have to be sunk, etc.,etc. In fact this seems out of the question.

Again the river is 1½ miles away and several
I visited the old pump house. It is on the edge of the North Saskatchewan river. The engine is a Fairbanks-Morse 25 h.p. torch ignition oil-burning engine.

The School Engineer runs the pump two days per week of 5 hours each using 1 gallon gas 2 gallons coal oil per hour, 1 pint of cylinder oil. He pumps 2' in the 60000 gallon tank through a 6" discharge pipe nearly 2 miles long. This is costing the school $100 per month.

Another factor is that the trains are not supposed to use water from this tank "except in cases of emergency". However, they load their trains heavily at Battleford and cannot get to Lloydminster on one filling. As a result the emergencies arise frequently. The school is pumping this water together with their own supply.

The Railway consider the tank and pipes as near the end of their usefulness. If necessity for replacement occurs or necessity arises I understand that their plan is to drill a well and construct a tank at Bressaylor, a few miles further west.

It is possible that in the end the supply will have to be obtained from the river through a 2" or 2½" pipe. It is unfortunate that the school is so far from the river.

The whole problem is straight cut and is very disturbing.

I hope that Mr. Rahbrick's bravery in going ahead will have its reward as his failure to obtain water will precipitate a very grave and difficult and expensive problem".

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

The undersigned conferred today with Mr. W.A. Johnston, Chief of the Borings Division of the Geological Survey, with respect to the deep well now being drilled at Thunderechild Indian School. After reading the reports on the well, Mr. Johnston stated that it would be useless to drill below the 700 foot depth now reached, that records of wells drilled in that district showed that water, if found at all, was generally at depths from 18 to 30 feet below the surface, no record of water being found deeper than 200 to 300 feet, and that if water should be struck at a lower depth in this formation it would be salt and unfit for use.

Generally speaking, the water near the surface is of better quality than that found lower down and in this case the river water, especially if filtered through a standpipe or caisson in the river, would be better than the well water. Also if the water in the well did not rise to say 200 feet from the surface, the cost of pumping from the river would not be much greater than the cost of pumping out of the well.

In this particular case, Mr. Johnston suggested that it would be best to try and make a well out of the existing drilled hole, as a preliminary measure and before abandoning it, in the following manner:

(a) Pull the casing out of the hole and replace with casing having screens at the two horizons where water has been found; that is between 4 feet and 24 feet and between 32 feet and 102 feet according to the log supplied in Mr. Hoover's letter of October 9th.

(b) If the casing cannot be pulled out due to the quicksand or for other reasons, perforate the casing at the horizons where water has been found and insert screens at these levels.

(c) Abandon the lower part of the well.

If these measures fail to produce a sufficient quantity of water, there appear to be two alternatives to obtain a water supply.

1. Drill or dig two or more shallow wells not exceeding 30 feet deep, of considerable width, similar to those already in existence, and connect them with pipes or drains so that the water may be collected in one well for pumping. These in effect would be
underground tanks for seepage, and except during a succession of dry years as at present, might readily supply enough water for the school.

2. Pump water from the North Saskatchewan river, with or without arrangements for filtering and storing it.

M.F. COCHRANE.

Sir,-

I beg to inform you that I visited the above named school to ascertain the possibilities of the spring mentioned by Father Allard.

I beg to report, in a preliminary way, that I interviewed Mr. Rahrick and also obtained information regarding the spring.

We discussed the suggestions mentioned in the Director's letter.

Neither (a), (b) or (c) are practical as only 5 balers (25 gallons) collected in 12 hours. Any system which involves using water in the sand from 4' to 100' is doomed to failure because of the paucity of water at these depths, the sand being hardly more than damp. Shallow wells in the vicinity 30' or 40' deep produce barely sufficient water for a family. That at 100' or less is similar.

Perforating the casing would produce similar results, viz:- only a nominal amount of water. It is to be noted that the casing is only down to 90 ft. at present. It cannot be pulled. (A perforator costs $700 or $800 according to Mr. Rahrick).

I asked Mr. Rahrick what he "honed" to obtain for the drilling from 535' to 700'. He states, incidentally, that the actual depth is over 700 feet. He also evidently considers that the official depth is 535 feet, not 500, as

O.H. Hoover, Esq.,
Calgary,
Alberta.
he received word to stop when he reached 535'. This appears only fair, as a matter of fact.

He stated that he thought that a 50-50 basis should be considered and named $600 gross. A 50-50 division would amount to $660 (165' x ½ of $8.00). I wish to obtain his idea of a fair deal.

He had not removed his rig from the School, although he had returned home to Unity himself. The reason for this was that he had a suggestion to make when I arrived (he came in from Unity today). His suggestion was to drill to the 200' depth - that is, between clay and shale, at some other point. He thought possibly water would be obtained. However, he removed his rig to Unity to-day after his conversation with me. Incidentally, I was told to-day that other wells were sunk to considerable depth in the general vicinity to 300' or 500' without water. One at Meota, 12 miles east, was 1100 ft. with no water. Other wells have produced water at various horizons. And so it goes.

The Spring.

The spring mentioned by Father Allard in his telegram lies to the Northwest of the school. It is on the farm of Mr. A. Lavallee and crosses the School farm and that of Mrs. U. Douville. It lies at an azimuth of 318° from the school. The spring is 7325 feet from the basement wall near the drilled well.

I ran a straight transit line from the School to the spring, using the 200 foot chain to place stakes 100 feet apart. I then obtained a profile of each 100' point. The
line falls fairly gradually with some rolls and irregularities from Sta. 0 to Sta. 71 + 90, the break of the hill. The fall from the School to the break on the hill is about 45 feet. The fall from the break to the spring, a distance of 130 feet, is 35 feet. The spring is in a coulee about 3/4 mile from the river proper. This hill forms a first break, as it were, in the descent to the river, over 200 feet further down. The coulee is really 100 feet wide and shallow, with the spring outlet in a smaller shallow coulee.

The farm house is at Sta. 70 and about 100 feet west of the line of stakes.

I tested the yield of the spring. The principal stream alone filled a 5 gallon pail in 15 seconds, a total of 28,800 gallons per day. The water actually pours out in a large stream over a trough which was put in 20 years ago and never removed. This spring water appears pure and it never varies in volume. The principal stream is probably three-quarters of the total amount emerging from the bank.

Father Allard was on a parochial visit to this home a few days ago. He was offered a drink of water. It was so cold and refreshing and free from alkali that he asked where it was obtained. He was shown the spring and also a pail that had been used to hold it for a year. This pail is quite clean and unmarked, as I saw it afterwards. I obtained a quart self-sealer full for analysis.

This report is a preliminary one as I may not return for several days and possibly the Director would be interested in ascertaining immediately my findings.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) P.A. Fetterly.

PROGRESS REPORT

on

WATER SITUATION

at

THUNDERCHILD INDIAN SCHOOL,

Delmas, Sask.,

by P.A. Netterly, B.Sc., R.P.E.

1. Purpose of Report

A wire was received from Father Allard, on Oct. 24, followed by a letter, describing a spring he had found about 1½ miles from the school which might be used for supply. Copies of the letter and telegram were sent to you on Oct. 26.

The writer visited the school on November 2 and examined the spring. He then prepared a preliminary report on the same evening. Copies of this report were sent to Ottawa under date November 6.

2. Comparative Elevations.

A profile was run in a straight line from the school to the spring to ascertain the general configuration of the surface and the difference in height. An actual construction line would diverge from this straight line westward in several places such as the vicinities of Stations 14, 26, 38, 42, 46, 62. In other words a falling contour would have to be located in order to negotiate the slightly rolling land. The general down slope is to the north and the river. Eight angles would be used.

The surface of the land at the new basement is
2.

99.6. The break in the hill at Station 71/90 is
56.2. Thus the total fall from the school to the break
is 43.4 feet, an average of 6' in 100' or 6%. The fall
from the break at 71/90 to the spring at 73/24 (Elevation
19.8) is 36.4 feet, an average of 27%.

The spring coulee falls rapidly to the
north.

3. Ownership of Spring.

The owner of the land upon which the spring
is located, Mr. A. Lavallee of Delmas, naturally thinks
that the spring belongs to him and valued it at $1000 in
conversation with Father Allard.

However, the Dominion Irrigation Act vested
ownership in the Crown, as the writer understands it, and
no doubt this ownership is now vested in the province by
the provincial act.

As a precautionary measure the writer inter-
viewed Mr. C.J. McGavin of the Department of Natural Resources
at Regina, regarding the matter. He agreed to give us a
tentative and unofficial prior right to file. Normal
application is deferred for the present.

4. Estimates.

It would necessitate a too great loss of
valuable time under present conditions for the writer to
prepare more than the most approximate and tentative
plans and estimates. Another reason is that
there is no doubt that the expense of development would be considerable because of the length of pipe and trench. The Department of Indian Affairs may not think it advisable to go further. The writer believes that it is an excellent and practicable source of water but the question of advisability of spending the money must be left with the Department.

The present system may cease at any time although present indications do not denote immediate failure although the expense is considerable. That would be to unduly alarm. Frequent repairs are however necessary.

It must be confessed that the idea of furnishing water to the town has occurred to the writer but this may be left for future consideration.

The "owner" of the spring could have a connection placed in his house which is only 100 feet from the line of pipe.

The estimates may be divided into three parts:

(a) Spring.

A hydraulic ram has been considered, as probably 40,000 or 50,000 gallons per day are produced while 6000 or 7000 gallons per day are needed at the school. The elevation (spring to tank) is about 75 feet. The coulee falls rapidly. A ram would have to be housed. Costs of a ram have not yet been obtained. One dealer
thought that the work, including head, friction on
7300 feet of 2" or 2½" pipe and working pressure of the
tanks, would be too great for practical use of a ram.
It would probably amount to 100 or 110 feet roughly.
This matter has been only tentatively considered.

If a regular pumping system were installed
the items would be as follows: Concrete cistern 8x8x8,
say, pump house, gasoline engine, force pump or
centrifugal pump and accessories. This would cost possibly
$1000 or $1100 altogether.

(b) Trench and pipe.

Enquiries have been made to the Town Engineer
of North Battleford, Sask. (20 miles from the school) regard-
ing a trench-digging machine the town is said to possess.
Data regarding frost line was also requested. However
tentative enquiries in Calgary have indicated that the
cost of trenching and backfilling a 9' trench amounts to
50¢ per lineal foot for a machine and $1.50 for hand
labour. A 2" pipe costs about 35¢ and 2½" pipe 38¢ per
foot.

Thus the cost of a completed trench would
appear to amount to 90¢ to $1.00 per foot. This price
must be considered as tentative only until more specific
data is obtained. A trench 6' or 8½" deep would be
proportionately less.

The cost of the trench would therefore be about
$7,000 with a trench digging machine, or $15,000 by hand
labour.
(a) School.

The water could be pumped directly into the pressure tanks but some form of automatic control would have to be evolved at the pumping plant. One sees no reason for a cistern at the school. Electricity could not well be used at the pumping plant as it is not very practical, the school not having much available power from the two Delco Light plants. In addition, the power, if available, would have to be taken to the spring, 7300 feet away.

The total cost would therefore be in the general vicinity of $9,000. This however would produce a sure and pure supply.

5. Conclusions.

Owing to failure of the well this would appear to be the only source available except the present source which will need rehabilitation frequently in part and possible replacement in the near or distant future. Two copies of a sketch plan are enclosed.

These are sufficient for present purposes as there was no practical value in spending time preparing detail plans until it is known whether the work will be proceeded with.

Father Allard stated that he was prepared to carry on as at present, even during the winter, until a competent system is decided upon.

The work could not well be done until spring as experience has taught this office that winter work in this vicinity practically doubles the cost.

P.A. Setterly

Calgary, Alberta, Nov. 15, 1934.
P.S. A letter has just been received from Father Allard stating that the "trench-digging" machine he had heard about in North Battleford is in reality a stone crusher. However, a machine may be available elsewhere. Maple Creek put in a new water system with one.

This sort of thing is very difficult to handle as many machines must be available if one knew where to find them.

It has since been suggested that

Number of gallons delivered by a ram in 24 hours = 

Gal. delivered by spring per minute x 936 x height of spring above ram ÷ by height in feet between ram and point of delivery.

e.g. \( \frac{25 \text{ gal.} \times 936 \times 10}{75' + 25 \text{ (friction etc.)}} \)

\( \frac{25 \times 936 \times 10}{100} = 2340 \text{ gallons per day.} \)

This allows the ram to be placed 10' below spring. This could be increased by lengthening the drive pipe and placing the ram further down the coulee. All possibilities have been considered only tentatively.

A No.8 ram costs about $250.
